[[File:Hedgehog Street garden at Hampton Court Palace Flower Show 2014.JPG|thumb|The show garden at Hampton Court Flower Show (2014). Designed by Tracy Foster, it won a gold medal and the People's Choice Award.]]'''Hedgehog Street''' is a [[UK]]-based [[conservation movement|conservation]] initiative set up by two [[charitable organisation]]s, the [[PTES|People's Trust for Endangered Species]] (PTES) and the [http://www.britishhedgehogs.org.uk/ British Hedgehog Preservation Society] (BHPS). The project was established in 2011 in response to a detected decline <ref>[http://www.ptes.org/files/1842_hedgehogs-_current_status_and_decline_anouschka_hof_phd_thesis.pdf Hof, A. (2009) A study of the current status of the hedgehog (''Erinaceus europaeus''), and its decline in Great Britain since 1960, PhD Thesis]</ref><ref>[http://ptes.org/files/1826_sobh_full_report.pdf Roos, S., Johnston, A. & Noble, D. (2012) The State of Britain’s Hedgehogs, BTO Research Report No. 598]</ref><ref>[http://ptes.org/files/1428_sobh2011lowres.pdf The State of Britain’s Hedgehogs (2011) by David Wembridge, PTES]</ref> in the [[European hedgehog|hedgehog]] (''Erinaceus europaeus'') population in Britain, where it is a [[indigenous (ecology)|native]] [[species]].
As of January 2017, over 47,000 volunteers have signed up to be ‘[https://www.hedgehogstreet.org/about-our-hedgehog-street-campaign/who-are-the-hedgehog-champions/ Hedgehog Champions]’, committing to making changes in their gardens to encourage and support wild hedgehogs (''Erinaceus europaeus'').
The [https://www.hedgehogstreet.org Hedgehog Street website] provides volunteers with information about the [https://www.hedgehogstreet.org/about-hedgehogs/ ecology and behaviour of hedgehogs], [https://www.hedgehogstreet.org/tips/ tips] on ways of managing gardens to benefit them, and free resources to encourage volunteers to recruit other people to participate.
==Hedgehogs and Development== One of the major objectives of the campaign is to work with the public and housing developers to connect gardens and greenspaces with '[https://www.hedgehogstreet.org/help-hedgehogs/link-your-garden/ Hedgehog Highways]', which are holes in fences/boundaries that allow hedgehogs to travel further to find food and nesting sites.
==Hampton Court Flower Show== In July 2014 there was a [https://www.hedgehogstreet.org/hamptoncourt/ Hedgehog Street garden] at the RHS [[Hampton Court Palace Flower Show]], designed by Tracy Foster, it featured a series of three linked gardens of differing styles. It won a gold medal and the People's Choice Award for 'best small garden'.<ref>[http://www.rhs.org.uk/shows-events/rhs-hampton-court-palace-flower-show/exhibitors/Hampton-gardens/hedgehog-street Hedgehog Street RHS website]</ref>
==Hedgehog Species Champion== In 2017, Secretary of State for Transport [[Chris Grayling|Chris Grayling MP]], was appointed the Species Champion for Hedgehogs in Parliament. The [https://www.buglife.org.uk/specieschampions Species Champion Project] partners Members of Parliament from England with wildlife organisations to bring political support to the protection and promotion of threatened wildlife. The project is run by a group of seven organisations: [[Amphibian and Reptile Conservation Trust|Amphibian and Reptile Conservation]], [[Bat Conservation Trust]], [[Buglife]], [[Bumblebee Conservation Trust]], [[Butterfly Conservation]], [[Plantlife]] and the [[RSPB]]. Additional support is provided by the [[Angling Trust]], the [[People's Trust for Endangered Species]], the British Hedgehog Preservation Society and [[Somerset Wildlife Trust]].
==References== <references/>
==External links== * [http://www.hedgehogstreet.org Hedgehog Street website]
[[Category:Environmentalism]] [[Category:Conservation in the United Kingdom]]

{{Infobox person | name = Helen Grace Scott<!-- use common name/article title --> | image = <!-- filename only, no "File:" or "Image:" prefix, and no enclosing [[brackets]] --> | alt = <!-- descriptive text for use by speech synthesis (text-to-speech) software --> | caption = | birth_name = Helen Grace Reswick<!-- only use if different from name --> | birth_date = {{Birth date|1915|06|16}} | birth_place = [[Brooklyn, New York|Brooklyn]], [[New York (state)|New York]], United States | death_date = {{Death date and age|1987|11|20|1915|06|16}} | death_place = | nationality = American | other_names = | occupation = | years_active = | known_for = Spying, radio and film work | notable_works = }} '''Helen Grace Reswick Scott Keenan''' (June 16, 1915 — November 20, 1987), more commonly, '''Helen Grace Scott''', was a [[United States]] citizen employed in the [[Office of Strategic Services]] and later the Office of U.S Chief Counsel for Prosecution of [[List of Axis personnel indicted for war crimes|Axis War Criminals]] on the staff of Justice [[Robert H. Jackson]] during [[World War II]]. She was also a broadcaster for [[Free France]] in [[Brazzaville]], and later in life, as '''Helen G. Scott''', was a close associate of [[François Truffaut]] and other French filmmakers.
==Early life== Helen Grace Reswick was born in [[Brooklyn, New York]], the daughter of William Reswick and Bessie Schwartz Reswick. She and her brothers were raised in [[Paris]], where their father worked as a journalist with the [[Associated Press]]. William Reswick, who was born in Ukraine, was also a correspondent in Moscow from 1922 to 1934, and wrote a memoir of his time there.<ref>"William Reswick, News Writer, 64; Former Reporter in Moscow Had Worked with Hoover, Baruch, and Otto Kahn" ''New York Times'' (June 3, 1954): 27. via [[ProQuest]]</ref> She was fluent in English and French from childhood.<ref name="CTObit" >Vincent Canby, [http://www.chicagotribune.com/news/ct-xpm-1987-12-03-8703300814-story.html "Helen Scott's Death Grieves Film World"] ''Chicago Tribune'' (December 3, 1987).</ref>
During [[World War II]], Reswick was a radio broadcaster for [[Free France]], based in [[Brazzaville]].<ref>Janet Bergstrom, [https://books.google.com/books?id=ePMxuoC5kTYC&lpg=PA393&ots=CIo0YC0T_N&dq=Brazzaville%20Helen%20G.%20Scott&pg=PA392#v=onepage&q=Brazzaville%20Helen%20G.%20Scott&f=false "Lost in Translation? Listening to the Hitchcock-Truffaut Interview"] in Thomas Leitch and Leland Poague, eds., ''A Companion to Alfred Hitchcock'' (John Wiley & Sons 2011): 392-394. {{ISBN|9781444397314}}</ref> After the war, she was a press attache to Justice Robert H. Jackson at the [[Nuremberg trials]]. She was recognized later for her wartime work: in 1965, the France Libre medal, and in 1986 she was named a "Chevalier De l'Ordre des Arts et des Lettres".<ref name="NYTObit">[https://www.nytimes.com/1987/11/24/obituaries/helen-g-scott-72-writer-for-truffaut-and-other-directors.html "Helen G. Scott, 72, Writer for Truffaut and Other Directors"] ''New York Times'' (November 24, 1987): 11.</ref>
==Alleged spy activities== Between 1933 and 1938, Helen Scott served on the Executive Committee of the [[Workers Alliance]], a [[Comintern]] affiliate front organization. In 1944, she worked for Congressman Boulton. Keenan had been a freelance journalist in the 1930s before beginning work in the [[Office of the Coordinator of Inter-American Affairs]] (OCIAA) as a writer and editor in 1945. She first worked for the New York line of [[KGB]], then later the [[Washington, D.C.]] branch of the KGB. {{Citation needed|date=June 2013}}
===Venona=== Helen Grace Scott Keenan's code name in Soviet intelligence, and later as deciphered by the [[Venona project]] is "Fir" (or "Spruce"). "Firtree" and "El" also occurred. Keenan is referenced in the following Venona decryptions:
*326 :KGB Moscow to New York, April 5, 1945; *3614–3615: KGB Washington to Moscow, June 22, 1945.
==Later career== Scott worked as a senior editor at the [[United Nations]] headquarters,<ref>Dolores Palà, [https://books.google.com/books?id=aVx0CQAAQBAJ&lpg=PT152&dq=Brazzaville%20Helen%20Scott&pg=PT152#v=onepage&q=Brazzaville%20Helen%20Scott&f=false ''The Way it Was''] (2015). {{ISBN|9781491766323}}</ref> and from 1959 to 1965 at the French Film Office in New York, as director of public relations.<ref>[http://articles.latimes.com/1987-11-26/news/mn-24609_1_french-directors "Passings: Helen G. Scott, French Arts Figure"] ''Los Angeles Times'' (November 26, 1987).</ref> She worked with many French and American filmmakers in this role, including [[Robert Benton]], [[Milos Forman]], [[Jacques Tati]], [[Alain Resnais]], and [[Jean-Luc Godard]]. She wrote the English subtitles of French-language films, including ''[[Manon des Sources (1986 film)|Manon of the Spring]]'' and ''[[Jean de Florette]]''.<ref name="NYTObit" />
She assisted François Truffaut as the interpreter in his conversations with [[Alfred Hitchcock]],<ref name="CTObit" /><ref name="NYTObit" /> using both her language skills and her specialized knowledge of film.<ref>Sidney Gottlieb, "Hitchcock on Truffaut" ''Film Quarterly'' 66(4)(Summer 2013): 10-22. DOI: 10.1525/fq.2013.66.4.10 via [[JSTOR]]</ref> She collaborated with Truffaut in writing the resulting book, ''[[Hitchcock/Truffaut]]'' (1966).<ref>François Truffaut in collaboration with Helen G. Scott, [https://books.google.com/books?id=W0YhcgAACAAJ&dq=Helen+G.+Scott&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiEseaJruDdAhWUFTQIHbBJC3kQ6AEILzAB ''Hitchcock''] (Simon and Schuster 1967). {{ISBN|9780586086537}}</ref> She wrote additional dialogue for Truffaut's ''Fahrenheit 451'' (1966), and was among the writers nominated for a [[Hugo Award]] when that film was a finalist for Best Dramatic Presentation in 1967.<ref>[http://www.thehugoawards.org/hugo-history/1967-hugo-awards/ 1967 Hugo Awards], The Hugo Awards official website.</ref> She translated another book of Truffaut's, ''The Adventures of Antoine Doinel'' (1971). Scott was Truffaut's confidante, and their correspondence offers insight into his personal life and relationships.<ref>Antoine de Baecque, Serge Toubiana, [https://books.google.com/books?id=a2H0AiDn4XIC&lpg=PA198&dq=Free%20French%20Helen%20Scott&pg=PA198#v=onepage&q=Free%20French%20Helen%20Scott&f=false ''François Truffaut''] (University of California Press 2000): 198, 208, 226. {{ISBN|9780520225244}}</ref>
Scott appeared in uncredited cameos in Godard's ''[[Weekend (1967 film)|Weekend]]'' (1967) and Truffaut's ''[[Bed and Board (1970 film)|Bed & Board]]'' (1970). She also appears in archival footage in the 2015 documentary ''[[Hitchcock/Truffaut (film)|Hitchcock/Truffaut]]''.<ref>Peter Travers, [https://www.rollingstone.com/movies/movie-reviews/hitchcock-truffaut-104244/ "Hitchcock/Truffaut"] ''Rolling Stone'' (December 3, 2015).</ref>
==Personal life== Helen G. Scott was divorced. She died in [[Paris]] in 1987, aged 72 years, from a heart attack.<ref name="CTObit" /> Her gravesite is in [[Montmartre Cemetery]], not far from Truffaut's.
==References== {{reflist}}
==Sources== * John Earl Haynes and Harvey Klehr, ''Venona: Decoding Soviet Espionage in America'' (New Haven: Yale University Press, 1999) * ''Underground Soviet Espionage Organization (NKVD) in Agencies of the United States Government'', 21 February 1946, [http://foia.fbi.gov/foiaindex/silversm.htm FBI Silvermaster file] (busted link) (65—56402), serial 573

{{more citations needed|date=July 2009}} '''The IATP Food and Society Fellows Program''' provides two-year, part-time fellowships to professionals working to address health, social justice, economic viability, environmental, and other issues in food and farming systems. The program started in 2001 as a collaboration between the [[Jefferson Institute]] and the [[Institute for Agriculture and Trade Policy]] (IATP), with the guidance and support of the [[W.K. Kellogg Foundation]]. The program is currently administered by IATP and funded by the W.K. Kellogg Foundation and the Woodcock Foundation.http://www.woodcockfdn.org Generally, 8-12 fellows are selected each year; 72 fellows have been selected through 2009.[http://www.iatp.org Institute for Agriculture and Trade Policy][http://www.foodandsocietyfellows.org/about Food and Society Fellows: About] ==Objectives== The goals of the Food & Society Policy Fellows Program are to: {{quote| *Use communication to influence the issues that reach the public agenda, thereby creating policy changes at the personal, organizational and public policy levels that advance sustainable food and farming systems *Increase the mass media communications on issues around sustainable food and farming systems that produce healthy, green, fair and affordable foods *Raise the profile of the fellows as food system experts among media and policymakers *Build capacity, leadership, and cohesiveness in a group of experts who collaborate and communicate using mass media channels to bring sustainable food system issues to the public agenda|[http://www.foodandsocietyfellows.org/about.cfm Food and Society Fellows - Program Overview]}} ==Food and Society Fellows== Food and Society Fellows organized by the year of their award.[http://www.foodandsocietyfellows.org/fellows IATP Food and Society Fellows] {{quote| '''2009-2010'''

page.title: Indigenous peoples and the UN-REDD Program in Panama

revision.text:
Following a series of disputes regarding the participation of [[indigenous peoples]] in the Panama UN-REDD National Programme, the National Coordinating Body of the Indigenous Peoples of Panama (COONAPIP) announced their withdrawal from the climate change mitigation program on February 25, 2013.<ref name=PRISMA>Cuellar, Nelson, Susan Kandel, Andrew Davis and Fausto Luna. “[http://www.prisma.org.sv/uploads/media/Indigenous_peoples_and_governance_in_REDD__readiness_in_Panama.pdf PRISMA Report Indigenous Peoples and Governance in REDD+ Readiness in Panama: Case Study on COONAPIP, ANAM and the UN-REDD Program]”. [http://www.prisma.org.sv/ The PRISMA Foundation]. Retrieved July 7th, 2013</ref> COONAPIP, which brings together the country´s seven indigenous peoples and their 12 traditional indigenous representative structures, cited a failure to ensure guarantees of respect for indigenous rights and the full and effective participation of indigenous peoples, and a breach of agreements made during the process of the program´s approval.<ref name=PRISMA /> In March 2013, the Panama UN-REDD National Programme was suspended pending the results of an independent investigation and evaluation.<ref>{{citeweb|url=http://www.un-redd.org/Newsletter36/Safeguards_and_MultipleBenefits/tabid/106077/Default.aspx|title=UN-REDD Launches Independent Evaluation of National Programme in Panama” UN-REDD Programme}} Retrieved July 5th, 2013.</ref> The dispute was highlighted as an important development in the broader context of global policy efforts to implement initiatives to [[Reducing emissions from deforestation and forest degradation|Reduce Emissions from Deforestation and Degradation]] (REDD+), which were at the time grappling with issues around the participation of indigenous peoples and forest communities in related initiatives, including the implementation of Free, Prior and Informed Consent.<ref name=PRISMA /> Preliminary results of an independent investigation and evaluation commissioned by the UN-REDD Programme were published,<ref>“Preliminary Report of the Independent Investigation and Evaluation Presented to the UN-REDD Policy Board” UN-REDD Programme. Retrieved July 11th, 2013.</ref> as well as a study of the conflict by a Central American non-governmental research center.<ref name=PRISMA />
In December 2013, the Panama UN-REDD National Programme was reopened following agreement between the Panama Government, through its National Environmental Authority (ANAM), and indigenous peoples, through the National Coordinating Entity of Indigenous Peoples in Panama (COONAPIP). This was realized through extensive consultations between ANAM and COONAPIP to resolve issues and develop an Environmental Agenda between indigenous peoples and the ANAM, which includes a revised result framework of the UN-REDD National Joint Programme of Panama. The General Assembly of COONAPIP, which took place on 29 November 2013 in Playa Muerto, in the Darien province of Panama, approved the Environmental Agenda jointly developed between ANAM and COONAPIP.<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=http://www.un-redd.org|title=Update: Panama Government and indigenous peoples in Panama agree to reopen UN-REDD National Programme|last=|first=|date=|website=|publisher=|access-date=}}</ref>
On the reopening of the National Programme in Panama, Candido Mezua, President of COONAPIP said, "We feel satisfied that the process followed with ANAM will help us to correct issues, and COONAPIP is going to engage again in the Programme." He added, "It is time to trust again".<ref name=":0" />
Mezua emphasized that REDD+ had to be conducted with full respect for the rights of indigenous peoples, asking for the support of UN agencies to ensure that rights such as free, prior and informed consent (FPIC) are respected and appropriate grievance mechanisms are made available for indigenous peoples. He further underscored the complexities and nuances of REDD+ and offered COONAPIP's contribution to national REDD+ efforts.<ref name=":0" />
In December 2013, UN-REDD Programme Policy Board congratulated Panama on its progress towards resolving the differences with the National Coordinating Body of Indigenous Peoples in Panama (COONAPIP) and announced the approval of a no-cost extension of Panama's National UN-REDD Programme until June 2015. The extension was approved together with a review of the new results framework of the Programme and with the full agreement of COONAPIP, who co-presented on a panel with the Government of Panama's National Environment Authority (ANAM) at the Eleventh Meeting of the UN-REDD Programme Policy Board, which took place from 9-10 December 2013 in Geneva.<ref name=":0" />
The UN-REDD Programme Policy Board, composed of representatives of partner countries, indigenous peoples and civil society, donor countries and UN agencies, was deeply appreciative of progress made in Panama and of the joint efforts of COONAPIP, ANAM and the UN-REDD Programme to resolve the conflict. Members noted that the experiences in Panama provided valuable lessons for other REDD+ countries and highlighted the importance of strong stakeholder engagement processes.<ref name=":0" />
==References== <references />

The '''International Decision Support Initiative''' ('''iDSI''') is a partnership between governments, universities, and thinktanks that helps health policy makers make better decisions.<ref name=about>{{cite web |url=http://www.idsihealth.org/about-us/ |title=ABOUT US |publisher=iDSI |accessdate=May 26, 2016}}</ref><ref name=phase2/> iDSI targets [[Developing country|low- and middle-income countries]] (LMICs),<ref>{{cite journal |url=http://www.bmj.com/content/bmj/352/bmj.i244.full.pdf |title=Role of priority setting in implementing universal health coverage |author=Yot Teerawattananon |publisher=The BMJ|display-authors=etal}}</ref> helping them prioritize health interventions as a means toward [[universal health coverage]].<ref name=cgdev>{{cite web |url=http://www.cgdev.org/working-group/priority-setting-institutions-global-health |title=Priority-Setting Institutions for Global Health |publisher=Center for Global Development |accessdate=May 29, 2016}}</ref> iDSI launched in November 2013<ref name=about/> as the result of a 2012 [[Center for Global Development]] working group.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.impatientoptimists.org/Posts/2016/02/The-International-Decision-Support-Initiative-Is-Scaling-UpThat-Means-Better-Decisions-and-Better-Health |title=The International Decision Support Initiative Is Scaling Up—That Means Better Decisions and Better Health |author=[[Amanda Glassman]] |date=February 8, 2016 |website=Impatient Optimists |publisher=Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation}}</ref><ref name=cgdev/>
==Partnerships==
The following organizations are iDSI's core partners:<ref name=phase2/>
* [http://www.imperial.ac.uk/centre-for-health-policy/our-work/global-health-and-development-group-/ Global Health and Development Group] (GHD) * HITAP ([[Health Intervention and Technology Assessment Program]], Thailand) * [[Center for Global Development]]<ref name=cgdev/> * [[PRICELESS SA]] (Priority Cost Effective Lessons for System Strengthening, South Africa)
Other partners include [[Centre for Health Economics]] (at the [[University of York]]), [[Imperial College London]], [[Itad]], [[Johns Hopkins Berman Institute of Bioethics]], the [[London School of Hygiene and Tropical Medicine]], [[Meteos (nonprofit company)|Meteos]], [[The Office of Health Economics|Office of Health Economics]], the [[University of Glasgow]], and the [[University of Strathclyde]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.idsihealth.org/who-we-are/supporting-partners/ |title=Supporting Partners |publisher=iDSI |accessdate=May 26, 2016}}</ref>
==Funding==
iDSI receives funding from the [[Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation]], the [[Department for International Development|UK Department for International Development]],<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.ohe.org/news/international-decision-support-initiative-idsi-mapping-priority-setting-health-17-low-and |title=international Decision Support Initiative (iDSI): Mapping of Priority-setting in Health in 17 Low and Middle Income Countries Across Asia, Latin America and Africa |accessdate=May 29, 2016 |date=April 22, 2015 |publisher=Office of Health Economics}}</ref> and the [[Rockefeller Foundation]].<ref name=about/><ref name=phase2/>
In December 2015, iDSI received $12.8 million in funding from the [[Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation]] for phase 2 of its operations.<ref name="phase2">{{cite web |url=http://www.idsihealth.org/blog/idsi2-launch/ |title=International Decision Support Initiative awarded US$12.8m grant from the Gates Foundation |publisher=iDSI |accessdate=May 26, 2016 |date=January 30, 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.gatesfoundation.org/How-We-Work/Quick-Links/Grants-Database/Grants/2015/12/OPP1134345 |title=National Institute for Health and Care Excellence |date=December 2015 |publisher=Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation}}</ref>
==Work==
iDSI has operated in China, India, Indonesia, Myanmar, the Philippines, South Africa, and Vietnam as "focus countries", but has also operated in additional countries.
Most of iDSI's work has focused on [[noncommunicable diseases]],<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.idsihealth.org/blog/idsi-in-action/india-2/ |title=iDSI in India |publisher=iDSI |accessdate=June 5, 2016}}</ref> [[Maternal death|maternal]] and [[Child mortality|child death]], and more general [[Priority-setting in global health|priority-setting]].
As part of their focus on [[universal health care]], iDSI has also worked on priority setting for mental health.<ref>{{cite web |author = Ryan Li |url=http://blogs.worldbank.org/health/comment/393#comment-393 |title=Thank you for raising such an |accessdate=May 29, 2016 |date=April 25, 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.idsihealth.org/blog/who-we-are/people/ryan-li/ |title=Ryan Li |publisher=iDSI |accessdate=May 29, 2016}}</ref>
iDSI is one of the collaborators for [[Disease Control Priorities Project#DCP3|DCP3]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://dcp-3.org/collaborators |title=Collaborators |publisher=DCP3 |accessdate=May 26, 2016}}</ref>

'''Kendall Carroll''' was shot March 19, 2013, just two weeks after the fatal [[Albuquerque Police Department]] (APD) shooting of [[Parrish Dennison]]. Kendall and his brother were both involved in an officer stand off. The stand off lasted for more than four hours. Michael the younger brother surrendered midway while Kendall continued on. State police sniper Shane Todd fired the lethal shot to end the stand off.
Throughout the altercation police threw tear gas into the apartment that the men were shooting at them from. Police were originally called to the scene because Kendall was a suspect in an earlier shooting which involved wounding an APD officer.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Lohmann|first1=Patrick|last2=Procter|first2=Jeff|title=New details in yesterday's SWAT standoff,police shooting|url=http://www.abqjournal.com/180341/news/state-police-kill-man-in-abq-standoff.html|accessdate=5 May 2015|agency=ABQ Journal|publisher=ABQ Journal}}</ref>

According to Cust & Cust, '''Kolarian''' is a word first used by George Campbell. He described it as one of the three non-Aryan language families of India, which he made up, along with the [[Tibeto-Burman]] and the [[Dravidian languages|Dravidian]].<ref name="CustCust2001">{{cite book|author1=Robert N. Cust|author2=Robert Needham Cust|title=A sketch of the modern languages of the East Indies|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=tTRpG1ulbewC&pg=PA79|accessdate=4 March 2012|origyear=1878|date=26 July 2001|publisher=Psychology Press|isbn=978-0-415-24501-2|pages=79–}}</ref>
Cust & Cust conjecture that the [[Austroasiatic language ]] family, its speakers were found in the then colonial provinces of Bengal, Madras and the Central provinces. They include the following languages as belonging to the group:<ref name="CustCust2001"/>
# [[Mundari language|Mundari]] # [[Ho language|Ho]] # [[Santali language|Santali]] # [[Kharia language|Kharia]] # [[Juang language|Juang]] # [[Korwa language|Korwa]] # [[Korku language|Korku]] # [[Sora language|Savara]] # [[Bondo language|Bondo]] # [[Gutob language|Gadaba]]
==Characteristics== Genders for animate and inanimate are different. Oblique forms for its nouns do not exist. It has a dual number and doesn't have a negative voice. There are two forms for each tense, which give the verb a transitive and intransitive meaning. There is variation in the meaning of the root achieved by infixing syllables, but the letters of the root remain unchanged<ref name="CustCust2001" /> Hastings considers Kolarian "radically distinct" from Dravidian, and an extreme example of an [[Agglutinative language]]. According to him its morphology "remotely resembles the Finno-Turki branch of the Ural-Altaic family. However on all other parameters it is completely different from "all other known forms of speech".<ref name="Hastings2003">{{cite book|author=James Hastings|title=Encyclopedia of Religion and Ethics|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=i53tYSX9SZEC&pg=PA158|accessdate=9 March 2012|date=24 January 2003|publisher=Kessinger Publishing|isbn=978-0-7661-3671-7|pages=119}}</ref>

[[File:LeadPaint1.JPG|thumb|[[Dutch Boy Paint]] logo (front)]] [[File:Lead Paint2.JPG|thumb|Dutch Boy Paint logo (rear)]]
'''Lead paint''' or '''lead-based paint''' is [[paint]] containing [[lead]]. As pigment, [[lead(II) chromate]] ([[Lead|Pb]] [[Chromium|Cr]] [[Oxygen|O<sub>4</sub>]], "[[chrome yellow]]"), [[Lead(II,IV) oxide]], ([[Lead|Pb<sub>3</sub>]] [[Oxygen|O<sub>4</sub>]], "red lead"), and [[lead(II) carbonate]] ([[Lead|Pb]] [[Carbon|C]] [[Oxygen|O<sub>3</sub>]], "[[white lead]]") are the most common forms.<ref name=Ullmann>{{cite encyclopedia|authors=Völz, Hans G. ''et al.''|title=Pigments, Inorganic|encyclopedia=Ullmann's Encyclopedia of Industrial Chemistry|year=2006|publisher=Wiley-VCH|place=Weinheim|doi=10.1002/14356007.a20_243.pub2}}.</ref> Lead is added to paint to accelerate [[drying oil|drying]], increase durability, maintain a fresh appearance, and resist moisture that causes corrosion. It is one of the main health and [[environmental issues with paint|environmental hazards associated with paint]]. In some countries, lead continues to be added to paint intended for domestic use,<ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.reuters.com/article/healthNews/idUSTRE57O64G20090825 | work=Reuters | title=Lead-laden paint still widely sold around the world | date=25 August 2009}}</ref> whereas countries such as the [[Lead-based paint in the United States|U.S.]] and the [[Lead-based paint in the United Kingdom|UK]] have regulations prohibiting this, although lead paint may still be found in older properties painted prior to the introduction of such regulations. Although lead has been banned from household paints in the United States since 1978, paint used in road markings may still contain it. Alternatives such as water-based, lead-free traffic paint are readily available, and many states and federal agencies have changed their purchasing contracts to buy these instead.{{fact|date=October 2016}}
==History== [[White lead|Lead white]] was being produced during the 4th century BC; the process is described by [[Pliny the Elder]], [[Vitruvius]] and the ancient Greek author [[Theophrastus]].
The traditional method making the pigment was called the stack process. Hundreds or thousands of earthenware pots containing vinegar and lead were embedded in a layer of either [[tan bark]] or cow [[feces]]. The pots were designed so that the vinegar and lead were in separate compartments, but the lead was in contact with the vapor of the vinegar. The lead was usually coiled into a spiral, and placed on a ledge inside the pot. The pot was loosely covered with a grid of lead, which allowed the carbon dioxide formed by the [[fermentation]] of the tan bark or the dung to circulate in the pot. Each layer of pots was covered by a new layer of tan, then another layer of pots. the heat created by the fermentation, [[acetic acid]] vapor and carbon dioxide within the stack did their work, and within a month the lead coils were covered with a crust of white lead. This crust was separated from the lead, washed and ground for pigment. This was an extremely dangerous process for the workmen. Medieval texts warned of the danger of "[[apoplexy]], [[epilepsy]], and paralysis" from working with lead white.<ref>Daniel V. Thompson, ''The Materials and Techniques of Medieval Painting'', p. 90-91.</ref>
Despite the risks, the pigment was very popular with artists because of its density and opacity; a small amount could cover a large surface. It was widely used by artists until the 19th century, when it was replaced by [[zinc white]] and [[titanium white]].<ref>Philip Ball (2000), ''Bright Earth, Art and the Invention of Colour'', pg. 99.</ref>
The dangers of lead paint were considered well-established by the beginning of the 20th century. In the July 1904 edition of its monthly publication, [[Sherwin-Williams]] reported the dangers of paint containing lead, noting that a French expert had deemed lead paint "poisonous in a large degree, both for the workmen and for the inhabitants of a house painted with lead colors".<ref name="SWP">{{cite web |url=http://babel.hathitrust.org/cgi/pt?id=nyp.33433066401898;view=1up;seq=110 |title=Dangers of White Lead |last1=Guenther |first1=Richard |date=1904-02-24 |website=[[Hathitrust]] |publisher=Sherwin Williams Co. |accessdate=2014-10-31}}</ref> As early as 1886, German health laws prohibited women and children from working in factories processing lead paint and [[lead sugar]].<ref name=ayass>{{cite book |editor1-last=Ayaß |editor1-first=Wolfgang |editor1-link=:de:Wolfgang Ayaß |date=1999-01-01 |title=Quellensammlung zur Geschichte der deutschen Sozialpolitik 1867 bis 1914, II. Abteilung: Von der kaiserlichen Sozialbotschaft bis zu den Februarerlassen Wilhelms II. (1881-1890), 3. Band: ''Arbeiterschutz'' |trans-title=Collection of Original Texts on the History of German Social Policy from 1867 through 1914, 2nd Series: from the Imperial Social Message Through the February Decrees of Wilhelm II (1881-1890), 3rd volume: ''Worker protection'' |language=German |location=Darmstadt |publisher=Wissenschaftliche Buchgesellschaft |isbn=3-534-13440-0 }}, sections 26 & 121</ref> In 1786, [[Benjamin Franklin]] wrote a letter warning a friend about the hazards of lead and lead paint, which he considered well-established.<ref>{{cite book |title=The Ingenious Dr. Franklin: Selected Scientific Letters of Benjamin Franklin |isbn=978-1258046989 |date=18 June 2011 |author=Benjamin Franklin |editor=Nathan G. Goodman |accessdate=20 July 2018 |url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=Wojw-wmYrNwC&pg=PA29&lpg=PA29 }}</ref>
The [[League of Nations]] began efforts to ban lead paint in 1921.<ref name=frowein>{{cite book |last1 = Frowein |first1 = Jochen A |last2 = Rüdiger |first2 = Wolfrum |year = 2000 |title = Max Planck Yearbook of United Nations Law |publisher = Martinus Nijhoff Publishers |isbn = 90-411-1403-3 |ref = harv}}</ref><ref name=newscientist>{{cite news |url=https://www.newscientist.com/article/mg21829190-200-the-wests-toxic-hypocrisy-over-lead-paint/ |date=29 May 2013 |title=The West's toxic hypocrisy over lead paint |work=[[New Scientist]] |accessdate=20 July 2018 |first=Perry |last=Gottesfeld }}</ref>
==Toxicity== {{further|Lead poisoning}} [[File:Lead Paint - cracking and flaking.jpg|thumb|right|Lead paint can crack and form flakes, which can contaminate the surrounding environment.]] Lead paint is hazardous. It can cause [[nervous system]] damage, stunted growth, [[kidney]] damage, and delayed development.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.atsdr.cdc.gov/toxfaqs/tf.asp?id=93&tid=22|title=ToxFAQs™ for Lead|date=August 2007|last=Agency for Toxic Substances and Disease Registry|publisher=Center for Disease Control}}</ref> It is dangerous to children because it tastes sweet,{{Citation needed|date=January 2018}} therefore encouraging children to put lead chips and toys with lead dust in their mouths. Lead paint is dangerous to adults and can cause reproductive problems in men or women. Decreases in sperm production in men have been noted. Lead is considered a possible and likely carcinogen. High levels may result in death.
==Regulation== {{Globalize/US|section|date=May 2012}} The [[European Union]] has passed a directive controlling lead paint use.
In Canada, regulations were first enacted under the Hazardous Products Act in 1976 that limited lead content of paints and other liquid coatings on furniture, household products, children's products, and exterior and interior surfaces of any building frequented by children to 0.5% by weight.<ref name="healthcanada-leadfaq">[http://www.hc-sc.gc.ca/ewh-semt/contaminants/lead-plomb/asked_questions-questions_posees-eng.php Some Commonly Asked Questions About Lead and Human Health], Health Canada</ref> New regulations on surface coating materials, which came into force in 2005, further limit lead to its background level for both interior and exterior paints sold to consumers. Canadian paint manufacturers have been conforming to this background level in their interior and exterior consumer paints since 1991.<ref>{{cite web|title=Lead and Health|url=http://www.hc-sc.gc.ca/ewh-semt/pubs/contaminants/lead-plomb-eng.php|publisher=Health Canada|accessdate=3 June 2013|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130603023707/http://www.hc-sc.gc.ca/ewh-semt/pubs/contaminants/lead-plomb-eng.php|archivedate=3 June 2013|df=}}</ref> Nevertheless, a Canadian company, Dominion Colour Corporation, is "the largest manufacturer of lead-based paint pigments in the world" and has faced public criticism for obtaining permission from the [[European Chemicals Agency]] to continue to export lead chromate paints from its Dutch subsidiary to countries where its uses are not tightly regulated.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/toronto/toronto-company-s-lead-based-products-a-danger-to-world-health-critics-say-1.3340853 |title=Toronto company's lead-based products a danger to world health, critics say |last=Fowler |first=Jennifer |date=1 December 2015 |work=[[CBC News]] |accessdate=20 April 2016}}</ref>
The United States' [[Consumer Product Safety Commission]] (CPSC) banned lead paint in 1977 in residential properties and public buildings (16 [[Code of Federal Regulations|CFR]] 1303), along with toys and furniture containing lead paint. The cited reason was "to reduce the risk of lead poisoning in children who may ingest paint chips or peelings".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cpsc.gov/cpscpub/prerel/prhtml77/77096.html|publisher=U.S. Consumer Product Safety Commission|title=CPSC Announces Final Ban On Lead-Containing Paint|date=2 September 1977|last=Office of Information and Public Affairs|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100819015700/http://www.cpsc.gov/CPSCPUB/PREREL/prhtml77/77096.html|archivedate=19 August 2010|df=}}</ref> For manufacturers, the CPSC instituted the [[Consumer Product Safety Improvement Act of 2008]], which changed the cap on lead content in paint from 0.06% to 0.009% starting August 14, 2009. In 2018 the State of Delaware banned the use of lead paint on outdoor structures.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://legis.delaware.gov/BillDetail?legislationId=26820|title=HB 456 AN ACT TO AMEND TITLES 14, 16, 17, 26, AND 29 OF THE DELAWARE CODE RELATING TO THE USE OF LEAD PAINTS ON OUTDOOR STRUCTURES.|last=State of Delaware|first=General Assembly|date=29 August 2018|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref>
In April 2010 the U.S. [[Environmental Protection Agency]] required that all renovators working in homes built before 1978 and disturbing more than six square feet of lead paint inside the home or 20 square feet outside the home be certified. EPA's Lead Renovation, Repair and Painting Rule (RRP Rule) lowers the risk of lead contamination from home renovation activities. It requires that firms performing renovation, repair, and painting projects that disturb lead-based paint in homes, child care facilities and pre-schools (any child occupied facility) built before 1978 be certified by EPA and use certified renovators who are trained by EPA-approved training providers to follow lead-safe work practices.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.epa.gov/getleadsafe/|title=U.S. EPA Renovation, Repair and Painting Program}}</ref>
As of 2018, there are an estimated 37 million homes and apartments with lead paint in the United States.<ref>{{cite news |last=Schmidt |first=Charles |url=https://undark.org/article/lead-testing-child-blood-levels/ |title=America’s Misguided War on Childhood Lead Exposures |work=Undark |date=2018-03-21 |accessdate=2018-03-22 }}</ref>
The Philippines banned lead paint in 2013, but in 2017, 15% of the paint still was not certified.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Mogensen|first1=Jackie Flynn|title=You’ll Probably Never Save as Many Lives as This Guy Who Got the Philippines to Stop Using Lead Paint|url=https://www.motherjones.com/politics/2018/04/youll-probably-never-save-as-many-lives-as-this-guy-who-got-the-philippines-to-stop-using-lead-paint/|accessdate=23 April 2018|work=[[Mother Jones (magazine)|Mother Jones]]|date=23 April 2018}}</ref>
Lead paint is not prohibited in India. A 2015 study found that over 31% of household paints in India had lead concentration above 10,000 parts per million (ppm), which far exceeds the [[Bureau of Indian Standards|BIS]] standard of 90 ppm for lead in paint.<ref>{{cite news |title=Over 31 percent paints have alarming levels of lead: study |url=http://indianexpress.com/article/lifestyle/health/over-31-percent-paints-have-alarming-levels-of-lead-study/ |journal=[[Press Trust of India]] |via=[[The Indian Express]] |accessdate=18 April 2016|date=9 June 2015}}</ref>
In [[South Africa]], the Hazardous Substances Act of 2009 classifies lead as a hazardous substance and limits its use in paint to 600 parts per million (ppm). A proposed amendment will modify this to 90 ppm, thereby almost completely eradicating lead from paint. The amendment would also include all industrial paints, which were previously excluded.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.engineeringnews.co.za/article/proposed-amendment-to-legislation-set-to-eliminate-lead-in-paint-2018-06-15|title=Proposed amendment to legislation set to eliminate lead in paint|last=Bulbulia|first=Tasneem|work=Engineering News|access-date=2018-09-25}}</ref>
==Lead paint in art==
===Oil paints=== In art, [[white lead|white lead paint]] is known as "flake white" or "Cremnitz white". It is valued for the ease of handling and resilience the lead confers to [[oil paint]]s. Lead white paint dries relatively quickly to form a strong, flexible paint film. Lead-based white is one of the oldest manufactured pigments. It was the only white pigment available to artists in appreciable quantities until the twentieth century, when zinc-white and titanium-white became available.<ref name="Mayer 1991">{{cite book|last=Mayer|first=Ralph|title=The artist's handbook of materials and techniques|year=1991|publisher=Viking|location=New York City|isbn=0670837016|edition=5. ed., rev. and updated}}</ref> Industrially produced lead white, the typical pigment from the 19th century until its ban, was thought to be inferior to traditionally fabricated forms, which had larger "flake" particles that conferred ease of handling.
Titanium and zinc whites are far less toxic than lead white and have largely supplanted it in most fine arts applications. Safety regulations have also made lead white more expensive and difficult to obtain in some regions, such as the EU. However, lead white oil paints are still produced and in use by artists who prefer their unique handling, mixing, and structural qualities.<ref name="Mayer 1991"/>
Flake white has various drawbacks, including a tendency to become transparent over time. It also blackens in the presence of certain atmospheric pollutants, although this can be reversed.
===Water-based paints=== Lead is not a traditional pigment in water mediums, as zinc is superior for works on paper, as is [[calcium hydroxide]] (slaked lime) for [[frescos]]. Lead-based paints, when used on paper, often cause the work to become discolored after long periods of time; the paint's lead carbonate reacts with [[hydrogen sulfide]] in the air and with acids, which often come from fingerprints.<ref>{{cite journal | title = A Study of the Discoloration Products Found in White Lead Paint | author = Claire L. Hoevel | journal = The American Institute for Conservation: Book and Paper Group Annual | volume= 4 | year = 1985 | url = http://aic.stanford.edu/sg/bpg/annual/v04/bp04-04.html}}</ref>
==Substitutes==
===Titanium=== Paint manufacturers have replaced white lead with a less toxic substitute, [[titanium white]] (based on the pigment [[titanium dioxide]]), which was first used in paints in the 19th century. Titanium dioxide is considered safe enough to use as a [[food coloring]] and in [[toothpaste]]. It is also a common ingredient in [[sunscreen]]. When used in paints today, it is often coated with [[silicon]] or [[aluminum oxide]]s for durability. Titanium white has far greater opacity and tinting strength than lead white, and it can easily overpower most other pigments if not mixed carefully. Titanium white has been criticized for leading to "chalkiness" in mixtures, and for allegedly decreasing the permanence of organic pigments mixed with it due to its high [[refractive index]].
===Zinc=== [[Zinc white]] is less opaque and weaker in tinting strength than either titanium white or lead white. It is commonly used to lighten mixtures subtly while maintaining transparency. Although zinc white is the standard white in watercolors, its structural soundness in oils has been debated. Zinc white dries slowly and creates a relatively inflexible paint film. Critics of the pigment argue that its use leads to excessive cracking and delamination, even when used sparingly.<ref name="naturalpigments">{{cite web|title=Zinc White – Problems in Oil Paint?|url=http://naturalpigments.com/education/article.asp?ArticleID=127|publisher=Natural Pigments LLC|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110206110619/http://naturalpigments.com/education/article.asp?ArticleID=127|archivedate=2011-02-06|df=}}</ref>

Chase | journal = Studies in Conservation | volume= 12 | issue= 4 | year = 1967 | pages = 125–139. | jstor=1505410}} * {{cite book |last= Ball |first= Philip |title= Bright Earth- Art and the Invention of Colour |year=2001 |publisher= Penguin Group |isbn= 9782754105033}} * {{cite book|url=http://www.press.umich.edu/titleDetailDesc.do?id=291047|title=Suing the Tobacco and Lead Pigment Industries: Government Litigation as Public Health Prescription|first=Donald G|last=Gifford|location=Ann Arbor|publisher=University of Michigan Press|year=2010|isbn=978-0-472-11714-7}} * {{cite book |last=Thomson |first=Daniel |title=The Materials and Techniques of Medieval Painting |year=1956 |publisher=Dover Publications |isbn=0-486-20327-1}}
