page.title: List of major crimes in Singapore

revision.text:
{{Update|date= November 2018}}
The following is a list of '''major [[Crime in Singapore|crimes in Singapore]]'''. They are arranged in chronological order.
==1960s==
===1963=== * 12 July 1963: A large number of detainees at the prison on [[Pulau Senang]] started a riot and killed prison officer Daniel Stanley Dutton and three of his assistants. After a five-month-long trial, 18 men were convicted of murder and hanged in Changi Prison on 29 October 1965. Another 29 men were also found guilty of rioting.<ref>{{cite web|last=Cornelius-Takahama|first=Vernon|url=http://infopedia.nl.sg/articles/SIP_728_2005-01-19.html|title=Pulau Senang|publisher=National Library Board, Singapore|date=2001|accessdate=20 November 2012|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130313050528/http://infopedia.nl.sg/articles/SIP_728_2005-01-19.html|archivedate=13 March 2013|df=}}</ref> * 27 August 1963: Sunny Ang Soo Kuan allegedly murdered his girlfriend, Jenny Cheok Cheng Kid, during a scuba-diving trip in the straits between [[Sisters' Islands]]. He was found guilty in a jury trial, sentenced to death, and hanged on 6 February 1967.<ref name="straitstimes.com">{{cite news|title=Guilty As Charged: Sunny Ang found guilty of girlfriend's murder though body was never found|url=http://www.straitstimes.com/singapore/courts-crime/guilty-as-charged-sunny-ang-found-guilty-of-girlfriends-murder-though-body|newspaper=The Straits Times|location=Singapore|date=16 May 2016|accessdate=16 May 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160516050602/http://www.straitstimes.com/singapore/courts-crime/guilty-as-charged-sunny-ang-found-guilty-of-girlfriends-murder-though-body|archive-date=2016-05-16|dead-url=no|df=}}</ref> Cheok's body was never found.<ref>{{cite web|author1=Jasli, Tettyana|author2=Chew, Valerie|url=http://infopedia.nl.sg/articles/SIP_1789_2011-09-26.html|title=The Sunny Ang murder case|publisher=National Library Board, Singapore|accessdate=20 November 2012|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130102145524/http://infopedia.nl.sg/articles/SIP_1789_2011-09-26.html|archivedate=2 January 2013|df=}}</ref>
==1970s==
===1970=== * 6 January 1970: 31-year-old dance hostess Mimi Wong Weng Siu and 37-year-old sweeper Sim Woh Kum were convicted of murder of a Mrs Watanabe and sentenced to death on Dec 7, 1970. Wong became the first woman to receive the capital punishment from a Singapore court. <ref>{{cite news|title=Guilty As Charged: Dance hostess Mimi Wong murdered her Japanese lover’s wife|url=https://www.straitstimes.com/singapore/courts-crime/guilty-as-charged-dance-hostess-mimi-wong-murdered-her-japanese-lovers-wife|newspaper=The Straits Times|location=Singapore|date=14 May 2016|accessdate=14 May 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160517103525/http://www.straitstimes.com/singapore/courts-crime/guilty-as-charged-dance-hostess-mimi-wong-murdered-her-japanese-lovers-wife|archive-date=2016-05-17|dead-url=no|df=}}</ref>
===1971=== * 29 December 1971: Businessman Ngo Cheng Poh and two of his employees were killed by a group of 10 men, who also robbed them of 120 gold bars. All were charged with murder.<ref>{{cite news|title=Guilty As Charged: Seven who killed for 120 gold bars hanged|url=http://www.straitstimes.com/singapore/courts-crime/guilty-as-charged-seven-who-killed-for-120-gold-bars-hanged|newspaper=The Straits Times|location=Singapore|date=16 May 2016|accessdate=16 May 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160516054911/http://www.straitstimes.com/singapore/courts-crime/guilty-as-charged-seven-who-killed-for-120-gold-bars-hanged|archive-date=2016-05-16|dead-url=no|df=}}</ref> Seven of the ten men were convicted of murder and hanged on 28 February 1975 while the remaining three were put under indefinite detention.<ref>{{cite web|last=Tok|first=Cherylyn|url=http://infopedia.nl.sg/articles/SIP_1753_2011-02-14.html|title=Gold Bar Murders|publisher=National Library Board, Singapore|accessdate=20 November 2012|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130313045835/http://infopedia.nl.sg/articles/SIP_1753_2011-02-14.html|archivedate=13 March 2013|df=}}</ref>
===1972=== * 18 September 1972: A 22-year-old seamstress Cheng Li Zhen was walking along [[Queenstown, Singapore|Queenstown]] with her sister when she suddenly screamed and collapsed to the ground with blood oozing out from her chest. It was only after she was in the hospital that they found that it was a gunshot wound. She never regained consciousness and died in the hospital soon after. The case remains unsolved.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Mystery of Queenstown 1972{{!}}My Queenstown|url = http://goodmorningyesterday.blogspot.sg/2009/04/mysterious-shooting-incident-in.html|website = myqueenstown.blogspot.sg|accessdate = 2015-10-18|archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20150924012522/http://goodmorningyesterday.blogspot.sg/2009/04/mysterious-shooting-incident-in.html|archive-date = 2015-09-24|dead-url = no|df = }}</ref> * 24 November 1972: Gunman Lim Ban Lim, who killed 27-year-old Corporal Koh Chong Thye on 23 June 1968, was ambushed by police officers in the vicinity of Block 6 near Golden City Theatre. Officers shot Lim three times in his body in a fire fight, killing Lim. His aide Chua Ah Kow shot himself dead during a gunfight three weeks later at Tank Road.<ref>{{cite news|title=Guilty As Charged: Lim Ban Lim was most wanted gunman in Singapore and Malaysia in 1960s|url=http://www.straitstimes.com/singapore/courts-crime/guilty-as-charged-lim-ban-lim-was-most-wanted-gunman-in-singapore-and|newspaper=The Straits Times|location=Singapore|date=16 May 2016|accessdate=16 May 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160515114826/http://www.straitstimes.com/singapore/courts-crime/guilty-as-charged-lim-ban-lim-was-most-wanted-gunman-in-singapore-and|archive-date=2016-05-15|dead-url=no|df=}}</ref>
===1974=== * 9 May 1974: 44-year-old Sim Joo Keow strangled her 53-year-old sister-in-law Quek Lee Eng over $2,000, before dismembering her body and keeping her torso in two earthen jars in her home. Quek's head and arms were found in a parcel near the Kallang River bank. Sim was sentenced to 10 years in jail in January 1975, after being convicted of manslaughter and hiding evidence.<ref>{{cite news|title=Guilty As Charged: Sim Joo Keow strangled sister-in-law, chopped up her body|url=http://www.straitstimes.com/singapore/courts-crime/guilty-as-charged-sim-joo-keow-strangled-sister-in-law-chopped-up-her-body|newspaper=The Straits Times|location=Singapore|date=16 May 2016|accessdate=16 May 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160515105714/http://www.straitstimes.com/singapore/courts-crime/guilty-as-charged-sim-joo-keow-strangled-sister-in-law-chopped-up-her-body|archive-date=2016-05-15|dead-url=no|df=}}</ref>
===1975=== * July 1975: District Judge E.C. Foenander sentenced Suhaymi Harith, 40, Khalil Mohammed Dol, 39, Wassan Sakeebun, 45, and Wagiman Abdullah, 47 a total of 64 years in jail plus 144 strokes of the cane. All four pleaded guilty to 228 charges of housebreaking, robbery and theft committed between Jan 5, 1973, and June 13, 1975.<ref>{{cite news|title=Guilty As Charged: Serial robbers, dressed in only their swimming trunks, terrorised residents|url=http://www.straitstimes.com/singapore/courts-crime/guilty-as-charged-serial-robbers-dressed-in-only-their-swimming-trunks|newspaper=The Straits Times|location=Singapore|date=16 May 2016|accessdate=16 May 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160517111748/http://www.straitstimes.com/singapore/courts-crime/guilty-as-charged-serial-robbers-dressed-in-only-their-swimming-trunks|archive-date=2016-05-17|dead-url=no|df=}}</ref>
===1978=== * 25 April 1978: 18-year-old police national serviceman [[Lee Kim Lai]]<ref>{{cite news|title=Guilty As Charged: Three friends who wanted to become robbers killed 2 men to get a gun|url=http://www.straitstimes.com/singapore/courts-crime/guilty-as-charged-three-friends-who-wanted-to-become-robbers-killed-2-men-to|newspaper=The Straits Times|location=Singapore|date=16 May 2016|accessdate=16 May 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160515103958/http://www.straitstimes.com/singapore/courts-crime/guilty-as-charged-three-friends-who-wanted-to-become-robbers-killed-2-men-to|archive-date=2016-05-15|dead-url=no|df=}}</ref> was abducted by three men from his sentry post at [[Mount Vernon, Singapore|Mount Vernon]] and forced into a taxi. They killed him for his service revolver and also killed the taxi driver. The three men were convicted of murder and hanged on 24 February 1984.<ref>{{cite news|title=Murderer's last gift — his eyes|url=http://eresources.nlb.gov.sg/newspapers/Digitised/Article/straitstimes19840226-1.2.28.aspx|newspaper=The Straits Times|location=Singapore|date=26 February 1984|accessdate=16 March 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160318222353/http://eresources.nlb.gov.sg/newspapers/Digitised/Article/straitstimes19840226-1.2.28.aspx|archive-date=2016-03-18|dead-url=no|df=}}</ref> *August 1978: Siti Aminah binte Jaffar, 24, a former barmaid and Anwar Ali Khan was caught for trafficking 43.5g of diamorphine (pure heroin), which exceeds the mandatory death penalty of 15g. Both were eventually sentenced to death. Anwar was hanged in 1983 after President Devan rejected his plea of clemency. Siti was spared with the death penalty and placed her under life imprisonment after President Devan accepted her plea of clemency. Siti became the first woman about to be sentenced to death for drug trafficking, but spared due to an accepted plea of clemency.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://eresources.nlb.gov.sg/newspapers/Digitised/Article/straitstimes19830219.2.33.1.aspx|title=Drugs woman told she will not hang|publisher=|access-date=2016-10-28|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161029115820/http://eresources.nlb.gov.sg/newspapers/Digitised/Article/straitstimes19830219.2.33.1.aspx|archive-date=2016-10-29|dead-url=no|df=}}</ref>
===1979=== * 6 January 1979: Four children between the ages of five and ten were found brutally slashed to death in their [[Housing and Development Board|HDB]] flat in [[Geylang|Geylang Bahru]]. The case remains unsolved.<ref>{{cite web|last=Kutty|first=N. G.|url=http://newspapers.nl.sg/Digitised/Article/straitstimes19790107.2.3.aspx|title=Four kids slashed to death...|newspaper=The Straits Times|location=Singapore|date=7 January 1979|accessdate=20 November 2012|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121107051236/http://newspapers.nl.sg/Digitised/Article/straitstimes19790107.2.3.aspx|archive-date=2012-11-07|dead-url=no|df=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Jasli|first=Tettyana|url=http://eresources.nlb.gov.sg/infopedia/articles/SIP_1872_2012-02-28.html|title=Geylang Bahru family murders|publisher=National Library Board, Singapore|accessdate=25 January 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141228000842/http://eresources.nlb.gov.sg/infopedia/articles/SIP_1872_2012-02-28.html|archive-date=2014-12-28|dead-url=no|df=}}</ref>
==1980s==
===1981=== * 25 January and 7 February 1981: Adrian Lim, a self-professed [[Mediumship|medium]], and his two accomplices murdered two children, purportedly as blood sacrifices in some ritual. The trial, which took 41 days, was the second longest murder trial in Singapore. The three of them were eventually found guilty, sentenced to death, and hanged on 25 November 1988. See [[Toa Payoh ritual murders]] for more information.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Munoo|first1=Rajendra|title=Adrian Lim Murders|url=http://eresources.nlb.gov.sg/infopedia/articles/SIP_71_2005-02-02.html?s=adrian%20lim|publisher=National Library Board, Singapore|accessdate=25 January 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160202103907/http://eresources.nlb.gov.sg/infopedia/articles/SIP_71_2005-02-02.html?s=adrian%20lim|archive-date=2016-02-02|dead-url=no|df=}}</ref>
===1983=== * 30 June and 23 July 1983: Sek Kim Wah, a 19-year-old [[National service in Singapore|conscript]], broke into the home of businessman Robert Tay Bak Hong at Andrew Road on 23 July with the aid of an accomplice, 19-year-old Malaysian Nyu Kok Meng. Sek killed Tay, his wife and their Filipino maid. Nyu released the Tays' daughter and her tutor. Sek also killed two persons at [[Seletar Reservoir]] earlier on 30 June. Sek was found guilty of murder and hanged on 9 December 1988 while Nyu was sentenced to life imprisonment and caning.<ref>{{cite news|title=Andrew Road murders: 19-year-old is charged|url=http://newspapers.nl.sg/Digitised/Article/straitstimes19830731-1.2.2.aspx|newspaper=The Straits Times|location=Singapore|date=31 July 1983|accessdate=25 January 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131112213359/http://newspapers.nl.sg/Digitised/Article/straitstimes19830731-1.2.2.aspx|archive-date=2013-11-12|dead-url=no|df=}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Andrew Road murders: Two for trial|url=http://eresources.nlb.gov.sg/newspapers/Digitised/Article/straitstimes19840322.2.102.aspx|newspaper=The Straits Times|location=Singapore|date=22 March 1984|accessdate=25 January 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160202124533/http://eresources.nlb.gov.sg/newspapers/Digitised/Article/straitstimes19840322.2.102.aspx|archive-date=2016-02-02|dead-url=no|df=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Execution By Hanging: 9/12/1988 Sek Kim Wah – Singapore|url=http://www.truecrimelibrary.com/crime_series_show.php?id=1041&series_number=13|website=True Crime Library|accessdate=25 January 2015|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121213165536/http://www.truecrimelibrary.com/crime_series_show.php?id=1041&series_number=13|archivedate=13 December 2012|df=}}</ref>
===1984=== * 12 December 1984: [[Death of Ayakannu Marithamuthu|Ayakanno Marithamuthu]], a caretaker at the [[Public Utilities Board]] holiday chalets in [[Changi]], was allegedly bludgeoned to death in the [[Orchard Road]] Presbyterian Church. His body was dismembered, cooked in curry, packed in plastic bags and disposed in rubbish bins along the roads. However, his remains and evidence of the murder were never found. His wife and her three brothers were charged in court in 1987 but released in the same year due to lack of evidence. The brothers were arrested again and released in June 1991 after spending four years in prison.<ref name="Other gruesome murders that took place in Singapore" />
===1985=== * 22 May 1985: Winnifred Teo Suan Lie, an 18-year-old [[Catholic Junior College]] student, was the victim of a rape and murder case. On 22 May, she left her house for a jog, but never returned home. Her mother made a police report. Teo's naked body was later found lying in undergrowth off Old Holland Road. She suffered multiple stab wounds on her neck. Her body showed signs of a fierce but futile protest, probably made when she was trying to fight off her killer(s). An autopsy showed that she had been sexually assaulted, and died of massive bleeding from the stab wounds. The murderer(s) were never discovered. The case remains unsolved.{{citation needed|date=January 2016}}
==1990s==
===1990=== * 15 May 1990: Tan Ah Hong and James Soh Fook Leong were stabbed by two men after chatting on the spiral steps of the Amber Beacon Tower at [[East Coast Park]]. They managed to make their way to a nearby restaurant for help. Soh, who was stabbed in the back, survived the ordeal. Tan died before the police arrived. She was stabbed in the neck, just below the ear. The murderers were never found and the case remains unsolved.{{citation needed|date=January 2015}}
===1991=== * 4 May 1991: Filipino domestic worker [[Flor Contemplacion]] murdered another Filipino domestic worker, Della Maga, and Nicholas Huang, the four-year-old son of Maga's employer. She was sentenced to death in January 1993 and hanged on 17 March 1995. The incident caused diplomatic relations between Singapore and the Philippines to be strained for some years.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Chew|first1=Valerie|title=Flor Contemplacion|url=http://eresources.nlb.gov.sg/infopedia/articles/SIP_1551_2009-07-31.html|publisher=National Library Board, Singapore|accessdate=25 January 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150107061231/http://eresources.nlb.gov.sg/infopedia/articles/SIP_1551_2009-07-31.html|archive-date=2015-01-07|dead-url=no|df=}}</ref> * September 1991: Dutchman [[Johannes van Damme]] was arrested at [[Changi Airport]] after the police found 9.5 pounds of heroin in his suitcase. He was found guilty of drug trafficking, sentenced to death, and hanged on 23 September 1994.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Shenon|first1=Philip|title=Singapore Executes a Dutch Engineer Arrested on Drug Charges|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1994/09/24/world/singapore-executes-a-dutch-engineer-arrested-on-drug-charges.html|newspaper=The New York Times|accessdate=25 January 2015|date=24 September 1994|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150209204916/http://www.nytimes.com/1994/09/24/world/singapore-executes-a-dutch-engineer-arrested-on-drug-charges.html|archive-date=2015-02-09|dead-url=no|df=}}</ref>
===1993=== * September 1993: Chong Poh Choon, a [[Republic of Singapore Navy|Navy]] regular, murdered his three children at their [[Housing Development Board|HDB]] flat in [[Bukit Batok]]. Chong was eventually sentenced to life imprisonment.<ref>{{cite news|title=Dad who killed children jailed for life|url=http://eresources.nlb.gov.sg/newspapers/Digitised/Article/straitstimes19940910-1.2.39.12.aspx|newspaper=The Straits Times|accessdate=25 January 2015|date=10 September 1994|location=Singapore|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160202114445/http://eresources.nlb.gov.sg/newspapers/Digitised/Article/straitstimes19940910-1.2.39.12.aspx|archive-date=2016-02-02|dead-url=no|df=}}</ref>
===1995=== * 8 March 1995: Briton [[John Martin Scripps|John Martin]] murdered South African Gerard George Lowe in River View Hotel, dismembered his body, and disposed the body parts in the [[Singapore River]]. He was found guilty of murder and hanged on 19 April 1996.<ref name="Other gruesome murders that took place in Singapore">{{cite news|title=Other gruesome murders that took place in Singapore|url=http://news.asiaone.com/News/AsiaOne+News/Crime/Story/A1Story20120403-337375.html|newspaper=The New Paper|location=Singapore|accessdate=25 January 2015|date=4 April 2012|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150104164706/http://news.asiaone.com/News/AsiaOne+News/Crime/Story/A1Story20120403-337375.html|archivedate=4 January 2015|df=}}</ref> * 23 Nov 1995: After bringing down Britain's oldest merchant bank Barings, Briton Nick Leeson pleaded guilty to two charges out of three charges of forgery and eight charges of cheating and was sentenced to 6½ years in prison.<ref>{{cite news|title=Guilty As Charged: Rogue trader Nick Leeson brought down Britain's oldest merchant bank Barings|url=http://www.straitstimes.com/singapore/courts-crime/guilty-as-charged-rogue-trader-nick-leeson-brought-down-britains-oldest|newspaper=The Straits Times|location=Singapore|accessdate=16 May 2016|date=16 May 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160516050310/http://www.straitstimes.com/singapore/courts-crime/guilty-as-charged-rogue-trader-nick-leeson-brought-down-britains-oldest|archive-date=2016-05-16|dead-url=no|df=}}</ref>
===1998=== * 20 April 1998: 23-year-old Malaysian freelance assistant cameraman and prop assistant Jonaris Badlishah killed 42-year-old make-up artist Sally Poh Bee Eng over a Rolex wrist watch. He was hanged on 8 Dec 1998 after a 19-day trial.<ref>{{cite news|title=Guilty As Charged: Jonaris Badlishah killed to get a Rolex for girlfriend|url=http://www.straitstimes.com/singapore/courts-crime/guilty-as-charged-jonaris-badlishah-killed-to-get-a-rolex-for-girlfriend|newspaper=The Straits Times|location=Singapore|accessdate=16 May 2016|date=16 May 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160515220659/http://www.straitstimes.com/singapore/courts-crime/guilty-as-charged-jonaris-badlishah-killed-to-get-a-rolex-for-girlfriend|archive-date=2016-05-15|dead-url=no|df=}}</ref>
==2000s==
===2001=== * 14 May 2001: Anthony Ler Wee Teang approached four youths and offered them a reward of S$100,000 to kill Annie Leong, his wife who was in the midst of divorcing him. A 15-year-old whom Ler had known for five years accepted the offer. Ler manipulated the youth to carry out the deed, and the youth fatally stabbed Leong with a knife given to him by Ler. Ler was found guilty of conspiring and abetting the murder of Leong and was hanged in December 2002. The youth was spared the death sentence because he was underage and placed under indefinite detention.<ref>{{cite news|title=Devil with a smile|url=http://news.asiaone.com/news/crime/devil-smile?page=0%2C0|newspaper=The Straits Times|location=Singapore|accessdate=25 January 2015|date=5 October 2013|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170407030133/http://news.asiaone.com/news/crime/devil-smile?page=0%2C0|archive-date=2017-04-07|dead-url=no|df=}}</ref>
===2002=== * 2 January 2002: British financial adviser Michael McCrea murdered his friend Kho Nai Guan and Kho's girlfriend, Lan Ya Ming, in Kho's apartment in Pinewood Garden. With the help of his girlfriend, Audrey Ong, and two others, McCrea disposed Kho and Lan's bodies in a car and abandoned it at the car park in [[Orchard Towers]]. McCrea and Ong fled from Singapore on 5 January and were arrested in Melbourne in June after being on the run for about six months. Ong was deported to Singapore and sentenced in February 2003 to 12 years imprisonment, while McCrea was extradited to Singapore in 2005 and sentenced to 24 years imprisonment in June 2006.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Tan|first1=Yee Lin|title=Orchard Towers double murder|url=http://eresources.nlb.gov.sg/infopedia/articles/SIP_1603_2009-10-31.html|publisher=National Library Board, Singapore|accessdate=25 January 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150210053321/http://eresources.nlb.gov.sg/infopedia/articles/SIP_1603_2009-10-31.html|archive-date=2015-02-10|dead-url=no|df=}}</ref> * December 2002: Australian [[Van Tuong Nguyen]] was convicted of carrying about 400 grams of heroin at [[Changi Airport]] while travelling from Cambodia to Australia and sentenced to death in March 2004 by the [[High Court of Singapore|High Court]]. After a failed appeal to the [[Court of Appeal of Singapore|Court of Appeal]] and despite pleas for clemency from the Australian government, Nguyen was hanged on 2 December 2005.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/asia-pacific/4487366.stm|title=Australian executed in Singapore|date=2 December 2005|publisher=BBC News|accessdate=26 January 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141129075117/http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/asia-pacific/4487366.stm|archive-date=2014-11-29|dead-url=no|df=}}</ref>
===2004=== * 44-year-old Chia Teck Leng was sentenced to 42 years in jail by High Court Judge Tay Yong Kwang after swindling four foreign banks out of $117 million from 1999 to 2003 using his position as the financial manager of [[Asia Pacific Breweries]] (APB).<ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.straitstimes.com/singapore/courts-crime/guilty-as-charged-chia-teck-leng-led-a-double-life-and-cheated-banks-of | title=Guilty As Charged: Chia Teck Leng led a double life and cheated banks of millions | publisher=Straits Times | date=16 May 2016 | accessdate=16 May 2016 | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160517061212/http://www.straitstimes.com/singapore/courts-crime/guilty-as-charged-chia-teck-leng-led-a-double-life-and-cheated-banks-of | archive-date=2016-05-17 | dead-url=no | df= }}</ref> * 10 October 2004: Eight-year-old Huang Na was found dead and stuffed inside a box at [[Telok Blangah Hill Park]]. Malaysian Took Leng How, an acquaintance of Huang's mother, was found guilty of murder and sentenced to death on 27 August 2005. Took was hanged on 3 November 2006 after failing to overturn his conviction at the [[Court of Appeal of Singapore|Court of Appeal]] and after [[President of Singapore|President]] [[S. R. Nathan]] rejected his plea for clemency. See [[Murder of Huang Na]] for more information.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Tan|first1=Yee Lin|title=Huang Na murder|url=http://eresources.nlb.gov.sg/infopedia/articles/SIP_1604_2009-10-31.html|publisher=National Library Board, Singapore|accessdate=25 January 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150110042757/http://eresources.nlb.gov.sg/infopedia/articles/SIP_1604_2009-10-31.html|archive-date=2015-01-10|dead-url=no|df=}}</ref> * November 2004: Nigerian [[Iwuchukwu Amara Tochi]] was arrested at Changi Airport for carrying 100 capsules containing heroin. He was hanged on 26 January 2007 after failing to overturn his conviction at the Court of Appeal and after President S. R. Nathan rejected his plea for clemency.<ref>{{cite news|title=Young Tochi hanged for heroin smuggling|url=http://www.smh.com.au/news/world/young-tochi-hanged-for-heroin-smuggling/2007/01/26/1169594481223.html|publisher=The Sydney Morning Herald|date=26 January 2007|accessdate=26 January 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160209074955/http://www.smh.com.au/news/world/young-tochi-hanged-for-heroin-smuggling/2007/01/26/1169594481223.html|archive-date=2016-02-09|dead-url=no|df=}}</ref>
===2005=== * 15–16 June 2005: Factory supervisor Leong Siew Chor murdered his lover, Chinese national Liu Hong Mei, and dismembered her body into seven parts. He dumped her body parts in the [[Kallang River]] and other places in Singapore. He was arrested on 17 June 2005 and sentenced to death on 19 May 2006. Leong was hanged on 30 November 2007 after President S. R. Nathan rejected his plea for clemency.<ref name="Other gruesome murders that took place in Singapore" /><ref>{{cite web|last1=Tok|first1=Cherylyn|title=Kallang body parts murder|url=http://eresources.nlb.gov.sg/infopedia/articles/SIP_1793_2011-03-17.html|publisher=National Library Board, Singapore|accessdate=25 January 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141227143223/http://eresources.nlb.gov.sg/infopedia/articles/SIP_1793_2011-03-17.html|archive-date=2014-12-27|dead-url=no|df=}}</ref> * 7 September 2005: Filipino domestic worker Guen Garlejo Aguilar killed another Filipino domestic worker, Jane Parangan La Puebla, over a sum of S$2,000 that La Puebla owed her. She hid La Puebla's body in her room for two days before dismembering it and dumping the body parts near [[Orchard MRT Station]] and [[MacRitchie Reservoir]]. The court found her guilty of manslaughter and sentenced her to 10 years imprisonment in May 2006.<ref name="Other gruesome murders that took place in Singapore" />
===2006=== * 15 February 2006: Tan Chor Jin shot and killed nightclub owner Lim Hock Soon at his apartment. He was nicknamed "One Eyed Dragon" by the Singaporean media because he was blind in his right eye. The Court of Appeal dismissed Tan's appeal against his death sentence on 30 January 2008<ref>{{cite web|title=Tan Chor Jin v Public Prosecutor [2008] 4 SLR 306; [2008] SGCA 32|url=http://www.singaporelaw.sg/sglaw/laws-of-singapore/case-law/free-law/court-of-appeal-judgments/13530-tan-chor-jin-v-public-prosecutor-2008-4-slr-306-2008-sgca-32|website=SingaporeLaw.sg|accessdate=25 January 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160130170543/http://www.singaporelaw.sg/sglaw/laws-of-singapore/case-law/free-law/court-of-appeal-judgments/13530-tan-chor-jin-v-public-prosecutor-2008-4-slr-306-2008-sgca-32|archive-date=2016-01-30|dead-url=no|df=}}</ref> and he was hanged in January 2009.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Teo|first1=Wan Gek|title=Donor 'designated kidney expressly' for Tang|newspaper=The Straits Times|location=Singapore|url=http://news.asiaone.com/News/the+Straits+Times/Story/A1Story20090111-113780.html|accessdate=25 January 2015|date=11 January 2009|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160131175029/http://news.asiaone.com/News/the+Straits+Times/Story/A1Story20090111-113780.html|archive-date=2016-01-31|dead-url=no|df=}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=The suspected murderer who shocked Singapore|url=http://www.taipeitimes.com/News/world/archives/2007/01/22/2003345842|accessdate=25 January 2015|agency=Taipei Times|date=22 January 2007|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140607153720/http://www.taipeitimes.com/News/world/archives/2007/01/22/2003345842|archive-date=2014-06-07|dead-url=no|df=}}</ref>
===2008=== * 18 September 2008: Chinese national Wang Zhijian murdered his lover Zhang Meng, 41, Zhang's daughter Feng Jianyu, 17, and Zhang's flatmate Yang Jie, 36, in Zhang's house. He also attempted to murder Yang's daughter, Li Meilin, 15. At the end of the trial in November 2012, he was sentenced to death for only Yang's murder while successfully raising the defence of diminished responsibility for the murder of the other two. In November 2014, during the cross-appeal between Wang and the prosecution, Wang's appeal against the death sentence was rejected while the prosecution's appeal was allowed, which made Wang guilty of all three murders.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Yishun triple murders: A look back at the case|url = http://www.straitstimes.com/singapore/courts-crime/yishun-triple-murders-a-look-back-at-the-case|website = The Straits Times|accessdate = 2015-10-18|last = migration|archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20151107054145/http://www.straitstimes.com/singapore/courts-crime/yishun-triple-murders-a-look-back-at-the-case|archive-date = 2015-11-07|dead-url = no|df = }}</ref>
===2009=== * April 2009: Chinese national Wang Wenfeng was sentenced to death for murdering taxi driver Yuen Swee Hong. Although he failed in his appeal against his sentence in the Court of Appeal in July 2012, he was re-sentenced to life imprisonment and caning in 2013 after changes to the law took effect that year.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Lee|first1=Amanda|title=Man spared the gallows despite killing cabbie|newspaper=Today|location=Singapore|url=http://www.todayonline.com/singapore/man-spared-gallows-despite-killing-cabbie|accessdate=25 January 2015|date=14 November 2013|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160129231901/http://www.todayonline.com/singapore/man-spared-gallows-despite-killing-cabbie|archive-date=2016-01-29|dead-url=no|df=}}</ref>
==2010s==
===2010=== *3 July 2010: Calvin Tan Jian Wei, Edwin Tan Jian An and Ho Boon Sheng intoxicated an 18-year-old pub waitress and raped her in a hotel in Jiak Chuan Road on the night of 3–4 July 2010. They were arrested in the morning of 4 July and sentenced in 2015 to imprisonment and caning.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Lim|first1=Yvonne|title=Brothers jailed for assisting in rape of pub waitress|url=http://www.todayonline.com/singapore/brothers-jailed-assisting-rape-pub-waitress|accessdate=13 January 2015|publisher=MediaCorp Press Ltd|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150111215845/http://www.todayonline.com/singapore/brothers-jailed-assisting-rape-pub-waitress|archive-date=2015-01-11|dead-url=no|df=}}</ref>
===2011=== *16 May 2011: The dead body of Ruliyawati, an Indonesian domestic worker, was discovered in the rooftop water tank of a HDB flat in [[Woodlands, Singapore|Woodlands]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Indonesian maid's body found in Woodlands rooftop water tank|url=http://news.asiaone.com/News/AsiaOne+News/Singapore/Story/A1Story20110516-279169.html|accessdate=27 December 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150104173405/http://news.asiaone.com/News/AsiaOne+News/Singapore/Story/A1Story20110516-279169.html|archive-date=2015-01-04|dead-url=no|df=}}</ref> A coroner's inquest found that she had drowned herself but the two wounds on her back were caused by her boyfriend, Bangladeshi national Mohammed Repon Mostafa. Repon, who was initially accused of her death, was granted a discharge not amounting to an acquittal in 2013.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Jalelah Abu Baker|title=Water tank death: Maid drowned but two wounds were caused by boyfriend|newspaper=The Straits Times|url=http://www.straitstimes.com/singapore/water-tank-death-maid-drowned-but-two-wounds-were-caused-by-boyfriend|accessdate=23 January 2016|date=May 2, 2013|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160208003110/http://www.straitstimes.com/singapore/water-tank-death-maid-drowned-but-two-wounds-were-caused-by-boyfriend|archive-date=2016-02-08|dead-url=no|df=}}</ref>
===2012=== *28 May 2012: The police found the body of Mallika Jesudasan, 56, with neck injuries in a flat in [[Bukit Batok]]. Jesudasan was said to have been killed in a bedroom by her 31-year-old son, Sujay Solomon Sutherson, believed to be mentally ill.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Suspect in Bukit Batok murder charged|url = http://news.asiaone.com/News/Latest+News/Singapore/Story/A1Story20120529-349002.html|website = news.asiaone.com|accessdate = 2015-10-27|archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20160217054550/http://news.asiaone.com/News/Latest+News/Singapore/Story/A1Story20120529-349002.html|archive-date = 2016-02-17|dead-url = no|df = }}</ref> Sujay was convicted of culpable homicide not amounting to murder on 15 September 2015 and sentenced to life imprisonment.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Siau|first1=Ming En|title=Man who slit his mum's throat sentenced to life imprisonment|url=http://www.channelnewsasia.com/news/singapore/cy-man-who-slit-mum-s/2129376.html|accessdate=23 January 2016|agency=Channel News Asia|date=16 September 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160131104058/http://www.channelnewsasia.com/news/singapore/cy-man-who-slit-mum-s/2129376.html|archive-date=2016-01-31|dead-url=no|df=}}</ref>
===2013=== *10 July 2013: Staff Sergeant Iskandar bin Rahmat murdered 67-year-old Tan Boon Sin and his 42-year-old son Tan Chee Heong. The body of the elder Tan was found in his home at Hillside Drive in Kovan while the body of his son was dragged under a car for one kilometre from the home before being dislodged outside [[Kovan MRT Station]].<ref>{{Cite web|title = 'I was fearing for my life': Kovan double murders accused claims self-defence|url = http://www.channelnewsasia.com/news/singapore/i-was-fearing-for-my-life/2228116.html|accessdate = 2015-12-02|archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20151205162528/http://www.channelnewsasia.com/news/singapore/i-was-fearing-for-my-life/2228116.html|archive-date = 2015-12-05|dead-url = no|df = }}</ref> Justice [[Tay Yong Kwang]] of the [[High Court of Singapore|High Court]] found Iskandar guilty of murder on 4 December 2015 and sentenced him to death.<ref>{{cite web|title=Public Prosecutor v Iskandar bin Rahmat [2015] SGHC 310|url=http://www.singaporelawwatch.sg/slw/attachments/74322/%5B2015%5D%20SGHC%20310.pdf|website=Singapore Law Watch|accessdate=23 January 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160129084708/http://www.singaporelawwatch.sg/slw/attachments/74322/%5B2015%5D%20SGHC%20310.pdf|archive-date=2016-01-29|dead-url=no|df=}}</ref> *16 November 2013: Tuti Aeliyah, a 28-year-old Indonesian domestic helper, stabbed and strangled her employer's daughter, 16-year-old Shameera Basha Noor Basha, to death.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Domestic helper charged with murder for allegedly stabbing employer's daughter to death|url = http://www.todayonline.com/singapore/domestic-helper-charged-murder-allegedly-stabbing-employers-daughter-death|website = TODAYonline|accessdate = 2015-10-27|archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20160129231911/http://www.todayonline.com/singapore/domestic-helper-charged-murder-allegedly-stabbing-employers-daughter-death|archive-date = 2016-01-29|dead-url = no|df = }}</ref> She was initially charged with murder, but the charge was reduced to culpable homicide after she was diagnosed to be suffering from severe depression with psychotic symptoms. The High Court found her guilty and sentenced her to 12 years imprisonment in May 2015.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Lum|first1=Selina|title=Maid jailed 12 years for strangling 16-year-old girl with pinafore|newspaper=The Straits Times|url=http://www.straitstimes.com/singapore/courts-crime/maid-jailed-12-years-for-strangling-16-year-old-girl-with-pinafore|accessdate=23 January 2016|date=25 May 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160208003023/http://www.straitstimes.com/singapore/courts-crime/maid-jailed-12-years-for-strangling-16-year-old-girl-with-pinafore|archive-date=2016-02-08|dead-url=no|df=}}</ref> *25 November 2013: 44-year-old Lim Ann Nee allegedly drowned her 17-month-old son, Emilien Lacroix, in the sea off [[East Coast Park]] and was charged with murder. She was found to be suffering from acute transient psychotic disorder and had her charge reduced to culpable homicide in 2014. On 24 March 2015, she was given a discharge not amounting to an acquittal.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Chong|first1=Elena|title=Woman given a discharge over son's death as she was of unsound mind then|newspaper=The Straits Times|url=http://www.straitstimes.com/singapore/courts-crime/woman-given-a-discharge-over-sons-death-as-she-was-of-unsound-mind-then|accessdate=23 January 2016|date=24 March 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160208002959/http://www.straitstimes.com/singapore/courts-crime/woman-given-a-discharge-over-sons-death-as-she-was-of-unsound-mind-then|archive-date=2016-02-08|dead-url=no|df=}}</ref> *8 December 2013: About 400 men rioted in [[Little India, Singapore|Little India]] after a fatal bus accident. 28 men were arrested at the scene, of whom four were released. 52 Indian nationals and one Bangladeshi national were repatriated (see [[2013 Little India riot]]). *12 December 2013: 33-year-old Jasvinder Kaur's decapitated body was found in the Whampoa River. The body was topless and missing two arms, only dressed in a pair of black pants. 25-year-old Gursharan Singh, a forklift driver, was charged with murder, while the other murder suspect, 33-year-old Harvinder Singh, Kaur's husband, is on [[Interpol]]'s wanted list.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Headless body murder an organised crime of passion: Coroner's report|url = http://www.channelnewsasia.com/news/singapore/headless-body-murder-an/2013196.html|website = Channel NewsAsia|accessdate = 2015-10-27|archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20151102061417/http://www.channelnewsasia.com/news/singapore/headless-body-murder-an/2013196.html|archive-date = 2015-11-02|dead-url = no|df = }}</ref> On 28 July 2015, a coroner's court found that Kaur had been murdered by Harvinder Singh, who is still on the run. Gursharan Singh was sentenced to 30 months imprisonment in April 2015 for helping Harvinder Singh to get rid of Kaur's body.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Ho|first1=Olivia|title=Headless woman killed by hubby: Court|newspaper=The Straits Times|url=http://www.straitstimes.com/singapore/courts-crime/headless-woman-killed-by-hubby-court|accessdate=23 January 2016|date=29 July 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160208001225/http://www.straitstimes.com/singapore/courts-crime/headless-woman-killed-by-hubby-court|archive-date=2016-02-08|dead-url=no|df=}}</ref>
===2014=== *8 January 2014: 41-year-old Lee Sze Yong and 50-year-old Heng Chen Boon kidnapped Ng Lye Poh, the 79-year-old mother of Lim Hock Chee, the chief executive officer of the [[Sheng Siong]] supermarket chain. The case was solved within 12 hours after a police report was made.<ref>{{cite news|title=Sheng Siong Kidnapping|url=http://www.straitstimes.com/sheng-siong-kidnapping|accessdate=21 May 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150523141703/http://www.straitstimes.com/sheng-siong-kidnapping|archive-date=2015-05-23|dead-url=no|df=}}</ref> Heng, who was originally charged with kidnapping, had his charge reduced on 9 April 2015. In May 2015, he pleaded guilty to abetting Lee to abduct Ng, and was sentenced to three years imprisonment. Lee is charged with kidnapping and was sentenced to life imprisonment and caning after he was found guilty on November 2016.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Alkatib|first1=Shaffiq|title=Lawyers of Sheng Siong kidnapping accomplice say he was too trusting of friend he helped|url=http://news.asiaone.com/news/singapore/lawyers-sheng-siong-kidnapping-accomplice-say-he-was-too-trusting-friend-he-helped|website=Asia One|accessdate=23 January 2016|date=14 May 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160217054513/http://news.asiaone.com/news/singapore/lawyers-sheng-siong-kidnapping-accomplice-say-he-was-too-trusting-friend-he-helped|archive-date=2016-02-17|dead-url=no|df=}}</ref> *4 June 2014: 51-year-old Andrea Tay Su Lin killed her 75-year-old mother, Rosaline Lim, at their flat in [[Ang Mo Kio]]. She then committed suicide by throwing herself out from the window. Tay had a poor relationship with her mother, whom she blamed for her grandmother's death.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Chong|first1=Elena|title=Ang Mo Kio double death: Woman killed mum and took her own life, says coroner|newspaper=The Straits Times|url=http://www.straitstimes.com/singapore/courts-crime/ang-mo-kio-double-death-woman-killed-mum-and-took-her-own-life-says-coroner|accessdate=23 January 2016|date=3 December 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160208003048/http://www.straitstimes.com/singapore/courts-crime/ang-mo-kio-double-death-woman-killed-mum-and-took-her-own-life-says-coroner|archive-date=2016-02-08|dead-url=no|df=}}</ref> *11 June 2014: A body without legs was found in a luggage at Syed Alwi Road, [[Little India, Singapore|Little India]]. Two Pakistani men were arrested as suspects in the case.<ref>{{cite news|title=Grisly legless body find: Two Pakistanis held for murder|url=http://www.todayonline.com/singapore/grisly-legless-body-find-two-pakistanis-held-murder|accessdate=27 December 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140617093704/http://www.todayonline.com/singapore/grisly-legless-body-find-two-pakistanis-held-murder|archive-date=2014-06-17|dead-url=no|df=}}</ref> They were found guilty of murder on February 17th 2016 and sentenced to death.<ref>{{cite news|title=Legless body in suitcase: Duo found guilty, to hang for murder|newspaper=The Straits Times|url=http://www.straitstimes.com/singapore/courts-crime/legless-body-in-suitcase-duo-found-guilty-to-hang-for-murder?xtor=CS1-10#link_time=1487299045|accessdate=18 February 2016}}</ref> *21 August 2014: 80-year-old Char Chin Fah was accused of murdering his daughter-in-law, 54-year-old Ong Guat Leng, in their home in [[Tampines]]. Chin was remanded at Complex Medical Centre in [[Changi]] for psychiatric assessment in August 2014. He was sentenced to 8 years in jail in 2016.<ref>{{cite news|last=Poh|first=Ian|title=Tampines murder case: 80-year-old accused remanded for psychiatric evaluation|newspaper=The Straits Times|url=http://www.straitstimes.com/singapore/courts-crime/tampines-murder-case-80-year-old-accused-remanded-for-psychiatric-evaluation|accessdate=23 January 2016|date=27 August 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160208003011/http://www.straitstimes.com/singapore/courts-crime/tampines-murder-case-80-year-old-accused-remanded-for-psychiatric-evaluation|archive-date=2016-02-08|dead-url=no|df=}}</ref> *20 November 2014: 40-year-old Jackson Lim Hou Peng was accused of murdering a Vietnamese woman, 32-year-old Tran Cam Ny, in a flat in [[Ang Mo Kio]]. On 19 December 2014, Lim was found to be "not of unsound mind" after an extended period of psychiatric evaluation and was due to be tried in court.<ref>{{cite news|last=Lim|first=Yvonne|title=Man accused of murdering Vietnamese woman fit to plead in court|newspaper=Today|url=http://www.todayonline.com/singapore/man-accused-murdering-vietnamese-woman-fit-plead-court|accessdate=23 January 2016|date=19 December 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160130060213/http://www.todayonline.com/singapore/man-accused-murdering-vietnamese-woman-fit-plead-court|archive-date=2016-01-30|dead-url=no|df=}}</ref> *17 December 2014: Zheng Xianghua, a Chinese national, stabbed himself after allegedly killing Wang Xueyan, also a Chinese national, in a flat in [[Tampines]]. He was charged with murder on 20 December 2014,<ref>{{Cite web|title=Man charged in Tampines murder case|url=http://news.asiaone.com/news/crime/man-charged-tampines-murder-case|website=Asia One|accessdate=23 January 2016|date=21 December 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160217063137/http://news.asiaone.com/news/crime/man-charged-tampines-murder-case|archive-date=2016-02-17|dead-url=no|df=}}</ref> but the charge was subsequently reduced to culpable homicide not amounting to murder, and Zheng was sentenced to 9 years' imprisonment on 11 April 2016.<ref>{{Cite web|title=Truck driver jailed 9 years for killing wife he suspected of having affair|url=http://www.straitstimes.com/singapore/courts-crime/truck-driver-jailed-9-years-for-killing-wife-he-suspected-of-having-affair|website=The Straits Times|accessdate=26 May 2016|date=11 April 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160416225430/http://www.straitstimes.com/singapore/courts-crime/truck-driver-jailed-9-years-for-killing-wife-he-suspected-of-having-affair|archive-date=2016-04-16|dead-url=no|df=}}</ref>
===2015=== * 13 April 2015: Annie Ee Yu Lian, a 26-year-old waitress, died from acute fat [[embolism]] as a result of systematic abuse from her flatmates in the flat at Woodlands over a period of 8 months. The couple, Tan Hui Zhen and her husband Pua Hak Chuan, admitted in High Court to charges of voluntarily causing grievous hurt with a dangerous weapon resulting in Ee's death and was sentence to 16.5 years and 14 years jail respectively on 1 December 2017. In addition, Pua was given 14 strokes of the cane.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://sg.news.yahoo.com/couple-admits-causing-flatmates-death-systematic-abuse-145204129.html|title=Couple admit to causing flatmate’s death through ‘systematic’ abuse|publisher=|access-date=2018-01-12|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180112101217/https://sg.news.yahoo.com/couple-admits-causing-flatmates-death-systematic-abuse-145204129.html|archive-date=2018-01-12|dead-url=no|df=}}</ref>
*5 October 2015: Belgian national Philippe Graffart allegedly murdered his five-year-old son, Keryan Graffart, at their D'Leedon condominium along Farrer Road.<ref>{{cite news|title=Singapore police extend investigation of Belgian charged with son's murder|url=http://www.bangkokpost.com/news/asean/782849/singapore-police-extend-investigation-of-belgian-charged-with-son-murder|accessdate=2 December 2015|agency=AFP}}</ref> *November 2015: 26-year-old Neo Chun Zheng murdered former [[Scoot]] air stewardess, 23-year-old Soh Yuan Lin, by stabbing her in the neck with a knife outside his HDB flat in [[Boon Lay]].<ref>{{cite news|last1=Lee|first1=Pearl|title=Man charged with murder of former air stewardess|url=http://www.straitstimes.com/singapore/courts-crime/man-charged-with-murder-of-former-air-stewardess|accessdate=3 December 2015|publisher=Straits Times|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20151202050005/http://www.straitstimes.com/singapore/courts-crime/man-charged-with-murder-of-former-air-stewardess|archive-date=2015-12-02|dead-url=no|df=}}</ref>
===2016=== *14 February 2016: 47-year-old Singaporean Loh Suan Lit murdered 57-year old Teck Whye Chin Long Kong Temple helper Tan Poh Huat.<ref>{{cite news|title=47-year-old Singaporean charged with Teck Whye temple murder|url=http://www.channelnewsasia.com/news/video/47-year-old-singaporean/2552822.html|accessdate=7 March 2016|publisher=CNA|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160307221409/http://www.channelnewsasia.com/news/video/47-year-old-singaporean/2552822.html|archive-date=2016-03-07|dead-url=no|df=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Man charged with Teck Whye temple murder brought to various crime scenes|url=http://razor.tv/section/77922/vertical.html?movideo_p=77922&movideo_m=1467786|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160307163421/http://razor.tv/section/77922/vertical.html?movideo_p=77922&movideo_m=1467786|dead-url=yes|archive-date=7 March 2016|publisher=The New Paper|accessdate=7 March 2016}}</ref> *25 February 2016: 50-year-old coffee-shop assistant Khor Tzoong Meng murdered 38-year-old Ang Kim Keat at Blk 23 [[Hougang]] Avenue 3.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Ong|first1=Justin|title=Coffeeshop assistant charged for Hougang murder|url=http://www.channelnewsasia.com/news/singapore/coffeeshop-assistant/2550538.html|accessdate=7 March 2016|publisher=CNA|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160307164337/http://www.channelnewsasia.com/news/singapore/coffeeshop-assistant/2550538.html|archive-date=2016-03-07|dead-url=no|df=}}</ref> *13 March 2016: 68-year-old Kong Peng Yee murdered his wife 63-year-old Wong Chik Yeok at [[Compassvale]] Crescent.<ref>{{cite news|title=Man charged with wife's murder|url=http://news.asiaone.com/news/crime/man-charged-wifes-murder|accessdate=16 March 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160317072512/http://news.asiaone.com/news/crime/man-charged-wifes-murder|archive-date=2016-03-17|dead-url=no|df=}}</ref> *22 March 2016: Boh Soon Ho, 47, was charged on Thursday (Apr 7) with the murder of his 28-year-old girlfriend, Chinese national Zhang Huaxiang, before he fled to Malaysia.<ref>{{cite news|title=Circuit Road Murder|url=http://www.straitstimes.com/singapore/courts-crime/28-year-old-woman-found-dead-in-circuit-road-block|access-date=2016-05-26|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160519062450/http://www.straitstimes.com/singapore/courts-crime/28-year-old-woman-found-dead-in-circuit-road-block|archive-date=2016-05-19|dead-url=no|df=}}</ref>

==Australia== * [[Australian Army]] ** [[1st Armoured Regiment (Australia)|1st Armoured Regiment]]: ''{{lang|la|Paratus}}'' ([[Latin]] for "prepared") ** [[1st Commando Regiment (Australia)|1st Commando Regiment]]: Strike swiftly ** [[2nd Commando Regiment (Australia)|2nd Commando Regiment]]: ''{{lang|la|Foras admonitio}}'' ([[Latin]] for "without warning") ** [[Royal Australian Artillery]]: ''{{lang|la|Quo fas et gloria ducunt}}'' ([[Latin]] for "Where right and glory lead") ** [[Royal Australian Engineers]]: ''{{lang|la|Ubique}}'' ([[Latin]] for "everywhere") and ''{{lang|fro|honi soit qui mal y pense}}'' ([[Old French]] for "evil be to him who evil thinks") *** [[Special Operations Engineer Regiment (Australia)|Special Operations Engineer Regiment]]: ''{{lang|la|Inter hastas et hostes}}'' ([[Latin]] for "between spears and enemies") ** [[Royal Australian Regiment]]: Duty first ** [[Special Air Service Regiment]]: Who dares wins * [[Royal Australian Air Force]]: ''{{lang|la|Per ardua ad astra}}'' ([[Latin]] for "through adversity to the stars") ** [[No. 41 Wing RAAF|No. 41 Wing]]: Pass not unseen ** [[No. 42 Wing RAAF|No. 42 Wing]]: Defend from above ** [[No. 44 Wing RAAF|No. 44 Wing]]: Steadfastness ** [[No. 78 Wing RAAF|No. 78 Wing]]: Fight ** [[No. 81 Wing RAAF|No. 81 Wing]]: Prepared to fight ** [[No. 82 Wing RAAF|No. 82 Wing]]: Find and destroy ** [[No. 84 Wing RAAF|No. 84 Wing]]: Guide and deliver ** [[No. 86 Wing RAAF|No. 86 Wing]]: Precision ** [[No. 92 Wing RAAF|No. 92 Wing]]: Watch and ward ** [[No. 395 Expeditionary Combat Support Wing RAAF|No. 395 Wing]]: Expeditionary support ** [[No. 396 Expeditionary Combat Support Wing RAAF|No. 396 Wing]]: Steadfast in support * [[Royal Australian Navy]]: Serving Australia With Pride ** [[Fleet Air Arm (RAN)|Fleet Air Arm]]: Unrivalled ** [[Royal Australian Navy Submarine Service|Submarine Service]]: Silent service
==Austria== * [[Jägerbataillon 26]]: ''{{lang|la|Kärntner allzeit voran}}'' ([[German language|German]] for "Carinthians always ahead") * [[Jagdkommando]]: ''{{lang|la|Numquam retro}}'' ([[Latin]] for "Never back down") * [[Jägerbataillon 25 Airborne]]: "{{lang|la|Mutig Tapfer Treu}}" ([[German language|German]] for "Brave Bravely Faithful")
==Bangladesh== * [[Bengali Armed Forces]]: ''{{lang|bn|Cira unnata mama śira}}'' ([[Bengali language|Bengali]] for "Ever High is My Head") ** [[Bengali Army]]: ''{{lang|bn|Samarē āmarā śāntitē āmarā sarbatra āmarā dēśēra tarē}}'' (Bengali for "In War, In Peace We are Everywhere for our Country") ** [[Bengali Navy]]: ''{{lang|bn|Śāntitē saṅgrāmē samudrē durjaẏa}}'' ([[Bengali language|Bengali]] for "In War and Peace Invincible at Sea") ** [[Bengali Air Force]]: ''{{lang|bn|Bānlāra ākāśa rākhiba mukta}}'' ([[Bengali language|Bengali]] for "Free shall we keep the sky of Bengal") ** [[Bengali Coast Guard]]: ''{{lang|bn|Sāgarē abhibhābaka}}'' ([[Bengali language|Bengali]] for "Guardian at Sea")
==Brazil== *Corpo de Fuzileiros Navais ([[Brazilian Marine Corps]]): Ad sumus ([[Latin]] for "here we are") *[[Grupamento de Mergulhadores de Combate]]: ([[ Brazilian Navy Combat Diver]]): Fortuna Audaces Sequitur ([[Latin]] for "luck follow the brave") *[[1º Batalhão de Ações de Comandos]]: ([[ 1° Commando Action Battalion]]):Maximo de confusão, morte e destruição na retaguarda do inimigo ([[Portuguese language|Portuguese]] for " Maximum of confusion, death and destruction behind the enemy lines") *[[1º Batalhão de Forças Especiais]]: ([[ 1º Special Forces Battalion]]): O Ideal como Motivação; A Abnegação como Rotina; O Perigo como Irmão e A Morte como Companheira ([[Portuguese language|Portuguese]] for " The Ideal as Motivation; Self-denial as routine; Danger as a Brother and Death as a Companion.") *[[Batalhão de Operações Policiais Especiais (PMERJ)]]: ([[ Special Police Operations Battalion]]): Missão dada é missão cumprida ([[Portuguese language|Portuguese]] for " A mission given is an accomplished mission") *[[Comando de Operações Táticas]]: ([[Tactical Operations Command]]): Em qualquer hora, em qualquer lugar para qualquer missão ([[Portuguese language|Portuguese]] for "At anytime, anywhere for any mission")
== Canada == * [[Canadian Army]]: ''{{lang|la|Vigilamus pro te}}'' ([[Latin]] for "we stand on guard for thee") ** [[Royal Regiment of Canadian Artillery]]: ''{{lang|la|Quo fas et gloria ducunt}}'' ([[Latin]] for "where duty and glory lead") and ''{{lang|la|ubique}}'' ([[Latin]] for "everywhere") ** [[1 Canadian Mechanized Brigade Group]]: ''{{lang|la|Semper vigilans}}'' ([[Latin]] for "always vigilant") *** [[Lord Strathcona's Horse (Royal Canadians)]]: Perseverance ** [[2 Canadian Mechanized Brigade Group]]: ''{{lang|la|Audacia et fortitudo}}'' ([[Latin]] for "strength and courage") *** [[The Royal Canadian Dragoons]]: ''{{lang|la|Audax et celer}}'' ([[Latin]] for "bold and swift") *** [[The Royal Canadian Regiment]]: ''{{lang|la|Pro patria}}'' ([[Latin]] for "for country") ** [[5 Canadian Mechanized Brigade Group]]: ''{{lang|fr|Allons-y}}'' ([[French language|French]] for "let's go") *** ''{{lang|fr|[[12e Régiment blindé du Canada|12{{sup|e}} Régiment Blindé du Canada]]}}'' (12th Canadian Armoured Regiment): ''{{lang|la|Adsum}}'' ([[Latin]] for "I am present") *** [[Royal 22nd Regiment]]: ''{{lang|fr|Je me souviens}}'' ([[French language|French]] for "I remember") ** [[31 Canadian Brigade Group]]: ''{{lang|la|Pro aris et focis}}'' ([[Latin]] for "for hearth and home") *** [[The Royal Canadian Regiment]]: ''{{lang|la|Pro patria}}'' ([[Latin]] for "for country") ** [[32 Canadian Brigade Group]]: Steadfast ** [[33 Canadian Brigade Group]]: ''{{lang|la|Fortes soli, fortiores una}}'' ([[Latin]] for "strong alone, stronger together") ** [[34 Canadian Brigade Group]]: ''{{lang|fr|Combattre, vaincre ou mourir}}'' ([[French language|French]] for "fight, overcome or die") *** [[Royal 22nd Regiment]]: ''{{lang|fr|Je me souviens}}'' ([[French language|French]] for "I remember") ** [[38 Canadian Brigade Group]]: ''{{lang|la|Progredere ne regredere}}'' ([[Latin]] for "ever forward, never back") ** [[39 Canadian Brigade Group]]: ''{{lang|la|Splendor sine occasu}}'' ([[Latin]] for "splendour without diminishment") ** [[41 Canadian Brigade Group]]: Fortune favours the bold * [[Royal Canadian Air Force]]: ''{{lang|la|Sic itur ad astra}}'' ([[Latin]] for "such is the pathway to the stars") * [[Royal Canadian Navy]]: Ready aye ready * [[Canadian Joint Operations Command]]: ''{{lang|la|Unanimi cum ratione}}'' ([[Latin]] for "united in purpose") * [[Canadian Special Operations Forces Command]]: ''{{lang|la|Viam inveniemus}}'' ([[Latin]] for "we will find a way") ** [[427 Special Operations Aviation Squadron]]: ''{{lang|la|Ferte manus certas}}'' ([[Latin]] for "strike with a sure hand") ** [[Canadian Joint Incident Response Unit]]: ''{{lang|la|Nunquam non parati}}'' ([[Latin]] for "never unprepared") ** [[Canadian Special Operations Regiment]]: ''{{lang|la|Audeamus}}'' ([[Latin]] for "we dare") ** [[Joint Task Force 2]]: ''{{lang|la|Facta non verba}}'' ([[Latin]] for "deeds, not words")
==Chile== * [[Chilean Army]]: ''{{lang|es|Siempre vencedor, jamás vencido}}'' ([[Spanish language|Spanish]] for "Always Victorious, Never Defeated")
==China, Republic of== '''[[Republic of China Military|Republic of China Armed Force]]''' *防衛固守，有效嚇阻(fang-wei-gu-shou, you-xiao-he-zu): persistent defense, effective intimidation. *決戰境外(jue-zhan-jing-wai): decisive battle outside of national boundary. *[[Republic of China Army]] **Aviation and Special Operation Command ***高山低頭，海水讓路(gao-shan-di-tou, hai-shui-rang-lu): the mountain bows, the ocean gives way. ***生為空特人，死為空特魂(sheng-wei-kong-te-ren, si-wei-kong-te-hun): live as kon-teh persons, die as kon-teh spirits.(空特kon-teh is abbreviation of Aviation and Special Warfare Command) *[[Republic of China Navy]] **忠、義(zhong, yi): loyalty and justice. **見敵必戰(jian-di-bi-zhan): we must battle when enemy is in sight. **[[Republic of China Marine Corps]] ***一日陸戰隊，終生陸戰隊(yi-ri-lu-zhan-dui, zhong-sheng-lu-zhan-dui): Once a marine, always a marine. ***不怕苦，不怕難，不怕死(bu-pa-ku, bu-pa-nan, bu-pa-si): fear no pain, fear no challenge, fear no death. ***永遠忠誠(yong-yuan-zhong-cheng): always faithful (taken from the [[United States Marine Corps|USMC]] motto ''semper fidelis'') *[[Republic of China Air Force]] **無空防即無國防(wu-kong-fang-ji-wu-guo-fang): without air defense there is no national defense. *Republic of China Military Police **忠貞憲兵(zhong-zheng-xian-bing): loyal military police. *Military Academy **親愛精誠: Fraternity, Devotion, Sincerity **貪生怕死勿入此門，升官發財請走他路(tan-sheng-pa-si-mo-ru-ci-men, sheng-guan-fa-cai-qing-zou-ta-lu): (those who) covet life and fear death do not enter this door, (those who wish for) promotion and wealth please take other paths.
==Estonia== * ''{{lang|et|[[Maavägi]]}}'' (Estonian Army) ** ''{{lang|et|[[Scouts Single Infantry Battalion|Scoutspataljon]]}}'' (Scouts Battalion): ''{{lang|la|E pluribus unum}}'' ([[Latin]] for "out of many, one")
==Finland== * ''{{lang|fi|[[Finnish Army|Maavoimat]]}}'' (Finnish Army) ** ''{{lang|fi|[[Armoured Brigade (Finnish Army)|Panssariprikaati]]}}'' (Armoured Brigade): ''{{lang|fi|Iske ja murra}}'' ([[Finnish language|Finnish]] for "strike and break through") ** ''{{lang|fi|[[Pori Brigade|Porin Prikaati]]}}'' (Pori Brigade): ''{{lang|fi|Kunnia, velvollisuus, tahto}}'' ([[Finnish language|Finnish]] for "honour, duty, will") ** ''{{lang|fi|[[Utti Jaeger Regiment|Utin Jääkärirykmentti]]}}'' (Utti Ranger Regiment): ''{{lang|la|Excelsior}}'' ([[Latin]] for "higher") * ''{{lang|fi|[[Finnish Air Force|Ilmavoimat]]}}'' (Finnish Air Force): ''{{lang|la|Qualitas potentia nostra}}'' ([[Latin]] for "quality is our strength") * ''{{lang|fi|[[Finnish Rapid Deployment Force|Suomen Kansainvälinen Valmiusjoukko]]}}'' (Finnish Rapid Deployment Force): ''{{lang|fi|Näytä hyvältä, tee hyvää!}}'' ([[Finnish language|Finnish]] for "look good, do good!")
==France== * ''{{lang|fr|[[French Army|Armée de Terre]]}}'' (French Army): ''{{lang|fr|Honneur et patrie}}'' ([[French language|French]] for "honour and fatherland") ** ''{{lang|fr|[[1st Parachute Hussar Regiment|1{{sup|er}} Régiment de hussards parachutistes]]}}'' (1st Parachute Hussar Regiment): ''{{lang|la|Omnia si perdas, famam servare memento}}'' ([[Latin]] for "if you have lost everything, remember there is still honour") ** ''{{lang|fr|[[1st Marine Infantry Parachute Regiment|1{{sup|er}} Régiment de parachutistes d'infanterie de marine]]}}'' (1st Marine Infantry Parachute Regiment): ''{{lang|fr|Qui ose gagne}}'' ([[French language|French]] for "who dares wins") ** ''{{lang|fr|[[2nd Marine Infantry Parachute Regiment|2{{sup|e}} Régiment de parachutistes d'infanterie de Régiment de parachutistes d'infanterie de marine]]}}'' (3rd Marine Infantry Parachute Regiment): ''{{lang|fr|Être et durer}}'' ([[French language|French]] for "to be and to last") ** ''{{lang|fr|[[2nd Marine Infantry Regiment|2{{sup|e}} Régiment d'infanterie de marine]]}}'' (2nd Marine Infantry Regiment): ''{{lang|la|Fidelitate et honore, terra et mare}}'' ([[Latin]] for "loyalty and honour on land and sea") ** ''{{lang|fr|[[3rd Marine Infantry Regiment|3{{sup|e}} Régiment d'infanterie de marine]]}}'' (3rd Marine Infantry Regiment): ''{{lang|fr|Debout les morts}}'' ([[French language|French]] for "The dead, get up") ** ''{{lang|fr|[[12th Cuirassier Regiment (France)|12{{sup|e}} Régiment de cuirassiers]]}}'' (12th Cuirassier Regiment): ''{{lang|la|In periculo ludunt}}'' ([[Latin]] for "amidst danger, they play") ** ''{{lang|fr|[[2nd Dragoon Regiment (France)|2{{sup|e}} Régiment de dragons]]}}'' (2nd Dragoon Regiment): ''{{lang|la|Da materiam splendescam}}'' ([[Latin]] for "give me a chance to shine") ** ''{{lang|fr|[[13th Parachute Dragoon Regiment|13{{sup|e}} Régiment de dragons parachutistes]]}}'' (13th Parachute Dragoon Regiment): ''{{lang|fr|Au-delà du possible}}'' ([[French language|French]] for "Beyond what is possible") ** ''{{lang|fr|[[11th Marine Artillery Regiment|11{{sup|e}} Régiment d'artillerie de marine]]}}'' (11th Marine Artillery Regiment): ''{{lang|la|Alter post fulmina terror}}'' ([[Latin]] for "the other terror after lightning") ** ''{{lang|fr|[[35th Parachute Artillery Regiment|35{{sup|e}} Régiment d'artillerie parachutiste]]}}'' (35th Parachute Artillery Regiment): ''{{lang|fr|Droit devant}}'' ([[French language|French]] for "Straight ahead") ** ''{{lang|fr|[[Chasseurs alpins]]}}'' (Alpine Rangers): ''{{lang|fr|Jamais être [[Franco-German Brigade]]: ''{{lang|de|Dem Besten verpflichtet}}'' and ''{{lang|fr|le devoir d'excellence}}'' ([[German language|German]] and [[French language|French]] for "the Duty to excel") ** ''{{lang|fr|[[French Foreign Legion|Légion étrangère]]}}'' (French Foreign Legion): ''{{lang|la|Legio patria nostra}}'' ([[Latin]] for "the legion is our fatherland") *** ''{{lang|fr|[[1st Foreign Cavalry Regiment|1{{sup|er}} Régiment étranger de cavalerie]]}}'' (1st Foreign Cavalry Regiment): ''{{lang|la|Nec pluribus impar}}'' ([[Latin]] for "not unequal to many") *** ''{{lang|fr|[[1st Foreign Engineer Regiment|1{{sup|er}} Régiment étranger de génie]]}}'' (1st Foreign Engineer Regiment): ''{{lang|la|Ad unum}}'' ([[Latin]] for "to the end") *** ''{{lang|fr|[[2nd Foreign Engineer Regiment|2{{sup|e}} Régiment étranger de génie]]}}'' (2nd Foreign Engineer Regiment): ''{{lang|fr|Rien n'empêche}}'' ([[French language|French]] for "nothing prevents") *** ''{{lang|fr|[[2nd Foreign Infantry Regiment|2{{sup|e}} Régiment étranger d'infanterie]]}}'' (2nd Foreign Infantry Regiment): ''{{lang|fr|Être prêt}}'' ([[French language|French]] for "be ready") *** ''{{lang|fr|[[2nd Foreign Parachute Regiment|2{{sup|e}} Régiment étranger de parachutistes]]}}'' (2nd Foreign Parachute Regiment): ''{{lang|la|More majorum}}'' ([[Latin]] for "after the custom of our ancestors") * ''{{lang|fr|[[French Navy|Marine nationale]]}}'' (French Navy): ''{{lang|fr|Honneur, patrie, valeur, discipline}}'' ([[French language|French]] for "honour, fatherland, valour, discipline") * ''{{lang|fr|[[French Air Force|Armée de l'air]]}}'' (French Air Force): ''{{lang|fr|Faire face}}'' ([[French language|French]] for "rise up") * ''{{lang|fr|[[Grande Armée]]}}'' (Grand Army): ''{{lang|fr|Valeur et discipline}}'' ([[French language|French]] for "valour and discipline")
== Germany == * ''{{lang|de|[[Bundeswehr]]}}'' (German Armed Forces): ''{{lang|de|Wir. Dienen. Deutschland.}}'' ([[German language|German]] for "We. Serve. Germany.") ** ''{{lang|de|[[German Army|Heer]]}}'' (German Army): ''{{lang|de|Schützen, helfen, vermitteln, kämpfen}}'' ([[German language|German]] for "protect, help, moderate, fight") *** ''{{lang|de|[[1st Panzer Division (Bundeswehr)|1. == Greece == * {{lang|el|[[Hellenic Army|Ελληνικός Στρατός]]}} (Hellenic Army): {{lang|el|Ἐλεύθερον τὸ Εὔψυχον}} ([[Greek language|Greek]] for "freedom stems from valour"){{efn|The phrase comes from [[Thucydides]]' ''[[History of the Peloponnesian War]]''.}} ** {{lang|el|[[First Army (Greece)|1η Στρατιά]]}} (First Army): {{lang|el|Εστ' αν (ο ήλιος) την αυτήν οδόν ίη}} ([[Greek language|Greek]] for "as long as (the sun) follows its course"){{efn|Before the [[Battle of Plataea]], [[Mardonius (general)|Mardonius]] offered the Athenians peace terms, with the hope of dividing the Greek forces. The Athenians responded with "As long as the sun follows his course, as he does now, we shall not come to a compromise with [[Xerxes I|Xerxes]]".}} *** {{lang|el|[[I Army Corps (Greece)|Α' Σώμα Στρατού]]}} (I Army Corps): {{lang|el|[[Molon labe|Μολών λαβέ]]}} ([[Greek language|Greek]] for "come and get them"){{efn|The phrase was uttered by the [[Sparta]]n King [[Leonidas I]], just prior to the [[Battle of Thermopylae]], as a response to the [[Achaemenid Empire|Persian]] King [[Xerxes I]]'s demand for the surrender of the Spartans' arms.}} *** {{lang|el|[[II Army Corps (Greece)|Β' Σώμα Στρατού]]}} (II Army Corps): {{lang|grc|[[List of Greek phrases#.CE.97.CE.B7|Ἢ τὰν ἢ ἐπὶ τᾶς]]}} ([[Ancient Greek]] for "either with it or on it"){{efn|Spartan mothers would utter the phrase to their sons before they went to war, reminding them to return victorious with the shield, or be brought back dead upon it. Returning home without a shield meant the soldier deserted, since a hoplite could not escape the field of battle unless he tossed away the heavy and cumbersome shield.}} **** {{lang|el|[[1st Infantry Division (Greece)|I Μεραρχία Πεζικού]]}} (1st Infantry Division): {{lang|el|Αέρα}} ([[Greek language|Greek]] for "(like the) wind"){{efn|The phrase is the traditional battle cry of Greek infantrymen when attacking the enemy.}} ***** {{lang|el|[[1st Raider/Paratrooper Brigade (Greece)|1η Ταξιαρχία Kαταδρομών-Αλεξιπτωτιστών]]}} (1st Raider/Paratrooper Brigade): {{lang|el|Ο Tολμών Nικά}} ([[Greek language|Greek]] for "who dares wins"){{efn|The phrase is a tribute to the [[Sacred Band (World War II)|Sacred Band]] that fought during [[World War II]] alongside the [[Special Air Service]], which also shares the motto.}} *** {{lang|el|[[IV Army Corps (Greece)|Δ' Σώμα Στρατού]]}} (IV Army Corps): {{lang|el|Τώ ξιφεί τόν δεσμό λελύσθαι}} ([[Greek language|Greek]] for "solve the knot with the sword"){{efn|The phrase is a reference to the [[Gordian Knot]], a legendary knot tied to a pole near the temple of Zeus in Gordium. It was prophesied that whoever loosed the knot would become ruler of all Asia. [[Alexander the Great]] solved the puzzle by slicing through the knot.}} *** {{lang|el|[[Hellenic Force in Cyprus|Ελληνική Δύναμη Κύπρου]]}} (Hellenic Force in Cyprus): {{lang|el|Το όμαιμόν τε και ομόγλωσσον και ομόθρησκον και ομότροπον}} ([[Greek language|Greek]] for "the same blood and common language and common religion and common traditions") * {{lang|el|[[Hellenic Navy|Πολεμικό Ναυτικό]]}} (Hellenic Navy): {{lang|el|Μέγα το της θαλάσσης κράτος}} ([[Greek language|Greek]] for "great is the country that controls the sea"){{efn|The phrase comes from [[Thucydides]]' account of [[Pericles]]' oration on the eve of the [[Peloponnesian War]].}} * {{lang|el|[[Hellenic Air Force|Πολεμική Αεροπορία]]}} (Hellenic Air Force): {{lang|grc|Αἰὲν Ὑψικρατεῖν}} ([[Ancient Greek]] for "always dominate the heights")

{{original research|date=June 2012}} '''''Looking Outward: A History of the U.S. Prison System from Colonial Times to the Formation of the Bureau of Prisons''''' by the "Birdman of Alcatraz", [[Robert Stroud]], is a history of the United States [[Prison]] System from colonial times until the formation of the [[United States Bureau of Prisons]] in the 1930s.
Robert Stroud gained the permission of the Warden at [[Alcatraz Island|Alcatraz Penitentiary]], [[San Francisco]], [[California]] to write a history of the U.S. prison system. Stroud had been incarcerated at [[McNeil Island]], [[United States Penitentiary, Leavenworth|Leavenworth Penitentiary]], [[Alcatraz Island]] and lastly at the [[Medical Center for Federal Prisoners, Springfield|United States Medical Center for Federal Prisoners]]. Stroud interviewed inmates, guards and administrative personnel at all those prisons. He also researched the written records on all of the other U.S. federal penitentiaries.
When Stroud finished his manuscript, he asked permission from the Warden at the Medical Center for Federal Prisoners at [[Springfield, Missouri]], to send his manuscript to prospective publishers. The Springfield Warden sent his request to the Director of the [[Federal Bureau of Prisons]] at [[Washington, D.C.]] who refused Stroud's request to offer his manuscript for publication. The Director said that Stroud's manuscript aroused prurient interest in homosexual activity and slandered the reputation of some guards, whom Stroud described as sadistic, and libeled some wardens, whom Stroud described as incompetent or corrupt.
[[Charles Dudley Martin]] of [[Missouri]] represented Stroud in his lawsuit against the Warden of United States Medical Center for Federal Prisoners and the Director of the Bureau of Prisons. When Stroud died, (the day before President John F. Kennedy was assassinated), the judge ordered Stroud's manuscripts to be impounded in custody of the Clerk for the [[United States District Court for the Western District of Missouri]] at Kansas City. The [[Probate Court]] of the State of Missouri for [[Jackson County, Missouri|Jackson County]] at Kansas City appointed Mr. Martin as administrator of Stroud's hand written will.
When Mr. Martin presented his letters of administration to the United States District Court for the Western District of Missouri and moved for custody of Stroud's manuscripts, the Bureau of Prisons dropped their objections after a hail of public criticism. The U.S. District Court then ordered the manuscripts delivered to the offices of Mr. Martin as administrator of Robert Stroud's estate.
An experienced [[literary agent]] in [[New York City]] was then retained, who offered a copy of ''Looking Outward'' to several New York publishers. Although they praised the manuscript, they declined to publish it. The prisoners, guards and wardens described by Stroud were at that time still alive. Only Stroud, who was dead, and his prisoner witnesses, who were scattered, could verify the claims of abuse and corruption. All of the publishers approached declined to publish Stroud's manuscript, fearing civil suits for publication of defamatory writings, along with potential civil damage suits for libel.
As of the 26th of December 2007, Mr. Martin still had Stroud's manuscript of ''Looking Outward'' in his possession, together with Stroud's hand written autobiography ''Bobbie''.<ref name="Goodwin">{{cite news |url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/life/books/2014/01/30/birdman-of-alcatraz-robert-stroud/5054535/ |title='Birdman of Alcatraz' publishes book long after death |last=Goodwin|first=Juliana |date=2014-01-30 |work=[[USA Today]] |accessdate=2018-05-05}}</ref> Mr. Martin also has the hand written notes of [[Thomas E. Gaddis]], who wrote the biography and screen play of ''Birdman of Alcatraz''.
==Fate of Stroud's manuscripts== With the court orders removing them from custody of the U. S. District Court and transferring them to Mr. Martin as the administrator of Stroud's estate, together with Thomas Gaddis's notes of ''Birdman of Alcatraz'', Mr. Martin has consigned the manuscript and partnered with Springfield, MO author; JE Cornwell. Together they will try to attract a major publishing company to publish the manuscript into four books. Mr. Martin also intends to put the original hand written manuscript up for sale at an auction-house, which has locations in both New York, New York and San Francisco, California.
In early 2014, the imminent publication of Stroud's manuscript was reported by several news outlets.<ref name="Goodwin"/><ref>{{cite web|title=Lawyer releases book by Birdman of Alcatraz|url=http://www.bizjournals.com/kansascity/blog/morning_call/2014/02/lawyer-releases-book-by-birdman-of.html|publisher=Kansas City Business Journal|accessdate=2014-02-12}}</ref>
On February 5, 2014, ''Looking Outward: A Voice From The Grave'' was made available for purchase as an Amazon Kindle [[eBook]]. By January 2015 it was also available in paperback form. As noted in the book's Prologue, "[the] work was originally divided into six parts. However, due to the death of the Writer, only four parts were completed" and the 2014 edition contains only the first of four parts of the entire manuscript,<ref>{{cite book |last1=Stroud |first1=Robert |last2=Eddings |first2=Pam |date=2013 |title=Looking Outward: A Voice From The Grave |url=https://www.amazon.com/Looking-Outward-Voice-Robert-Stroud-ebook/dp/B00IA8YNYI/ref=sr_1_1?s=digital-text&ie=UTF8&qid=1525491702&sr=1-1#reader_B00IA8YNYI |location= |publisher=Looking Outward, LLC |page=7 |isbn=978-0-9828531-7-7}}</ref> but as of Fall 2015 no additional date was known for the availability of the other three parts.
==Sources== * Most information contained in this article is the result of email correspondence with Charles Dudley Martin - Legal Representative and Estate Administrator of Robert Stroud
