The '''NSE co-location scam''' relates to the market manipulation at the [[National Stock Exchange of India]], India's leading stock exchange. Allegedly select players obtained market price information ahead of the rest of the market, enabling them to [[Front running|front run]] the rest of the market,{{cite news|url=https://www.bloombergquint.com/law-and-policy/2018/08/17/top-nse-officials-facilitated-co-location-fraud-says-sebi-show-cause-notice#gs.p2XdU6U|title=Top NSE Officials ‘Facilitated’ Co-Location Fraud, Says SEBI Show-Cause Notice|date=2018-08-18}}{{cite news|url=https://www.moneylife.in/article/nse-whistleblowers-4th-letter-alleges-rigging-of-currency-market-manipulation-at-nse/54990.html|title=NSE whistleblower’s 4th letter alleges rigging of currency market; manipulation at NSE|date=2018-08-10}} possibly breaching the NSE’s purpose of [[Demutualization|demutualisation]] exchange governance and its robust transparency-based mechanism.{{Cite news|url=https://www.business-standard.com/article/opinion/should-nse-be-allowed-to-file-consent-terms-118082000017_1.html|title=Should NSE be allowed to file 'Consent Terms'?|date=2018-08-20|newspaper=[[Business Standard]] India|last1=Basu|first1=Debashis}} The alleged connivance of insiders by rigging NSE’s [[Algorithmic trading|algo-trading]] and use of co-location servers ensured substantial profits to a set of brokers.{{cite news|url=https://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/business/india-business/nse-moves-sebi-to-settle-co-location-scam/articleshow/59690660.cms|date=2017-07-21|title=NSE moves Sebi to settle co-location scam}}{{cite news|url=https://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/business/india-business/co-location-case-i-t-dept-conducts-searches-on-nse-brokers/articleshow/61672114.cms|date=2017-06-21|title=Co-location case: I-T dept conducts searches on NSE brokers|publisher=[[Times of India]].com}}{{cite news|url=https://m.dailyhunt.in/news/india/english/financial+chronicle-epaper-finance/letters+from+a+whistle+blower+to+sebi+on+nse+rot-newsid-73928653|date=2015-09-27|title=Letters from a whistle-blower to SEBI on NSE rot}} This multi-dollar, widespread market fraud came to light when markets' regulator, the [[Securities and Exchange Board of India]] (SEBI), received the first anonymous complaint through a [[Whistleblower|whistle-blower]]'s letter in January 2015.{{cite news|url=https://www.moneylife.in/article/algo-scam-sebirsquos-show-cause-notice-to-nse-14-an-escape-route/50679.html|date=2017-06-06|title=Algo Scam: SEBI’s Show-cause Notice to NSE 14 an Escape Route?|publisher=moneylife.in}}{{cite news|url=https://www.thenewsminute.com/article/moneylife%E2%80%99s-nse-expose-why-battle-against-stock-exchange-not-just-their-own-33874|date=2015-11-01|title=Moneylife's NSE Expose: Why the battle against the stock exchange is not just their own|publisher=thenewsminute.com}} The whistle-blower alleged that trading members were able to capitalise on advance knowledge by colluding with some exchange officials. The overall default amount through NSE’s [[high-frequency trading]] (HFT) is estimated to be 50,000 crores over five years.{{cite news|url=https://www.sundayguardianlive.com/investigation/11764-why-income-tax-officers-are-zeroing-ajay-shah|date=2017-11-26|title=Why Income Tax officers are zeroing in on Ajay Shah|publisher=sundayguardanlive}}{{cite news|url= https://www.pgurus.com/is-nse-becoming-its-own-judge-jury-and-acquitter/ |date=2017-11-19|title=Is NSE becoming its own Judge, Jury and Acquitter?|publisher=pgurus.com}} The NSE co-location case is under investigation by the [[Central Bureau of Investigation]] (CBI), the [[Securities and Exchange Board of India]] (SEBI) and the Income-tax Department (I-T department) who are probing the involvement of NSE and SEBI officials, as well as NSE's former and current executives and brokerages.{{cite news|url=https://www.financialexpress.com/market/sebi-finds-lapses-at-nse-in-co-location-case-issues-show-cause-notices-to-related-parties/1232454/|date=2018-07-05|title=Sebi finds lapses at NSE in co-location case, issues show-cause notices to related parties|publisher=[[The Financial Express (India)|The Financial Express]]}}{{cite news|url=https://www.business-standard.com/article/markets/sebi-finds-lapses-at-nse-in-co-location-case-issues-show-cause-notices-118070500409_1.html |date=2018-07-05|title=Sebi finds lapses at NSE in co-location case, issues show-cause notices|publisher=Business Standard}}{{cite news|url=https://www.business-standard.com/article/markets/i-t-dept-suspects-money-laundering-by-opg-securities-117112001061_1.html|date=2017-11-21|title=I-T dept brings in ED to check money trail in NSE co-location case|publisher=Business Standard}} ==Background== In January 2010, the NSE began offering a [[Colocation centre|co-location]] facility to members. Members could place their servers in the Exchange's premises in return for a fee. This allowed them faster access to the buy and sell orders being disseminated by the exchange’s trading engine.{{cite news|url=https://www.moneycontrol.com/news/trends/features-2/how-ravi-narain-built-the-nse-and-then-lost-his-grip-2296629.html|date=2017-06-04|title=How Ravi Narain built the NSE, and then lost his grip|publisher=Money Control}} The term 'co-location' means 'a setup wherein the broker’s computer is located in the same area as the stock exchange’s server. This gives a 10:1 (typically) speed advantage for the broker'.{{cite news|url=https://www.pgurus.com/anatomy-of-a-crime-p2-the-amount-of-the-hft-loot/|date=2017-09-25|title=Anatomy of a crime P2 – The amount of the HFT loot|publisher=pgurus}}{{cite news|url=https://www.pgurus.com/anatomy-crime-p1-benefited-hft-high-frequency-trading/|date=2017-09-24|title=Anatomy of a crime P1 – How some benefited from HFT (High Frequency Trading)|publisher=PGurus}} In addition, [[High-frequency trading]] (HFT) or [[algorithmic trading]] refers to the use of electronic systems, which can potentially execute thousands of orders on the stock exchange in less than a second. Also, retail investors monitoring prices are subject to a delay as compared to the tick-by-tick data broadcast a user receives in a co-location facility. {{cite news|url=https://www.livemint.com/Money/fK2Uiuoal9lzOuTFP2E7DK/Sebi-looking-at-ways-to-limit-algo-trading-colocation-bene.html|date=2016-04-13|title=Sebi looking at ways to limit algo trading, co-location benefits|publisher=Live Mint}} Unusually, the SEBI did not put out a discussion paper to collect market feedback before giving permission to proceed with the facility. There are no public records on HFT executed on the NSE.{{cite news|url=https://www.sundayguardianlive.com/news/ajay-shah-cambridge-analytica-style-mastermind-financial-markets|date=2018-06-09|title=Ajay Shah: Cambridge Analytica-style mastermind of financial markets|publisher=Sunday Guardian Live}} It is mentioned in passing in the NSE’s 2009-10 annual report statement: "In keeping with global trends, the exchange has provided members a co-location facility for low latency high frequency trading. The Co-location data center is an international standard, state of the art, highly robust, resilient and secure infrastructure."{{cite web|url=https://www.nseindia.com/global/content/about_us/NSEIL_Annual_Report_2011.pdf|title=NSEIL Annual Report|date=2011-04-26|website=nseindia.com}} The whistle-blower’s letter that was addressed to SEBI and copied to the leading financial magazine, ''Moneylife''. clearly stated that:
when the co-location was started by NSE it took some time for the more enterprising to figure out what was happening in the system. By the end of the year, smart people had all figured out the way to game the system lay in being the first one to connect to the server and preferably the server, which was fastest.{{cite news|url=https://www.moneylife.in/article/blowing-the-whistle-on-manipulation-in-nse/42337.html|date=2015-06-19|title=Blowing the Whistle on Manipulation in NSE|publisher=Moneylife}}
The co-location case was initiated when certain members associated with HFT allegedly teamed up and worked in coalition for about four years, i.e. 2010- 2014 overriding rules and regulations set in place by SEBI, the market regulator.{{cite news|url=https://economictimes.indiatimes.com/markets/stocks/news/probe-into-allegations-against-nse-for-favouring-clients-turning-out-to-be-a-farcical-drama/articleshow/59328132.cms |date=2017-06-27|title=Probe into allegations against NSE for 'favouring clients' turning out to be a farcical drama|publisher=etmarkets.com}}{{cite news|url=https://www.thehindubusinessline.com/markets/co-location-case-cbi-names-nse-sebi-officials-opg-securities/article24039742.ece|date=2018-05-30|title=Co-location case: CBI names NSE, SEBI officials, OPG Securities |publisher=Business Line}} According to an unnamed individual familiar with SEBI's investigation: "Access to co-location facilities and HFT trading gave the select brokers differential advantage such as display of market data, viewing order book prior to order execution."{{cite news|url=https://www.livemint.com/Money/fK2Uiuoal9lzOuTFP2E7DK/Sebi-looking-at-ways-to-limit-algo-trading-colocation-bene.html|date=2016-04-13|title=Sebi looking at ways to limit algo trading, co-location benefits |publisher=LiveMint}} ==Resignations at NSE== ''[[The Economic Times]]'' first reported that on 22 May 2017, SEBI issued [[show cause]] notices to the exchange and fourteen individuals, including former managing directors Chitra Ramakrishna and Ravi Narain.{{cite news|url=https://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/business/india-business/sebi-sends-show-cause-notices-to-nse-ex-mds/articleshow/64862154.cms|date=2018-07-05|title=Sebi sends show-cause notices to NSE, ex-MDs |publisher=Times Of India}} Notices have been sent to Ravi Narain, vice-chairman of NSE, who was serving as chief executive officer (CEO) and managing director (MD) at the exchange during the period when the alleged violations took place. Other officials include Ravi Varanasi, who was the chief of NSE’s business development vertical and was heading the surveillance department of the exchange during this period, and Suprabhat Lala, chief of regulation and head of the trading division during 2010-13. Among other officials who received show cause notices were former technology heads — Ravi Apte, and Umesh Jain, and former chief operating officer Subramanian Anand. NSE vice-chairman Ravi Narain had put in his papers on 2 June 2017, amid regulators intensifying their probe into the alleged lapses in high frequency trading.{{cite news|url=https://www.thehindu.com/business/markets/ravi-narain-quits-as-nse-vice-chairman/article18708349.ece|date=2017-06-12|title=Ravi Narain quits as NSE vice-chairman|publisher=The Hindu}}{{cite news|url=https://economictimes.indiatimes.com/markets/stocks/news/sebi-sends-fresh-notices-to-nse-key-officials/articleshow/64864605.cms|title=Sebi sends fresh notices to NSE, key officials|date=2018-07-05|publisher=Economic Times}} Chitra Ramakrishna, MD and CEO resigned from the exchange in December 2016. The media reported that Chitra’s resignation the result of two governance-related issues at NSE. One was the loss of confidence in the NSE top management due to the colocation controversy. The second was the controversy surrounding a high-ranking official at NSE, Anand Subramanian, who was re-designated on 1 April 2015 as Group Operating Officer and Advisor to the MD. This appointment happened after communication from the NSE, MD and the CEO's office bypassing the Human Resources department. Complaints regarding this appointment, and Subramanian’s high salary, reached the board prompting it to examine the appointment process. This led to Subramanian leaving the exchange in October 2016.{{cite web|url=https://www.moneylife.in/article/subramanian-anand-resigned-from-nse/48590.html|title=Subramanian Anand resigned from NSE|website=moneylife.in|date=24 October 2016}}Both Mr. Narain and Ms. Ramakrishna were part of the NSE’s founding team, having joined the bourse in 1994.{{cite news|url=https://www.telegraphindia.com/1170603/jsp/business/story_154859.jsp|title=NSE probe prompts key man to quit|website= [[The Telegraph (Calcutta)|The Telegraph]]|date=2017-06-03}} After receiving show cause notices from SEBI, 12 out of 14 high profile current and former top executives of NSE including Ravi Narain and Chitra Ramakrishna filed an application with SEBI to settle the co-location issue under [[Consent (criminal law)|consent]] mechanism in July 2017.{{cite news|url=https://economictimes.indiatimes.com/markets/stocks/news/former-and-current-nse-executives-opt-for-consent-mode-to-settle-co-location-case/articleshow/60833992.cms|title=Former and current NSE executives opt for consent mode to settle co-location case|website= etmarkets.com|date=Sep 26, 2017}} {{cite news|url=https://indianexpress.com/article/business/market/consent-mechanism-nse-sebi-to-work-for-early-settlement-4760234/|title=Consent mechanism: NSE, Sebi to work for early settlement|website= indianexpress.com|date=July 21, 2017}}The consent process is an alternative dispute resolution mechanism, allows an alleged wrongdoer to settle a pending issue by accepting a penal action without admitting or denying the guilt.{{cite news|url= https://www.thehindubusinessline.com/markets/12-nse-officials-file-for-consent-settlement-on-co-location-issue/article22093049.ece1|title=12 NSE officials file for consent settlement on co-location issue|website=Business Line|date=2017-08-09}} During this period, in July 2017, Vikram Limaye took charge as MD and CEO of the NSE. He gave assurances that he would approach SEBI for a settlement of the co-location issue and would find the underlying cause of this issue. {{cite news|url= https://www.thehindubusinessline.com/markets/limaye-takes-over-as-nse-chief-insists-he-will-get-to-the-bottom-of-colocation-issue/article9773647.ece|title= Limaye takes over as NSE chief, insists he will get to the bottom of co-location issue|website=The Hindu|date= July 17, 2017}} However, a consent application filed by the exchange was later returned in March 2018 after the CBI investigation gathered momentum. {{cite web|url= https://www.moneylife.in/article/nse-algo-scam-cbi-steps-in-where-sebi-was-pussyfooting/54193.html|title= NSE Algo Scam: CBI Steps in Where SEBI Was Pussyfooting|website= moneylife.in|date= 31 May 2018}}{{cite news|url= https://www.business-standard.com/article/markets/sebi-finds-lapses-at-nse-in-co-location-case-issues-show-cause-notices-118070500409_1.html|title= Sebi finds lapses at NSE in co-location case, issues show-cause notices|date=2018-07-05|website= [[Business Standard]]}} ==P. Chidambaram’s conduit== During the [[United Progressive Alliance]] (UPA) rule from 2004 to 2014, [[P. Chidambaram]] was the finance minister for almost seven years and K.P. Krishnan had been the longest-serving joint secretary and additional secretary for the capital market.{{cite web | url=https://www.firstpost.com/business/nse-crisis-will-sebi-initiate-a-deeper-probe-in-to-the-alleged-unfair-trade-practices-3530199.html | title=NSE crisis: Will Sebi initiate a deeper probe into the alleged unfair trade practices?}} Markets are shocked that P. Chidambaram chose favourable bureaucrats like C B Bhave and key persons like Chitra Ramakrishna, Ravi Narain, Ashok Chawla and Ramesh Abhishek to head market regulators SEBI, NSE and FMC respectively.{{cite web | url=https://www.sundayguardianlive.com/news/officials-look-pm-modi-rescue-economy-toxic-cabal | title=Officials look to PM Modi to rescue economy from toxic cabal| date=2018-07-14}} Ravi Narain and Chitra Ramakrishna’s proximity to K.P. Krishnan and P. Chidambaram is said to be the reason for their appointments. It was during this period, the NSE continued operations such as HFT for many years, "enabling brokers to help their clients especially the Foreign International Investors (FII) to make piles of illegal cash". SEBI ignored complaints from the Bombay Stock Exchange (BSE) and the FT Group’s MCX-SX. It failed to ask the NSE to discontinue the HFT system for years.{{cite web | url=https://www.pgurus.com/anatomy-of-a-crime-p5-conclusion/ | title=Anatomy of a crime P5 - Conclusion| date=2017-10-08}} Outside the government, P. Chidambaram also has confidants of eminence like Ajay Narottam Shah, Vijay Kelkar, Suprabhat Lala and the other heads of key domestic financial institutions. Prior to 2010, the then-chairman of SEBI, C.B. Bhave sent some officials from SEBI to the United States for the training on co-location facilities. There they met Ajay Shah to discuss the practice. After this, NSE started providing a co-location facility in 2010 without a formal application or regulation under the name of [[Direct Market Access]] (DMA).{{cite web | url=https://www.sundayguardianlive.com/news/ajay-shah-cambridge-analytica-style-mastermind-financial-markets | title=Ajay Shah: Cambridge Analytica-style mastermind of financial markets| date=2018-06-09}} According to the whistle-blower, "the NSE’s top brass, in connivance with some bureaucrats in the then Finance Ministry and powerful ministers in the UPA government manipulated and milked the system".[https://relaysblog.files.wordpress.com/2017/09/rs-50000-cr-hft-mafia-scandal.pdf MUCH–SUPPRESSED BY NSE: SEBI’S TAC REPORT] ==The role of Ajay Shah== The CBI booked Ajay Shah, professor at the [[National Institute of Public Finance and Policy]] (NIPFP) and former consultant in the finance ministry in co-location scandal.{{cite web | url=https://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/india/cbi-books-stock-broker-for-manipulating-nse-system/articleshow/64389164.cms | title=CBI books stock broker for manipulating NSE system - Times of India}} As CBI details it, Ajay Shah lobbied for the NSE because of his clout in the Finance Ministry and had been instrumental in the exploitation of the NSE TBT (Tick-By-Tick) architecture.{{cite web | url=https://www.livemint.com/Money/qBSyIApQehrv59pAYBljDK/CBI-files-case-against-three-for-exploiting-NSE-systems.html | title=CBI files case against three for exploiting NSE systems| date=2018-05-30}} The CBI’s probe revealed that Ajay Shah collected NSE trade data in 2005-06 under the guise of doing research, while he was employed with Centre for Monitoring Indian Economy (CMIE). He developed algo software named 'Chanakya'.{{cite news|url=https://www.thehindu.com/business/cbi-books-stock-broker-for-illegal-nse-access/article24039051.ece|title=CBI books stockbroker for illegal NSE access|newspaper=The Hindu|date=2018-05-30|last1=Pandey|first1=Devesh K.}} This software was then sold to selected brokers like OPG securities on a profit-sharing basis through a firm called Infotech Financials. Sunita Thomas, one of the directors of Infotech, is Ajay Shah's sister-in-law and the wife of the NSE’s then-trading head Suprabhat Lala.[https://www.pgurus.com/ajay-shah-in-the-garb-of-an-academic/ Ajay Shah – In the garb of an academic]2018-07-03 After the CBI named Ajay Shah in the co-location scandal in July 2018, SEBI also served show cause notice on him for breaching the data sharing agreement with the NSE.{{cite web | url=https://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/business/india-business/sebi-sends-show-cause-notices-to-nse-ex-mds/articleshow/64862154.cms | title=Sebi sends show-cause notices to NSE, ex-MDs - Times of India}} The whistle-blower has alleged that Ajay Shah has also benefited by influencing FIIs and Participatory (PN) Note activities on NSE, and he had profit-sharing contracts with OPG Securities, Alpha Grep and Omnesys. Even on the floor of parliament, 10th August 2018, Pon Radhakrishnan, the minister of state for finance said in response to a question by Dr. Kirit Somaiya that: "Securities & Exchange Board of India (SEBI) examination, inter alia, observed that the professor had employed a device/ scheme/ artifice, wherein the confidential and sensitive data provided by NSE was misused in fraudulent manner, which resulted in compromising the integrity of the securities market." Even when Income-Tax authorities raided Ajay Shah’s premises in November 2017, it is alleged that I-T secured some very confidential documents and they also found the budget representations on his computer well before the actual release of budget.{{cite web | url=https://www.pgurus.com/p5-six-questions-for-ajay-shah/ | title=P5 - Six Questions for Ajay Shah| date=2018-07-05}} Ajay Shah is known to be close to P Chidambaram and was extremely close to K P Krishnan. It is believed that the Finance Ministry was giving a minimum of Rs 1 crore every year to National Institute of Public Finance and Policy for Ajay Shah’s group.{{cite web | url=https://www.sundayguardianlive.com/news/ajay-shah-cambridge-analytica-style-mastermind-financial-markets | title=Ajay Shah: Cambridge Analytica-style mastermind of financial markets| date=2018-06-09}} In fact, designing the Nifty-50 for the NSE had made Ajay Shah a popular figure in the Finance Ministry. Ajay Shah and his wife Susan Thomas were paid a substantial royalty every year from the turnover of Nifty trading, which is 80% of the total turnover of the NSE. However, it is unprecedented to give such an annual royalty from research and it is claimed to be a violation of standard industry norm where a one-time payment is given to researchers of any of the market indices.{{cite web | url=https://www.sundayguardianlive.com/investigation/11764-why-income-tax-officers-are-zeroing-ajay-shah?curator=alphaideas&utm_source=alphaideas | title=Why Income Tax officers are zeroing in on Ajay Shah| date=2017-11-26}} ==The Brokers-NSE Nexus== The brokers-NSE nexus came to the forefront with the co-location scandal. The broker entity to receive maximum benefit in the scandal was OPG Securities, which was provided multiple login IPs and allowed access from the secondary servers.{{cite news|url=https://www.bloombergquint.com/markets/2018/05/30/cbi-books-stock-broker-opg-securities-for-manipulating-nse-system#gs.56fqbsY|title=NSE Co-Location Case: CBI Books OPG Securities Owner, Others For Manipulating NSE System|date=2018-05-30}}{{cite news|url=https://www.moneylife.in/article/algo-scam-sebirsquos-show-cause-notice-to-nse-14-an-escape-route/50679.html|title=Algo Scam: SEBI’s Show-cause Notice to NSE 14 an Escape Route?|date=2017-06-06}} Due to favourable access, OPG Securities and other entities benefited instead of other brokers and their clients. Other firms on the list of 22 brokers who repeatedly logged in early on the NSE servers include: Alpha Grep, SMC Global, Barclays Securities, Kredent, Pace, Religare Securities, NYCE, Motilal Oswal, Kotak Securities, DE Shaw, Crimson, Advent, Mansukh Stock Brokers, JM Global, AB Financial, Indus Broking and Quant Broking.{{cite news|url=https://www.moneycontrol.com/news/business/markets/nse-co-location-case-sebi-heat-now-on-brokers-who-logged-in-first-repeatedly-2410971.html|title=NSE co-location case: SEBI heat now on brokers who logged in first repeatedly|date=2017-10-12}}{{cite news|url=https://www.moneycontrol.com/news/business/companies/nse-co-location-audit-3-brokers-misused-secondary-server-and-ignored-exchange-notification-2782961.html|title=NSE co-location audit: 3 brokers misused secondary server and ignored exchange warning|date=2018-08-01}} The CBI investigation revealed that 90% of the time OPG securities, in collusion with unknown officials of the NSE, was first to access the NSE servers.{{cite news|url=https://www.sundayguardianlive.com/news/ajay-shah-cambridge-analytica-style-mastermind-financial-markets|title=Ajay Shah: Cambridge Analytica-style mastermind of financial markets|date=2018-06-09}} SEBI’s TAC report also revealed that OPG securities was given access using the co-location facility during 2010-2014 that enabled it to log in to the NSE server before any other entity and receive data before any other broker in the market.{{cite web|url=http://cbi.gov.in/firs/2018/2018_pdf/2018_ac1_firs/RC2162018A0011.pdf|title= First Information Report|date=2018-05-28}} SEBI has alleged in its show-cause notice that the firm has earned close to ₹ 25 crore in profit.{{cite web|url=https://www.bloombergquint.com/markets/2018/08/21/sebi-co-location-probe-how-much-opg-gained-with-first-access-to-nses-server#gs.DfFpag8|title=SEBI Co-Location Probe: How Much OPG Gained With First Access To NSE's Server|date=2018-08-21}} According to the whistle-blower, OPG Securities alone had trades worth over Rs. 6,000 crore on the NSE using co-location. In addition, the exchange's "order book" was exported to FIIs and FPIs, helping them make illegal gains in the stock market.{{citeweb|url=http://www.mydigitalfc.com/companies-and-markets/letters-whistle-blower-sebi-nse-rot|title=Letters from a whistle-blower to SEBI on NSE rot|date=2018-09-12}}{{citeweb|url=https://www.sundayguardianlive.com/investigation/11764-why-income-tax-officers-are-zeroing-ajay-shah|title=Why Income Tax officers are zeroing in on Ajay Shah|date=2017-11-26}} While OPG Securities used the base technology, Omnesys Technologies provided the trading software. Whistle-blower Ken Fong's letter points to Bangalore-based, front-end technology provider Omnesys, a company that sold trading software to NSE's members and is said to have benefited, legitimately, from its ability to connect ahead of others to the exchange's servers. The whistle-blower states Omnesys was so sure of the early bird strategy that it had profit-sharing arrangements with clients.{{citeweb|url=http://www.mydigitalfc.com/companies-and-markets/letters-whistle-blower-sebi-nse-rot|title=Letters from a whistle-blower to SEBI on NSE rot|date=2018-09-12}} Omnesys gave the technology to NSE members on a profit-sharing basis and the NSE’s wholly owned subsidiary secured 26 per cent stake in Omnesys at a huge discount.{{citeweb|url=https://www.nseindia.com/global/content/about_us/NSEIL_Annual_Report_2015.pdf|title=National Stock Exchange of India Limited Twenty-Thirds Annual Report (2014-2015)|date=2015}} Chitra Ramakrishna, NSE's then-deputy managing director, was sitting on the board of Omnesys technologies according to documents from the registrar of companies.{{citeweb|url=https://economictimes.indiatimes.com/markets/stocks/news/why-is-nse-bogged-in-negatives-maybe-it-needs-to-put-protocol-first/articleshow/57908993.cms|title=Why is NSE bogged in negatives? Maybe it needs to put protocol first|date=2017-05-30}} As the whistle-blower mentioned in his first letter dated, 14th January 2015, Omnesys was the market leader with its DMA product being highly popular on the institutional desk. This is important since the NSE was the second largest shareholder of Omnesys and worked closely with them for several years.{{citeweb|url=https://www.moneylife.in/article/blowing-the-whistle-on-manipulation-in-nse/42337.html|title=Blowing the Whistle on Manipulation in NSE|date=2015-06-19}} ==Action by Agencies against perpetrators== ===SEBI Action=== In November 2015, the whistle-blower’s letter referred to SEBI’s technical advisory committee (TAC) report that concluded in March 2016, that NSE systems were prone to 'manipulation' and thus recommended an investigation. This was when SEBI directed the new NSE board to conduct a forensic audit of its systems and deposit revenue from co-location trading in an escrow account.{{cite web | url=https://www.livemint.com/Money/DBJrjsgvbqWNdrcnmFQQGO/Sebi-examining-NSE-directors-role-in-algotrading-investiga.html | title=Sebi examining NSE directors' role in algo-trading investigation| date=2017-05-28}} This was a blow to NSE’s plans of going public as the co-location server facility stream accounted for nearly 35–40 per cent of the NSE’s core revenues. The NSE added public interest directors to its board. They include: Ashok Chawla, former finance secretary; Naved Masood, former secretary in the Ministry of Corporate Affairs; TV Mohandas Pai, chairman of Manipal Global Education Services; Dinesh Kanabar, former deputy CEO of KPMG in India, and Dharmishta Raval, former SEBI executive director.{{cite web | url=http://epaperbeta.timesofindia.com/Article.aspx?eid=31818&articlexml=In-Second-High-Profile-Exit-Narain-Walks-Away-03062017001057 | title=The Times Group}} The board then appointed Deloitte to conduct a forensic inquiry. The Deloitte report, submitted to SEBI on 23 December 2016, found that the exchange's tick-by-tick (TBT) system was prone to manipulation and restated the findings by the SEBI panel that some stock brokers obtained preferential access to servers.{{Cite news | url=https://www.business-standard.com/article/opinion/should-nse-be-allowed-to-file-consent-terms-118082000017_1.html | title=Should NSE be allowed to file 'Consent Terms'?| newspaper=Business Standard India| date=2018-08-19| last1=Basu| first1=Debashis}} The NSE also admitted this in its draft prospectus.{{cite web | url=http://www.mydigitalfc.com/companies-and-markets/letters-whistle-blower-sebi-nse-rot | title=Letters from a whistle-blower to SEBI on NSE rot | mydigitalfc}} In a written reply, Minister of State for Finance, Arjun Meghwal told the Lok Sabha in 2016: "The architecture of NSE with respect to dissemination of tick-by-tick through transmission control protocol (TCP) or internet protocol (IP) was prone to manipulation or market abuse. And this system has been discontinued by NSE from 3 December 2016." SEBI’s action so far has been to nudge the NSE into conducting investigations by two big global consulting firms, Deloitte and Ernst & Young, despite the fact that both had a potential conflict of interest, having handled major projects or consulting assignments for the bourse. Ravi Narain, as MD and CEO of the NSE, was also the head of the sub-committee which chose Deloitte for the forensic audit of NSE, despite being fully aware that Deloitte was working on a large project for NSE’s disaster recovery centre (DRC). This was a clear case of conflict of interest.{{cite web | url=https://www.outlookbusiness.com/the-big-story/lead-story/perilous-monopoly-3810 | title=Perilous Monopoly | Outlook Business}} In July 2018, SEBI issued a second show cause notice to the NSE, many of its former and existing executives, and senior officials alleged to have violated the SEBI Act, Securities Contracts (Regulation) Act, 1956 and Prohibition of Fraudulent and Unfair Trade Practices and broker regulations.{{cite web | url=https://www.bloombergquint.com/markets/2018/07/04/nse-gets-second-show-cause-notice-from-regulator-in-co-location-probe | title=NSE Gets Second Show-Cause Notice from SEBI in Co-Location Probe}} The notice comes even as the CBI has booked brokers and unidentified officials at the NSE and SEBI for preferential access through the co-location service.{{cite web | url=https://www.thehindubusinessline.com/markets/co-location-case-cbi-names-nse-sebi-officials-opg-securities/article24039742.ece | title=Co-location case: CBI names NSE, SEBI officials, OPG Securities}}{{cite news|url=https://www.thehindu.com/business/cbi-books-stock-broker-for-illegal-nse-access/article24039051.ece|title=CBI books stockbroker for illegal NSE access|newspaper=The Hindu|date=2018-05-30|last1=Pandey|first1=Devesh K.}} In August 2018, the Madras High Court issued notice to SEBI seeking appropriate action against NSE employees for the alleged fraud in co-location services and directed SEBI to file its response.{{cite web | url=https://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/city/chennai/madras-high-court-puts-sebi-on-notice-in-multicrore-stock-trading-scam/articleshow/65457187.cms | title=Madras high court puts Sebi on notice in multicrore stock trading scam - Times of India}}However, SEBI will hear this case in the mid of December, 2018.{{cite web|url=https://www.thehindubusinessline.com/markets/sebi-to-hear-nse-algo-case-in-december/article25540292.ece|title=SEBI to hear NSE algo case in December|date|2018-11-19 ===Raid conducted by Income Tax department=== In November 2017, the Income Tax Department (I-T) raided the premises of top former and serving officials of the NSE and its brokers. The I-T Department seized Rs. 11 crore cash from the Delhi residence of Sanjay Gupta, promoter of OPG securities. Officials of the I-T also raided more than 50 OPG group premises in Mumbai, Delhi and Kolkata. Along with cash, some laptops, storage devices and confidential documents were also seized.{{cite web | url=https://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/india/i-t-dept-seizes-rs-11-crore-cash-in-raids-related-to-nse-co-location-case/articleshow/61691871.cms | title=I-T dept seizes Rs.11 crore cash in raids related to NSE co-location case - Times of India}} It was reported in the media that during the I-T raids one name that repeatedly cropped up was that of Ajay Shah. I-T officials maintain that Ajay Shah developed the algorithm for the company OPG Securities.{{cite web | url=https://www.sundayguardianlive.com/investigation/11764-why-income-tax-officers-are-zeroing-ajay-shah | title=Why Income Tax officers are zeroing in on Ajay Shah| date=2017-11-26}} I-T officials also disclosed that they have gathered reconstructed order books with cash being transmitted to tax havens (preferred by FIIs) like Cyprus, the British Virgin Islands, Mauritius, and Hong Kong — wherever OPG securities had access.{{cite web | url=https://www.sundayguardianlive.com/investigation/11764-why-income-tax-officers-are-zeroing-ajay-shah?curator=alphaideas&utm_source=alphaideas | title=Why Income Tax officers are zeroing in on Ajay Shah| date=2017-11-26}} The I-T raid was conducted two days after the NSE submitted reports from forensic auditors EY and the Indian School of Business (ISB) to SEBI. Surprisingly, in their reports, both EY and the ISB exonerated the exchange and its officials.{{Cite news | url=https://economictimes.indiatimes.com/markets/stocks/news/it-raids-on-former-current-nse-officials-even-as-forensic-auditors-give-clean-chit/articleshow/61671549.cms | title=I-T raids on former, current NSE officials even as forensic auditors give clean chit| newspaper=The Economic Times| date=2017-11-16| last1=Narayanan| first1=Dinesh}} ===CBI action=== On 28th May 2018, the Central Bureau of Investigation filed nine-page first information report (FIR) a year after the second whistle- blower, calling himself Jaime Jones, made serious allegations in a letter to the SEBI chairman.{{cite web | url=https://www.moneylife.in/article/nse-algo-scam-cbi-steps-in-where-sebi-was-pussyfooting/54193.html | title=NSE Algo Scam: CBI Steps in Where SEBI Was Pussyfooting}} CBI then booked unknown officials of the NSE and SEBI, promoter of stock-trading company OPG Securities, Sanjay Gupta, his brother-in-law Aman Kokrady and NIPFP’s professor, Ajay Shah for manipulating NSE servers to get 'preferential' access by using the co-location facility at the NSE. The new element in the FIR was the allegation that Ajay Shah allegedly used his access to data as an academic to build algo-trading software that gave OPG Securities an advantage. CBI booked the case against these individuals for entering into criminal conspiracy, attempting to give and receive bribes, abuse of their official position, unfair access to TBT servers of the NSE for wrongful gain, manipulating the NSE server, and for destroying electronic evidence. CBI has also alleged that Sanjay Gupta and his brother-in-law, were illegally trading in Dubai, Ghana, Singapore, Hong Kong and China through his firm.{{cite news|url=https://www.thehindu.com/business/cbi-books-stock-broker-for-illegal-nse-access/article24039051.ece|title=CBI books stockbroker for illegal NSE access|newspaper=The Hindu|date=2018-05-30|last1=Pandey|first1=Devesh K.}} After filing this case, CBI teams also conducted raids at multiple locations in Delhi, Mumbai and Bangalore. M. Damodaran, former SEBI chairman made a statement saying, "Having seen reports of the CBI registering a case in connection with NSE's co-location issue, I hope SEBI's dealing with the matter is proceeding at the desired pace. It is important for regulatory credibility that SEBI takes effective action immediately. Since an Exchange is a first-level regulator, it must measure up, and be seen as measuring up, to the highest levels of governance. Failing that, SEBI must take quick corrective action."{{cite web | url=https://www.moneylife.in/article/nse-algo-scam-cbi-steps-in-where-sebi-was-pussyfooting/54193.html | title=NSE Algo Scam: CBI Steps in Where SEBI Was Pussyfooting}} ==NSE vs. Moneylife Case== On 8 July 2015, Sucheta Dalal wrote an article on ''Moneylife''{{’}}s portal alleging that certain NSE officials were leaking sensitive data related to HFT or co-location to a select set of market participants so that could trade faster than their competitors.{{citeweb|url=https://www.thenewsminute.com/article/moneylife%E2%80%99s-nse-expose-why-battle-against-stock-exchange-not-just-their-own-33874|title=Moneylife's NSE Expose|date=2015-09-01}} The article was based on an alleged complaint made to SEBI in January by an official of a Singapore-based hedge fund. The whistle-blower’s first letter came from Singapore and was addressed to BK Gupta, deputy general manager of SEBI, and dated 14 January 2015. It was copied to Sucheta Dalal from ''Moneylife''.{{citeweb|url=https://www.moneylife.in/article/blowing-the-whistle-on-manipulation-in-nse/42337.html|title=Blowing the Whistle on Manipulation in NSE|date=2015-06-19}} The co-location scandal came to light when the NSE filed a defamation suit on 21s July 2015, claiming damages of Rs.100 crore in the Bombay High Court against ''Moneylife'', to stop the publication and circulation of the article. However, the court dismissed the case and asked the NSE to pay Rs.1.5 lakh each to journalists Debashis Basu and Sucheta Dalal. The court also imposed a penalty of Rs.47 lakh on the NSE to be paid in the form of a donation to [[Masina Hospital]] and [[Tata Memorial Centre|Tata Memorial Hospital]] in Mumbai. The court also ordered SEBI to investigate the charges levelled by the whistle-blower.{{citeweb|url=https://www.moneylife.in/article/nse-withdraws-its-rs100-crore-defamation-suit-against-moneylife-pays-rs50-lakh-as-cost-and-penalty/51608.html|title=NSE withdraws its Rs100 crore defamation suit against Moneylife, pays Rs50 lakh as cost and penalty|date=2017-09-12}} == References == {{reflist}} [[Category:Scandals in India]] [[Category:Corruption in India]] [[Category:Stock exchanges in India]]

{{short description|18th-century Khan of Kalat}} {{Infobox nobility | name =Mir Nasir Khan Baloch I | title = [[Khan of Kalat]] | reign = 1749-1794 | predecessor = [[Mir Muhabbat]] | successor = [[Mahmud Khan I]] | birth_place = [[Khanate of Kalat|Kalat]] | death_date = 1794 | death_place =[[Khanate of Kalat|Kalat]] | religion = [[Islam]] | module = {{Infobox military person | embed = yes | allegiance = [[Mughal Empire]]
[[Durrani Empire]] | branch = [[Nawab]] of the [[Khanate of Kalat]] | rank = [[Sardar]], [[Plenipotentiary]], [[Nawab]] | battles = [[Third Battle of Panipat]] }} }} '''Mir Noori Naseer Khan Brahui '''was the [[Khan (title)|Khan]] ([[head of state]]) of the princely state of [[Kalat (princely state)|Kalat]] in what is now the [[Balochistan (Pakistan)|Balochistan]] province of [[Pakistan]] during the eighteenth century.[http://dsal.uchicago.edu/reference/gazetteer/pager.html?objectid=DS405.1.I34_V06_283.gif Baluchistan - Imperial Gazetteer of India, v. 6, p. 277.] == History == '''Mir Muhammad Nasir Khan I''' (also known as ''Mir Noori Nasir Khan'') was probably the most powerful of the Khans of Kalat who ruled for 45 years from 1749 to 1794. After an initial unsuccessful revolt against [[Ahmad Shah Durrani]] in 1758 he later became his most powerful ally and his [[Baloch people|Baloch]] Army fought alongside the [[Afghan]]s of Abdali against the [[Persian people|Persians]], the [[Maratha Empire|Marathas]] and the [[Sikh]]s. The boundaries of the '''Khanate of Kalat''' under Nasir Khan I extended far beyond those of modern Balochistan and included the town of [[Karachi]]. ==References== {{reflist}} {{Khans of Kalat|Mir Muhabbat| |Mir Muhammad Naseer Khan Noori I|Mir Mahmud Khan I|}} {{authority control}} [[Category:1794 deaths]] [[Category:18th-century monarchs in Asia]] [[Category:Baloch people]] [[Category:Princely rulers of Pakistan]] [[Category:Khans of Kalat]] [[Category:Nawabs of Pakistan]] {{Pakistan-history-stub}}

[[File:Page number.jpg|thumb|250 px|Page number in a book]] '''Page numbering''' is the process of applying a sequence of numbers (or letters, or roman numerals) to the pages of a book or other document. The number itself, which may appear in various places on the page, can be referred to as a '''page number''' or as a '''folio'''.<ref name="CMS">''[http://www.chicagomanualofstyle.org/16/ch01/ch01_sec005.html The Chicago Manual of Style, Sixteenth Edition]'' (2003), pp. 32–33.</ref> Like other numbering schemes such as [[Chapter (books)|chapter]] numbering, page numbers allow the [[citation]] of a particular page of the numbered document and facilitates to the reader to find specific parts of the document and to know the size of the complete text (by checking the number of the last page).
==Numbering conventions== Even numbers usually appear on [[Recto and verso|verso]] pages, while odd numbers appear on [[Recto and verso|recto]] pages. In the printing industry, in cases where odd numbers appear on verso pages and even numbers on recto pages, this is referred to as ''non-traditional folios'' (in the past, it had been referred to as ''Chinese folios'', however this term has fallen out of favor in recent years).{{Citation needed|date=May 2013}}
In books, some pages, known as ''blind folios'',<ref name="CMS"/> of the [[front matter]] and [[back matter]] are numbered, but the numbers are not always printed on the pages. Publishers are not consistent about how they number the pages of their books. Some publishers stick with the default numbering of the tool they are using, which is typically to number the first page of the front matter as one and all pages after that in a consecutive order. When publishers wish to distinguish between the front matter and the story, the initial title pages are not numbered, the front matter is numbered using lower-case [[Roman numerals]] (i, ii, iii, etc.) and the first page of the story or main content begins with one. The title page of the story is not numbered, but if a story is broken into multiple parts (Part I, Part II, etc.), the title page for the section may be included in the numbering but not shown on the page. The first page of Chapter One would then be numbered as page three rather than page one as would be the normal case.
The sixteenth edition of the ''[[Chicago Manual of Style]]''<ref name="CMS"/> calls for the beginning of the text to begin with the Arabic number 1, while the front matter that precedes it is to be numbered with lower-case Roman numerals. If the front matter is extensive and a second half-title page is included, it is to be numbered as page one and its verso as page two. If a part title is included, it is to be included in the same numbering as the text. Page numbers do not appear on part titles. Most citation systems also call for the identification of the page number from which a quote or point is drawn. For example, such usage is specified in their citation formats of both the ''[[Chicago Manual of Style]]'',<ref>''The Chicago Manual of Style, Sixteenth Edition'' (2003), pp. 596, 598.</ref> and the ''[[Bluebook]]''.<ref>''The Bluebook: A Uniform System of Citation, Seventeenth Edition'' (2000), pp. 34–36.</ref>
=={{anchor|Location number}}Electronic documents== [[E-books]] and other electronic documents published in a non-[[Reflowable document|reflowable format]] such as [[PDF]] are normally [[Pagination|paginated]] and numbered in the same way as their printed counterparts.
While reading devices for reflowable documents such as [[EPUB]] e-books may display page numbers, these numbers change from device to device depending on factors such as the size of the display and the selected font size. This makes them unsuitable for citation purposes. To remedy this problem, [[Amazon Kindle]] e-books contain what are called "location numbers", that is, numbers in the margin of the electronic text that indicate where the corresponding page begins in the printed version of the book.<ref>{{cite news|last=Pogue|first=David|title=Page Numbers for Kindle Books an Imperfect Solution|url=http://pogue.blogs.nytimes.com/2011/02/08/page-numbers-for-kindle-books-an-imperfect-solution/|accessdate=9 July 2011|newspaper=[[New York Times]], "Pogue's Post" blog|date=8 February 2011}}</ref>
==Manuscripts== In [[codicology]], each physical sheet (''folium'', abbreviated ''fol.'' or ''f.'') of a manuscript is numbered, and the sides are referred to as ''folium [[recto and verso|rectum]]'' and ''folium [[recto and verso|versum]]'', abbreviated as ''r'' and ''v'' respectively. This results in designations like ''5r'' (the front side of the fifth sheet), or ''8v'' (the back side of the eighth sheet).

36037 Fulda
|- bgcolor="#FFFFFF" |President || colspan="2" | vacant |- bgcolor="#FFFFFF" |Members || colspan="2" | 25,000 ''(2010)'' |- bgcolor="#FFFFFF" |- !colspan="3" | Internet |- bgcolor="#FFFFFF" |valign="top" | Home page || colspan="2" | [http://www.rhoenklub.de/ www.rhoenklub.de] |} The '''Rhön Club''' ({{lang-de|Rhönklub}}) is an inter-state local history and rambling club in [[Bavaria]], [[Hesse]] and [[Thuringia]], with around 25,000 members in 88 branches and is one of the larger German rambling clubs in the Association of German Alpine and Rambling Clubs (''Verband Deutscher Gebirgs- und Wandervereine''). == Aims == The club was founded on 6 August 1876 in [[Gersfeld]] with the aim of opening up the [[Rhön Mountains]] as a hiking and rambling area. Its aim today is the conservation of the valuable natural and cultural countryside of the Rhön from a number of ecological viewpoints, especially: * the preservation of rare plants * the care of native animals and the general protection of wildlife * the conservation of valuable cultural sites * the fostering of local customs * the preservation of local folk songs * the knowledgeable speaking of the dialect * the care of old cultural objects == Presidents == {| class="wikitable" |- class="hintergrundfarbe6" ! {{Multiple issues| {{Lead too short|date=August 2018}} {{More citations needed|date=September 2018}}}} [[File:Flag of Russia.svg|thumb|200px|Flag of [[Russia]].]] [[File:RedSquare SaintBasile (pixinn.net).jpg|thumb|250px|[[Saint Basil's Cathedral]] on the [[Red Square]], in Moscow]] '''Russophilia''' (literally love of [[Russia]] or [[Russians]]) is individual or collective admiration and fond of Russia, [[Russian history]] and [[Russian culture]], especially someone who is sympathetic to the political system and customs of the former Soviet Union or who exhibits Russian nationalism in spite of not even being either an ethnic Russian or a Russian citizen. The opposite of Russophilia is [[Russophobia]].
==Russophilia in Europe== Russophilia in other European countries may be based on [[stereotype]]s produced by [[media culture|mass culture]] ("traditional Russian hospitality", "Russian tenderness" etc.),{{Citation needed|date=September 2018}} as well as on in-depth study of Russian mentality, as expressed, e.g., by American author Robert Alexander: "I love Russians for their dramatic, emotional nature. They're not afraid to love, not afraid to get hurt, not afraid to exaggerate or act impulsively."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rusoffagency.com/authors/alexander_r/kitchen_boy/kitchen_boy_reading_guide.htm|title=Book Group Guide - Rusoff Agency|website=Rusoffagency.com|accessdate=17 October 2018}}</ref>
In October 2004, the [[Gallup Poll|International Gallup Organization]] announced the results of its poll,<ref name=HelsSan>''[[Helsingin Sanomat]]'', October 11, 2004, [http://www.hs.fi/english/article/International+poll+Anti-Russian+sentiment+runs+very+strong+in+Finland/1076154202275 International poll: Anti-Russian sentiment runs very strong in Finland. Only [[Kosovo]] has more negative attitude]</ref> according to which approximately 20% of the residents of [[Western Europe]] viewed Russia positively, with the most positive view coming from [[Iceland]], [[Germany]], [[Greece]], and [[United Kingdom|Britain]]. The percentage of respondents expressing a positive attitude towards Russia was 9% in [[Finland]], [[Turkey]], and [[Japan]], 38% in [[Lithuania]], 36% in [[Latvia]], and 34% in [[Estonia]].{{Citation needed|date=September 2018}} Estonia and especially Latvia have a large number of ethnic Russians, which likely affected the result.
==Russophilia in Serbia and Montenegro==
===Russophilia in Serbia=== {{Refimprove section|date=September 2018}} Russia is hugely popular in Serbia, and [[Serbs]] have always traditionally seen Russia as a close ally due to shared [[Slavs|Slavic]] culture and Orthodox faith.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://crms.org.rs/zasto-je-putin-toliko-popularan-u-srbiji/|title=Зашто је Путин толико популаран у Србији? – Центар за развој међународне сарадње|website=crms.org.rs|accessdate=17 October 2018}}</ref> In Serbia and Montenegro, whose nations are both predominately [[Eastern Orthodox]], the faith expressed by a vast majority of Russians, there was no Soviet influence and Russians were always seen as friendly brotherly people.{{Citation needed|date=September 2018}} About 83% of Serbs see Russia as their first ally on the international scene.{{Citation needed|date=September 2018}} In both Serbia and Montenegro, there are neighbourhoods, streets, buildings and statues named after something Russian.{{Citation needed|date=September 2018}} In Serbia there is the Russian Centre of Science and Culture and [[Hotel Moskva (Belgrade)|Hotel Moskva]].
<gallery> Image:Ruski centar za kulturu i nauku u Beogradu.JPG|[[Russian Center of Science and Culture (Belgrade)]] Image:Dmitry Medvedev in Serbia 20 October 2009-8.jpg|[[Dmitry Medvedev]] in [[National Assembly of Serbia]] Image:Ruska crkva, Belgrade.jpg|Russian Orthodox Church in [[Tašmajdan park]], Belgrade File:Vladimir Putin in Serbia March 2011-34.jpeg|[[Vladimir Putin]] at Belgrade's [[Red Star Stadium]] in March 2011 File:Vladimir Putin in Serbia March 2011-39.jpeg|[[Vladimir Putin]] in front of [[Cathedral of Saint Sava]] </gallery>
===Russophilia in Montenegro=== Montenegro is also an [[Eastern Orthodox]] and [[Slavic people|Slavic]] country. There is the [[Moscow bridge|Moscow Bridge]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.androidvodic.com/info_podgorica_turisticke-atrakcije_moskovski-most|title=Moscow bridge in Podgorica|website=Androidvodic.com|accessdate=17 October 2018}}</ref> in [[Podgorica]], and a statue of Russian singer and actor [[Vladimir Vysotsky]] next to the bridge.
<gallery> File:Dva mosta panorama sm.jpg|[[Moscow bridge|Moscow Bridge]], [[Podgorica]] </gallery>
==Russophilia in Ukraine== Following [[Ukrainian independence]] in 1991 Ukrainians, mostly in the [[East Ukraine|east]] and [[South Ukraine|south]] of the country, voted to a see a more Russophile attitude of the government, ranging from closer economic partnership to full national union.<ref>{{cite book|format=PDF|url=https://www.census.gov/population/international/files/sp/SP90.pdf|title=Ethnic Reidentification in Ukraine (page 17)|publisher=[[United States Census Bureau]]|first=Stephen|last=Rapawy|year=1997|location=Washington, D.C.|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://www.census.gov/content/dam/Census/library/working-papers/1997/demo/sp90.pdf|archivedate=19 October 2012|df=dmy-all}}</ref> Since the [[Russian military intervention in Ukraine (2014–present)|2014 Russian military intervention in Ukraine]] the overall attitude of Ukrainians towards Russia and Russians has become much more negative.<ref>[https://www.brookings.edu/blog/order-from-chaos/2017/10/18/how-ukraine-views-russia-and-the-west/ How Ukraine views Russia and the West], [[Brookings Institution]] (October 18, 2017)</ref>
===Western Ukraine=== {{Main|Western Ukrainian Russophiles}} '''Russophilia''' (Moscophilia, [[Ukrainian language|Ukrainian]]: москвофільство, ''moskvofil’stvo'') was a linguistic, literary and socio-political movement in the Western [[Ukraine|Ukrainian]] territories of [[Galicia (Central Europe)|Galicia]], [[Carpathian Ruthenia|Transcarpathia]], and [[Bukovyna]] in the 18th - 20th centuries. Proponents of this movement believed in linguistic, cultural, social union with Russian people and later in state union with Russia. Among the causes for the emergence of this phenomenon were the absence of Ukrainian statehood, centuries of foreign oppression, fragmented Ukrainian territories and dispersed population, as well as the defection of national elite to neighbouring cultures and a weak sense of national identity.{{Citation needed|date=September 2018}}
===Russophile Movement in Transcarpathia=== The first instances of Russophilia in [[Carpathian Ruthenia|Transcarpathia]] date back as far as late 18th early 19th centuries when several famous Russians with ties to the government and the court of the tsar settled there. Such famous scientists and social activists as [[I. Orlai]], [[M. Baludiansky]], [[P. Lodiy]] and others lived in Transcarpathia and maintained close ties with the country of their birth and thereby promoted interest towards Russia, especially towards its cultural life, its language and literature.{{Citation needed|date=September 2018}}
===Russophile Movement in Galicia and Bukovyna=== When [[Galicia (Eastern Europe)|Galicia]] and [[Bukovyna]] were incorporated into the [[Habsburg Empire]] in 1772 the Austrian government treated the Ukrainian population of these territories with suspicion as it was afraid it was susceptible to Russian influence due to the closeness of Ukrainian and Russian languages and cultures. This mistrust of the authorities was cultivated by influential Polish politicians and activists in an effort to forestall the growth of national consciousness on territories where Poles traditionally had influence. Any attempt at cultural revival was met with hostility from the Austrian government which regarded them as an influence from Moscow. In spite of this atmosphere of mistrust and suspicion the first educational establishment "The Fellowship of Priests" was founded in [[Przemyśl]]. Metropolitan M. Levytsky began to introduce the [[Ruthenian language]] in elementary schools, developed grammar books, insisted on instruction in University in Ruthenian and founded "Ruska Troyka" Society. The [[Lemko-Rusyn Republic]], after [[World War I]], attempted to join [[Lemko]] territories to Russia, and later to similar areas of the newly formed [[Czechoslovakia]].{{Citation needed|date=September 2018}}

{{Infobox ethnic group |group=Sara |image=Chadgirl.jpg |caption=A Sara woman |total=~4 million |popplace= The Republic of [[Chad]], the [[Central African Republic]], and the Republic of North [[Sudan]] |langs=[[Sara languages]], [[French language|French]] |rels=[[Christianity]], Sara animism ([[traditional African religion]]), [[Islam]] |related=[[Nilotic peoples]] }} The '''Sara people''' are Nilotes originating from the Upper Nile. They predominantly reside in southern [[Chad]], the northwestern areas of the [[Central African Republic]], and the southern border of North [[Sudan]].<ref>[https://www.britannica.com/topic/Sara Sara people], Encyclopædia Britannica</ref> They speak the [[Sara languages]], a dialect or sub-group of the [[Nilo-Saharan languages|Nilo-Saharan]] family.<ref>[http://www.ethnologue.com/17/subgroups/sara/ Sara languages], Ethnologue</ref> They are also the largest [[Ethnic groups in Chad|ethnic group in Chad]].<ref>[https://www.cia.gov/library/publications/the-world-factbook/geos/cd.html Chad: Society and People], CIA Factbook, US Government</ref><ref>{{cite book|author=Christine Zuchora-Walske|title=Chad in Pictures|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=kkB1GaR2SXEC&pg=PA47|year=2009|publisher=Twenty-First Century|isbn=978-1-57505-956-3|page=47}}</ref>
Sara oral histories add further details about the people. In summary, the Sara are mostly animists (veneration of nature), with a social order made up of several patrilineal clans formerly united into a single polity with a national language, national identity, and national religion. Many Sara people have retained their ethnic religion, but some have converted to Christianity and Islam.<ref name="Olson1996p510"/>
==Overview== [[File:Charirivermap.png|thumb|left|180px|Many Sara people live in the region southeast of [[Lake Chad]], which is irrigated by the Chari and Logone rivers.<ref name="Olson1996p510">{{cite book|author=James Stuart Olson|title=The Peoples of Africa: An Ethnohistorical Dictionary|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=MdaAdBC-_S4C&pg=PA510|year=1996|publisher=Greenwood|isbn=978-0-313-27918-8|page=510}}</ref>]]
===In Chad=== The Sara (Kameeni) are the largest ethnic group in the Republic of Chad, they're concentrated in the [[Moyen-Chari Region|Moyen-Chari]], the [[Logone Oriental Region|Logone Oriental]], the [[Logone Occidental Region|Logone Occidental]], and parts of the [[Tandjilé Region|Tandjile]] regions. They're originally from the Nile valley and migrated towards what is now Chad during the sixteenth century AD, seeking refuge in the south against northern [[Arab slave trade|Muslim slave raiders]].<ref>http://www.our-africa.org/chad/history-politics</ref>{{notinref|date=October 2017}} After their arrival, they continued to be the target of violent raids by northern [[Fula people|Fulani]] and [[Arab]] people.<ref name="Olson1996p510"/><ref name= Azevedo>{{cite book|author=M. J. Azevedo|title=The Roots of Violence: A History of War in Chad|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Y-SNAgAAQBAJ&pg=PA11 |year=2005|publisher=Routledge|isbn=978-1-135-30080-7|pages=10–11}}</ref><ref name="Shillington2013p228">{{cite book|author=Kevin Shillington|title=Encyclopedia of African History 3-Volume Set|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=umyHqvAErOAC&pg=PA228 |year=2013|publisher=Routledge|isbn=978-1-135-45670-2|page=228}}</ref>
[[File:COLLECTIE TROPENMUSEUM Twee Sara mannen met gezichtsscarificaties TMnr 60033953.jpg|thumb|180px|Body scarring rituals to create lifelong body art have long been a part of Sara culture and acts as a means of affirming solidarity; both men and women subscribe to it.<ref>Mario Zamora et al (1981), [http://files.eric.ed.gov/fulltext/ED241392.pdf#page=139 Image and Reality in African Interethnic Relations: The Fulbe and their Neighbors], US Department of Education, pages 136-137, 162-167</ref>]] The local Muslim groups of what is now Chad, referred to the Sara as ''"Kirdi"'', with the term "Kirdi" denoting a non-Muslim person. The Muslim raiders of what is now Chad were autonomously called ''"Bagirmi"'', and this geo-political conflict between the ''Kirdi'' and the ''Bagirmi'' continued through the nineteenth century.<ref name=levinsonsara/><ref name="Gateseoa254"/>
The French colonial empire entered the ongoing hostilities in the early twentieth century, and the Sara people became a part of the French Equatorial Africa, more specifically as part of the ''"1e Tchad utile"''. The Sara society was transformed by this development, both in terms of culture such as French-based education and training, but also socio-economically because of forced labor and conscription to serve the French military during the World Wars.<ref name=levinsonsara/> At the time of independence from France in 1960, the southerners of Chad were more assimilated into French institutions than the northerners.<ref name=levinsonsara>{{cite book|title = The Encyclopedia of World Cultures - 10 Volume set, 1st Edition|author=David Levinson|publisher= Gale|isbn= 978-0816118403|chapter=Sara|year=1996}}</ref> This led to their political dominance of the country after 1960. They were also a part of the civil war with populations in north and central Chad, each population aligning with a different ideology.<ref name="Gateseoa254">{{cite book|author1=Anthony Appiah|author2=Henry Louis Gates|title=Encyclopedia of Africa|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=A0XNvklcqbwC |year=2010|publisher=Oxford University Press|isbn=978-0-19-533770-9|pages=253–256}}</ref>
===In the Central African Republic=== The Sara people make up ten per cent of the population of the [[Central African Republic]], making it the fourth largest ethnic group in the country. They live in the northwest part of CAR.
==Languages== The Sara people natively speak the [[Sara languages]]. This dialect cluster belongs to the [[Nilo-Saharan languages|Nilo-Saharan]] family.
==Genetics== Analysis of classic genetic markers and DNA polymorphisms by Excoffier et al. (1987) found that the Sara are most closely related to the [[Kunama people]] of [[Eritrea]]. Both populations speak languages from the Nilo-Saharan family. They are also similar to West African populations, but biologically distinct from the surrounding [[Cushitic languages|Cushitic]] and [[Ethiopian Semitic languages|Ethiopian Semitic]] [[Afroasiatic languages|Afro-Asiatic]]-speaking groups.<ref>{{cite journal|authors=Excoffier, Laurent, et al.|title=Genetics and history of sub-Saharan Africa|journal=American Journal of Physical Anthropology|date=1987|volume=30|pages=151–194|url=http://archive-ouverte.unige.ch/unige:14816/ATTACHMENT01|accessdate=1 September 2016|doi=10.1002/ajpa.1330300510}}</ref>
== Famous Sara people == *[[François Tombalbaye]], first [[President of Chad]] *[[Noël Milarew Odingar]], who overthrew Tombalbaye during the [[Chadian coup of 1975|1975 coup]] *[[Fidèle Moungar]], Prime minister of Chad in 1993, president of [[Action for Unity and Socialism]] *[[Sosthene Moguenara]], Chad born German Track and Field Athlete
==See also== *[[Demographics of Chad]] *[[Demographics of the Central African Republic]] *[[Sara languages]]

[[Honduras]] has experienced a long history of changing social conditions, beginning with the bands of foragers in ancient times, through the development of complex societies in the Pacific coast side of the [[isthmus]], and evolving through the innovations introduced by the [[Spanish Empire|Spanish]] in the colonial period.
Post colonial Honduras continued many of the colonial social structures and institutions, with major additions in the late nineteenth and early twentieth century as major foreign companies pioneered new modes of producing export products and systems of controlling labor. More recent trends in [[industrialization]] have also had important effects.
== Summary ==
Honduras faces enormous challenges in the areas of [[crime]] and [[human rights]] and improving overall economic and [[Living Conditions|living conditions]] in one of the hemisphere’s poorest countries. The [[United States]] has a close relationship with Honduras, characterized by significant foreign assistance, an important trade partnership, a military presence in the country, and cooperation on a range of transnational issues.
A U.S.-Central America Free Trade Agreement (CAFTA) with five [[Central America|Central American]] countries was signed on May 28, 2004, and a combined U.S.-[[Dominican Republic–Central America Free Trade Agreement|Dominican Republic-Central America Free Trade Agreement]] (DR-CAFTA) was signed on August 5, 2004. The [[Honduran Congress]] approved the agreement on March 3, 2005, by a vote of 124-4. The Bush Administration views DR-CAFTA as a means of solidifying democracy in Honduras and promoting safeguards for [[environmental protection]] and [[labor rights]] in the country.
Critics fear that a CAFTA without strong environmental and labor provisions would do nothing to spur reforms in the country. For additional information, see CRS Report RL31870, The Dominican Republic.-Central America-United States Free Trade Agreement (DRCAFTA); and CRS Report RL32322, Central America and the [[Dominican Republic]] in the Context of the Free Trade Agreement (DR-CAFTA) with the United States.<ref>For more info visit: https://fpc.state.gov/documents/organization/47138.pdf</ref>
== Social history == === Early history ===
The indigenous people of Honduras developed stratified societies in some regions very early, and much of the earliest period conditions were shaped by its division into unequally represented social groups, in which some economic exploitation took place. Documentation, limited as it was from Maya sites confirms this inequality which is also observed archaeologically.
Early Spanish reports likewise speak of inequities in the society, and the Spanish tended to exacerbate these. The [[encomienda]] system while it initially drew heavily on the older systems of taxation and labor employment used by indigenous polities, added new elements. The mining economy, at first drawing on laborers from the encomiendas, increasing used slave labor in the late sixteenth century, and then as the mines were depleted, also turned back to wage labor.
===Twentieth Century===
In the last years of the nineteenth century, Honduran governments sought to encourage economic growth by creating incentives for foreign concerns to operate in the country. The involvement of such companies as [[United Fruit Company|United Fruit]], [[Standard Fruit Company|Standard Fruit]] and others in the northern sections of the country led to concentration of landholdings, the emergence of a class of [[United States|North American]] managers living in separate quarters on estates, and the importation of migrant workers from the [[English-speaking Caribbean|English-Speaking Caribbean]] and elsewhere in Central America altered the pattern of small holding farming that had prevailed in the region before. Many of the new workers were housed in barracks, frequently came without families and were subject to strict discipline.
Beginning in the late 1970s, new foreign concerns began the introduction of [[maquiladora]]s, larger more modern factories to produce textiles and other goods. They were particularly interested in using the labor of young females, to the point that in much of the industry female workers outnumber male by as much as two-to-one. This imbalance in employment has led increasingly to problems with the often unemployed males, and led to a concomitant growth of gangs and violence.<ref>{{cite book |first=Adrienne |last=Pine |title=Working Hard, Drinking Hard: On Violence and Survival in Honduras |location=Berkeley and Los Angeles |publisher=University of California Press |year=2007 |isbn=978-0-520-25543-2 }}</ref> Substance abuse, at first primarily alcohol, and later hard drugs (especially as the international drug trade has made use of Honduras for the transit of drugs) have created their own problems.
