{{Infobox women |image = Japanese women.jpg |caption = Women wearing [[kimonos]] in [[Tokyo]], [[Japan]] |gii = 0.131 (2012) |gii_rank = 21st |matdeath = 5 (2010) |womparl = 13.4% (2012) |femed = 80.0% (2010) |womlab = 64.6% [[employment rate]] (2015)<ref name="stats.oecd.org">http://stats.oecd.org/Index.aspx?DatasetCode=LFS_SEXAGE_I_R#</ref> | ggg = 0.6498 (2013) | ggg_rank = 105th | ggg_ref = <ref name="ggr">{{cite web|title=The Global Gender Gap Report 2013|url=http://www3.weforum.org/docs/WEF_GenderGap_Report_2013.pdf#page=20|publisher=World Economic Forum|pages=12–13}}</ref> }} {{Women in society sidebar}}
While '''women in Japan''' were recognized as having equal legal rights to men after [[World War II]], economic conditions for women remain unbalanced.<ref name=nytimes-soble /> Modern policy initiatives to encourage motherhood and workplace participation have had mixed results.<ref name=Borovoy />
While a high percentage of Japanese women are college graduates, making up 77% of the part-time work force,<ref name=Economist>{{cite web|title=Holding back half the nation|url=https://www.economist.com/news/briefing/21599763-womens-lowly-status-japanese-workplace-has-barely-improved-decades-and-country|website=The Economist|publisher=The Economist|accessdate=12 December 2015}}</ref> they typically earn 27% less than their male counterparts.<ref name="Nikkei Asian Review 2017">{{cite web | title=Japan's gender wage gap persists despite progress- Nikkei Asian Review | website=Nikkei Asian Review | date=23 Feb 2017 | url=http://asia.nikkei.com/Politics-Economy/Economy/Japan-s-gender-wage-gap-persists-despite-progress}}</ref> Traditional expectations for married women and mothers are cited as a barrier to full economic equality.<ref name=Nohara /> The monarchy is strictly males-only and a princess has to give up her royal status when she marries a commoner.
==Cultural history==
{{multiple image| align = left | direction = vertical | header = | header_align = left/right/center | footer = 19th century depictions of Japanese women, ''Woman in Red Clothing (1912)'' and ''Under the Shade of a Tree (1898)'' by [[Kuroda Seiki]]. ''Japanese Woman (1903)'' by Hungarian artist [[Bertalan Székely]].| footer_align = left | image1 = Woman in Red Clothing by Kuroda Seiki.jpg | width1 = 220| caption1 = | image2 = Under the Shade of a Tree by Kuroda Seiki (Woodone Museum of Art).png | width2 = 220| caption2 = | image3 = Japan no.jpg | width3 = 220| caption3 = }}
The extent to which women could participate in Japanese society has varied over time and social classes. In the 8th century, Japan had women emperors, and in the 12th century during the [[Heian period]], women in Japan could inherit property in their own names and manage it by themselves: "Women could own property, be educated, and were allowed, if discrete (sic), to take lovers."<ref name="Women in World History">{{cite web|title=Heroines: Heian Period (Women in World History Curriculum)|url=http://www.womeninworldhistory.com/Heian9.html|website=www.womeninworldhistory.com}}</ref>
{{multiple image| align = right | direction = horizontal | header = | header_align = left/right/center | footer = | footer_align = left | image1 = RyokoMutsu.jpg | width1 = 141| caption1 = Countess Ryoko Mutsu, wife of notable diplomat Count [[Mutsu Munemitsu]]. Photographed in 1888.| image2 = Yanagiwara Byakuren.jpg | width2 = 157| caption2 = Yanagiwara Byakuren, a poet and member of the imperial family.}}
From the late [[Edo period]], the status of women declined. In the 17th century, the "[[Onna Daigaku]]", or "Learning for Women", by [[Confucianism|Confucianist]] author [[Kaibara Ekken]], spelled out expectations for Japanese women, stating that "such is the stupidity of her character that it is incumbent on her, in every particular, to distrust herself and to obey her husband".<ref name=Ekken>{{cite book|last1=Ekken|first1=Kaibara|title=Onna Daigaku A Treasure Box of Women's Learning.|date=2010|publisher=Gardners Books|isbn=0955979676|url=https://archive.org/stream/womenwisdomofjap00kaib/womenwisdomofjap00kaib_djvu.txt}}</ref>
During the [[Meiji period]], [[industrialization]] and [[urbanization]] reduced the authority of [[father]]s and [[husband]]s, but at the same time the Meiji Civil Code of 1898 (specifically the introduction of the [[Ie (Japanese family system)|"ie"]] system) denied women [[legal rights]] and subjugated them to the will of household heads.<ref name="Womeninworldhistory">[http://www.womeninworldhistory.com/WR-04.html The Meiji Reforms and Obstacles for Women Japan, 1878–1927]</ref>
===Behavioral expectations===
In interviews with Japanese housewives in 1985, researchers found that socialized [[Femininity|feminine]] behavior in Japan followed several patterns of modesty, tidiness, courtesy, compliance, and self-reliance.<ref name="Lebra 1985">{{cite book|last1=Lebra|first1=Takie Sugiyama|title=Japanese women : constraint and fulfillment|date=1985|publisher=University of Hawaii Press|location=Honolulu, HI|isbn=0824810252|edition=Pbk.}}</ref> Modesty extended to the effective use of silence in both daily conversations and activities. Tidiness included personal appearance and a clean home. Courtesy, another trait, was called upon from women in domestic roles and in entertaining guests, extended to activities such as preparing and serving tea.
Lebra's traits for internal comportment of femininity included compliance; for example, [[child]]ren were expected not to refuse their parents. Self-reliance of women was encouraged because needy women were seen as a burden on others. In these interviews with Japanese families, Lebra found that girls were assigned helping tasks while boys were more inclined to be left to schoolwork.<ref name="Lebra 1985" /> Lebra's work has been critiqued for focusing specifically on a single economic segment of Japanese women.<ref name=Tamanoi>{{cite journal|last1=Tamanoi|first1=Mariko|title=Women's Voices: Their Critique of the Anthropology of Japan|journal=Annual Review of Anthropology|date=October 1990|volume=19|pages=17–37|url=http://search.ebscohost.com/login.aspx?direct=true&db=a9h&AN=11266352&site=ehost-live|accessdate=25 December 2015|issn=0084-6570|postscript={{subscription needed|via=[https://www.ebsco.com EBSCO]'s Academic Search Complete}}|doi=10.1146/annurev.an.19.100190.000313}}</ref>
Although Japan remains a socially conservative society, with relatively pronounced [[gender roles]], Japanese women and Japanese society are quite different from the strong stereotypes that exist in foreign media or travel guides, which paint the women in Japan as 'submissive' and devoid of any self-determination.<ref>''Rethinking Japan: Social sciences, ideology & thought'', by Adriana Boscaro, Franco Gatti, Massimo Raveri, pp. 164-173</ref> Another strong stereotype about Japan is that women always stay in the home as housewives and that they do not participate in public life: in reality most women are employed – the [[employment rate]] of women (age 15–64) is 64.6% (data from [[OECD]] 2015<ref name="stats.oecd.org">http://stats.oecd.org/Index.aspx?DatasetCode=LFS_SEXAGE_I_R#</ref>).
==Political status of women==
The Japanese Constitution, drafted by the US and adopted in the post-war era, provided a legal framework favorable to the advancement of women’s equality in Japan.<ref name=Chanlett>{{cite journal|last1=Chanlett-Avery|first1=Emma|last2=Nelson|first2=Rebecca M.|title="Womenomics" in Japan: In Brief|journal=Congressional Research Service|date=2014|url=https://www.fas.org/sgp/crs/row/R43668.pdf}}</ref> Women were given the [[Women's suffrage in Japan|right to vote]] in 1946. This allowed them greater freedom, equality to men, and a higher status within Japanese society. Other postwar reforms opened education institutions to women and required that women receive [[equal pay for equal work]]. In 1986, the Equal Employment Opportunity Law took effect. Legally, few barriers to women's equal participation in the life of society remain. However, socially they lack opportunities in the workforce due to the long work hours and dominance in the workplace by men.
[[File:5000 Yenes (2004) (Anverso).jpg|thumb|right|Portrait of [[Ichiyō Higuchi]], pioneering female author on 5000 yen banknote]]
In a global survey of women in parliaments, Japan ranked 123rd out of 189 countries.<ref name="Economist 2015">{{cite web|last1=Economist|title=Holding back half the nation|url=https://www.economist.com/news/briefing/21599763-womens-lowly-status-japanese-workplace-has-barely-improved-decades-and-country|website=The Economist|publisher=The Economist|accessdate=15 December 2015}}</ref> In Japan's [[National Diet|Diet]], women hold slightly less than 10% of seats despite a government goal for 30% of elected officials to be women by 2020.<ref name=Chanlett /> In the lower house of the Diet, women hold only 8% of seats, with 19% in the upper house.<ref name="Economist 2015" /> Less than 1% of mayors were women.<ref name=Beech>{{cite web|last1=Beech|first1=Hannah|title=‘You Mean Women Deserve Careers?’ Patriarchal Japan Has Breakthrough Moment|url=http://world.time.com/2013/09/30/you-mean-women-deserve-careers-patriarchal-japan-has-breakthrough-moment/|website=Time|publisher=Time Magazine|accessdate=15 December 2015}}</ref>
The Japanese government has expressed a will to address this inequality of numbers in the 21st century of the [[Heisei period]] through several focused initiatives,<ref name=ShinzoAbe>{{cite web|last1=Abe|first1=Shinzo|title=Unleashing the Power of 'Womenomics'|url=https://www.wsj.com/news/articles/SB10001424052702303759604579091680931293404|website=Wall Street Journal|publisher=Wall Street Journal|accessdate=15 December 2015}}</ref> and a 2012 poll by the [[Cabinet Office (Japan)|Cabinet Office]] found that nearly 70% of all Japanese polled agreed that men were given preferential treatment.<ref name="Gender Equality Bureau 1-10">{{cite web|last1=Cabinet Office|first1=Gender Equality Bureau|title=Perceptions of Gender Inequality|url=http://www.gender.go.jp/english_contents/pr_act/pub/pamphlet/women-and-men15/pdf/1-10.pdf|website=www.gender.go.jp/|publisher=Japan Cabinet Office Gender Equality Bureau|accessdate=15 December 2015}}</ref>
==Professional life==
[[File:Kazuyo Sejima mg 5000.jpg|thumb|150px|[[Kazuyo Sejima]], an architect]]
During the 21st century, Japanese women are working in higher proportions than the United States's working female population.<ref name="nytimes-soble">{{cite news |last1=Soble |first1=Jonathan |title=To Rescue Economy, Japan Turns to Supermom |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2015/01/02/business/international/in-economic-revival-effort-japan-turns-to-its-women.html |accessdate=2015-04-07 |work=[[The New York Times]] |date=1 January 2015 }}</ref> Income levels between men and women in Japan are not equal; the average Japanese woman earns 40 percent less than the average man, and a tenth of management positions are held by women.<ref name="nytimes-soble"/> Women are often found in part time or temporary jobs. 77% of these jobs were filled by women in 2012.<ref name=Economist /> Among women who do work, women-only unions are small in size and in relative power.<ref name="Briskin 1999">{{cite journal|last1=Briskin|first1=Linda|title=Autonomy, diversity and integration: Union women's separate organising in North America and Western Europe in the context of restructuring and globalization|journal=Women's Studies International Forum|date=1999|volume=22|issue=5}}</ref> A common occupation for young women is that of [[office lady]], that is, a female office worker who performs generally [[pink collar]] tasks such as serving tea and [[Secretary|secretarial]] or [[Clerk|clerical]] work.
Japan has a strong tradition of women being [[housewives]] after marriage.<ref name=Hendry /><ref name=Morsbach>{{cite book|last1=Morsbach|first1=Helmut|authorlink1=The Couple|editor1-last=Corbyn|editor1-first=Marie|title=Aspects of Japanese Marriage|date=1978|publisher=Penguin Books|page=98}}</ref> When mothers do work, they often pick up part-time, low-paying jobs based on their children's or husband's schedule.<ref name=Hirata>{{cite book|last1=Hirata|first1=Keiko|last2=Warschauer|first2=Mark|title=Japan : the paradox of harmony|date=2014|publisher=Yale University Press|location=New Haven|isbn=978-0300186079|page=49}}</ref> Taking care of the family and household is seen as a predominately female role, and working women are expected to fulfill it.<ref name=Nemoto>{{cite journal|last1=Nemoto|first1=Kumiko|title=Long Working Hours and the Corporate Gender Divide in Japan|journal=Gender, Work & Organization|date=Sep 2013|volume=20|issue=5|pages=512–527|doi=10.1111/j.1468-0432.2012.00599.x|url=http://search.ebscohost.com/login.aspx?direct=true&db=a9h&AN=89305565&site=ehost-live|publisher=Wiley-Blackwell|issn=0968-6673|postscript={{subscription needed|via=[https://www.ebsco.com EBSCO]'s Academic Search Complete}}}}</ref> Nevertheless, in recent years the numbers of women who work has increased: in 2014, women made up 42.7% of the labour force of Japan.<ref>http://data.worldbank.org/indicator/SL.TLF.TOTL.FE.ZS</ref> Japan has an especially high proportion of women who work part-time, and a majority of those women are mothers.<ref>Yu, p. 494</ref>
In one poll, 30% of mothers who returned to work reported being victims of "maternity harassment", or "matahara".<ref name=Beech /> The [[Bento|obento box]] tradition, where mothers prepare elaborate lunches for their children to take to school, is an example of a domestic female role.<ref>Anne Allison. 2000. Japanese Mothers and Obentōs: The Lunch Box as Ideological State Apparatus. Permitted and Prohibited Desires: Mothers, Comics, and Censorship in Japan, pp. 81-104. Berkeley, CA: University of California Press. http://fds.duke.edu/db/attachment/1111</ref>
A number of government and private post-war policies have contributed to a gendered division of labor.<ref name=Borovoy /> These include a family wage offered by corporations which subsidized health and housing subsidies, marriage bonuses and additional bonuses for each child; and pensions for wives who earn below certain incomes.<ref name=Borovoy /> Additionally, in 1961, income for wives of working men were untaxed below $10,000; income above that amount contributed to overall household income.<ref name=Borovoy /> Corporate culture also plays a role; while many men are expected to socialize with their managers after long work days, women may find trouble balancing child-rearing roles with the demands of mandatory after-work social events.<ref name="nytimes-soble"/>
Some economists suggest that a better support system for working mothers, such as a shorter daily work schedule, would allow more women to work, increasing Japan's economic growth.<ref name=Nohara>{{cite web|last1=Nohara|first1=Yoshiaki|title=Goldman’s Matsui Turns Abe to Womenomics for Japan Growth|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2014-01-21/goldman-s-matsui-turns-abe-to-womenomics-for-japan-growth|publisher=Bloomberg}}</ref> To that end, in 2003, the Japanese government set a goal to have 30% of senior government roles filled by women. In 2015, only 3.5% were; the government has since slashed the 2020 goal to 7%, and set a private industry goal to 15%.<ref name=CNN-Yan>{{cite web|last1=Yan|first1=Sophia|last2=Ogura|first2=Junko|title=Japan slashes target for women in senior positions|url=http://money.cnn.com/2015/12/07/news/economy/japan-women-senior-positions|website=CNN|publisher=CNN|accessdate=17 December 2015}}</ref>
==Family life==
[[File:Japanese family meal in 1950s.jpg|thumb|A Japanese family as presented in a magazine in the 1950s]]
The traditional role of women in Japan has been defined as "three submissions": young women submit to their fathers; married women submit to their husbands, and elderly women submit to their sons.<ref name=Cooper>{{cite book|last1=Cooper|first1=Jessica|title=The Roles of Women, Animals, and Nature in Traditional Japanese and Western Folk Tales Carry Over into Modern Japanese and Western Culture|date=2013|publisher=East Tennessee State University|location=USA|url=http://dc.etsu.edu/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?article=1170&context=honors}}</ref><ref name=Kitamura>{{cite book|last1=Kitamura|first1=Mariko|title=The Animal-Wife: A Comparison of Japanese Folktales with their European Counterparts.|date=1982|publisher=University of California|location=Los Angeles}}</ref> Strains of this arrangement can be seen in contemporary Japan, where housewives are responsible for cooking, cleaning, child-rearing and support their husbands to work without any worries about family,<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Moscicki|first1=Helen|title=EBSCOhost Login|journal=search.ebscohost.com|date=8 July 1944|page=19}}</ref> as well as balancing the household's finances.<ref name="Economist 2015" /> Yet, as the number of dual-income households rises, women and men are sharing household chores, and research shows that this has led to increased satisfaction over households that divide labor in traditional ways.<ref name=Bae>{{cite journal|last1=Bae|first1=Jihey|title=Gender Role Division in Japan and Korea: The Relationship between Realities and Attitudes|journal=Journal of Political Science & Sociology|date=2010|issue=13|pages=71–85}}</ref>
Families, prior to and during the [[Meiji Restoration|Meiji restoration]], relied on a patriarchal lineage of succession, with disobedience to the male head of the household punishable by expulsion from the family unit.<ref name=":0">{{cite book|last1=Borovoy|first1=Amy|title=The Too-Good Wife: Alcohol, codependency, and the politics of nurturance in postwar Japan|date=2005|publisher=University of California Press|location=Berkeley, CA|isbn=0520244524|page=68}}</ref><ref name=Yoshizumi>{{cite book|last1=Yoshizumi|first1=Kyoko|editor1-last=Fujimura-Fanselow|editor1-first=Kumiko|editor2-last=Kameda|editor2-first=Atsuko|title=Japanese Women: new perspectives on the past, present and future|date=1995|publisher=Feminist Press at the City University of New York]|location=New York|pages=183–197}}</ref> Male heads of households with only daughters would adopt male heirs to succeed them, sometimes through [[Arranged marriages in Japan|arranged marriage]] to a daughter.<ref name=Hendry>{{cite book|last1=Hendry|first1=Joy|title=Marriage in changing Japan : community and society|date=1986|publisher=C.E. Tuttle Co.|location=Rutland, Vt.|isbn=0804815062|edition=1st Tuttle}}</ref> Heads of households were responsible for house finances, but could delegate to another family member or retainer (employee).<ref name="Hendry"/> Women in these households were typically subject to arranged marriages at the behest of the household's patriarch.<ref name="Hendry"/> Married women marked themselves by blackening their teeth and shaving their eyebrows.<ref name="Hendry"/>
[[File:Woman in traditional dress holding open parasol and carrying baby on her back. (19949880145).jpg|thumb|upright|Woman in traditional dress holding open parasol and carrying baby on her back, c. 1910]]
After the Meiji period, the head of the household was required to approve of any marriage.<ref name=Hendry /> Until 1908, it remained legal for husbands to murder wives for infidelity.<ref name=Hendry />
As late as the 1930s, arranged marriages continued, and so-called "[[Romantic love|love matches]]" were thought to be rare and somewhat scandalous, especially for the husband, who would be thought "effeminate".<ref name=Hendry /><ref name=Iwasaki>{{cite journal|last1=Iwasaki|first1=Yasu|title=Divorce in Japan|journal=American Journal of Sociology|date=1930|volume=36}}</ref>
The Post-War Constitution, however, codified women’s right to choose their partners.<ref name=Hendry /> Article 24 of [[Constitution of Japan|Japan's Constitution]] states:
:''Marriage shall be based only on the mutual consent of both sexes and it shall be maintained through mutual cooperation with the equal rights of husband and wife as a basis. With regard to choice of spouse, property rights, inheritance, choice of domicile, divorce and other matters pertaining to marriage and the family, laws shall be enacted from the standpoint of individual dignity and the essential equality of the sexes.''
This established several changes to women’s roles in the family, such as the right to inherit the family home or land, and the right of women (over the age of 20) to marry without the consent of the house patriarch.<ref name=Hendry />
[[File:Morioka Kinder 2.JPG|thumb|left|150px|A little girl in Morioka.]]
In the early Meiji period, many girls married at age 16; by the post-war period, it had risen to 23, and continued to rise.<ref name=Hendry /> The average age for a Japanese woman’s first marriage has steadily risen since 1970, from 24 to 29.3 years old in 2015.<ref name="Cabinet Office 1-1">{{cite web|title = Population, Family and Household|url = http://www.gender.go.jp/english_contents/pr_act/pub/pamphlet/women-and-men15/pdf/1-1.pdf|publisher = Japan Cabinet Office Gender Equality Bureau|accessdate = 15 December 2015}}</ref>
===Right to divorce=== In the [[Edo period|Tokugawa period]], men could [[divorce]] their wives simply through stating their intention to do so in a letter. Wives could not legally arrange for a divorce, but options included joining convents, such as at [[Kamakura]], where men were not permitted to go, thus assuring a permanent separation.<ref name=Hendry />
Under the Meiji system, however, the law limited grounds for divorce to seven events: sterility, adultery, disobedience to the parents-in-law, loquacity, larceny, jealousy, and disease. However, the law offered a protection for divorcees by guaranteeing a wife could not be sent away if she had nowhere else to go.<ref name=Hendry /> Furthermore, the law allowed a woman to request a divorce, so long as she was accompanied by a male relative and could prove desertion or imprisonment of the husband, profligacy, or mental or physical illness.<ref name=Hendry />
By 1898, cruelty was added to the grounds for a woman to divorce; the law also allowed divorce through mutual agreement of the husband and wife. However, children were assumed to remain with the male head of the household.<ref name=Hendry /> In contemporary Japan, children are more likely to live with single mothers than single fathers; in 2013, 7.4% of children were living in single-mother households; only 1.3% live with their fathers.<ref name="Cabinet Office 1-1" />
When divorce was granted under equal measures to both sexes under the post-war constitution, divorce rates steadily increased.<ref name=Hendry />
In 2015, Article 733 of Japan’s Civil Code that states that women cannot remarry 6 months after divorce was reduced to 100 days. The 6 month ban on remarriage for women was previously aiming to "avoid uncertainty regarding the identity of the legally presumed father of any child born in that time period". Under article 772, presumes that after a divorce, a child born 300 days after divorce is the legal child of the previous husband. A ruling issued on December 16, 2015, the Supreme Court of Japan ruled that in light of the new 100 days before women's remarriage law, so that there is no confusion over the paternity of a child born to a woman who remarried, any child born after 200 days of remarriage is the legal child of the current husband.
The Ministry of Japan revealed the outline of an amendment for the Civil Code of Japan on February 18, 2016. This amend shortens the women's remarriage period to 100 days and allows any woman who is not pregnant during the divorce to remarry immediately after divorce.<ref>Umeda, S. (2016, February 26). Global Legal Monitor. Retrieved December 04, 2016, from https://www.loc.gov/law/foreign-news/article/japan-new-instructions-allow-women-to-remarry-100-days-after-divorce/</ref>
===Surname change=== The [[Law of Japan|Civil Code of Japan]] requires legally married spouses to have the same surname. Although the law is gender-neutral, meaning that either spouse is allowed to change his/her name to that of the other spouse, Japanese women have traditionally [[Maiden and married names|adopt their husband’s family name]] and 96% of women continue to do so as of 2015.<ref name="Guardian">{{cite web|author1 = Reuters in Tokyo|title = Japanese women in court fight to keep their surnames after marriage|url = https://www.theguardian.com/world/2015/dec/11/japan-supreme-court-rule-one-surname-law-married-couples|website = The Guardian|publisher = Reuters|accessdate = 15 December 2015|archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20151211071657/http://www.theguardian.com/world/2015/dec/11/japan-supreme-court-rule-one-surname-law-married-couples|archivedate = 11 December 2015}}</ref> In 2015, the [[Japanese Supreme Court]] upheld the constitutionality of the law, noting that women could use their maiden names informally, and stating that it was for the legislature to decide on whether to pass new legislation on separate spousal names.<ref>https://www.bbc.com/news/world-asia-35109455</ref>
===Motherhood===
While women before the Meiji period were often considered incompetent in the raising of children, the Meiji period saw [[mother]]hood as the central task of women, and allowed education of women toward this end.<ref name=Niwa>{{cite journal|last1=Niwa|first1=Akiko|title=The Formation of the Myth of Motherhood in Japan|journal=US Japan Women's Journal|date=1993|volume=4|pages=70–82}}</ref> Raising children and keeping household affairs in order were seen as women's role in the state.<ref name=nolteandhastings>{{cite book|last1=Nolte|first1=Sharon|last2=Hastings|first2=Sally|authorlink1=The Meiji State's Policy Toward Women, 1890-1910|editor1-last=Bernstein|editor1-first=GL|title=Recreating Japanese Women, 1600-1945|date=1991|publisher=University of California Press|location=Berkeley}}</ref> Women's political and social advancement was thus tied to their role as mothers.<ref name=Borovoy />
Today, Japanese mothers are still seen as managers of a household, including the behavior of their children. For example, media reports often focus on the apologies of criminals' mothers.<ref name=Iwao>{{cite book|last1=Iwao|first1=Sumiko|title=The Japanese Woman: Traditional Image and Changing Reality|date=1993|publisher=Free Press|location=New York}}</ref>
There is continuing debate about the role women's education plays in [[Aging of Japan|Japan's declining birthrate]].<ref name=Sanger>{{cite news|last1=Sanger|first1=David|title=Tokyo official ties birth decline to higher education|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/14/world/tokyo-official-ties-birth-decline-to-education.html|accessdate=26 December 2015|agency=New York Times|publisher=New York Times|date=14 June 1990|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150525195316/http://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/14/world/tokyo-official-ties-birth-decline-to-education.html|archivedate=25 May 2015}}</ref> Japan's [[total fertility rate]] is 1.4 children born per woman (2015 estimate),<ref name="cia.gov">https://www.cia.gov/library/publications/the-world-factbook/geos/ja.html</ref> which is below the replacement rate of 2.1. Japanese women have their first child at an average age of 30.3 (2012 estimate).<ref name="cia.gov"/>
Government policies to increase the birthrate include early education designed to develop citizens into capable parents.<ref name=Naikakufu>{{cite book|last1=(Cabinet Office)|first1=Naikakufu|title=Shōshika shakai hakusho (Heisei 17nen han) – Shōshika taisaku no genjō to kadai [White Paper for a Society with a Declining Birthrate – Situation and Outline of Measures against the Declining Birthrate]|date=2005|publisher=Gyosei|location=Tokyo}}</ref> Some critics of these policies believe that this emphasis on birth rate is incompatible with a full recognition of women's equality in Japan.<ref name=Boling>{{cite journal|last1=Boling|first1=Patricia|title=Family Policy in Japan|journal=Journal of Social Policy|date=1998|volume=27|issue=2|pages=173–190|doi=10.1017/s0047279498005285}}</ref><ref name=Schoppa>{{cite book|last1=Schoppa|first1=Leonard J.|title=Race for the exits: the unraveling of Japan's system of social protection|date=2008|publisher=Cornell University Press|location=Ithaca, N.Y.|isbn=0801474450|edition=[Pbk.].}}</ref><ref name=Lenz>{{cite journal|last1=Lenz|first1=Ilse|title=From Mothers of the Nation to Global Civil Society: The changing role of the Japanese women's movement in Globalization|journal=Social Science Japan|date=2006|volume=9|issue=1|pages=91–102|doi=10.1093/ssjj/jyk011}}</ref>
==Education==
[[File:Summer Evening Beside the Lake by Fujishima Takeji (Geidai Museum).jpg|thumb|left|Teenage girls reading books, ''Summer Evening Beside the Lake (1897)'' by [[Fujishima Takeji]] ]]
With the development of society, more and more girls go to colleges to receive higher education.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Huang, Placier|first1=Haigen, Peggy|title=Four Generations of Women's Educational Experience in a Rural Chinese Community.|journal=Gender & Education|date=October 2015|volume=27|issue=6|page=599–617|doi=10.1080/09540253.2015.1069799}}</ref> Today, more than half of Japanese women are [[vocational college|college]] or [[university]] graduates.<ref name=Chanlett /> The proportion of female researchers in Japan is 14.6%.<ref name="Cabinet Bureau 1-8">{{cite web|last1=Gender Equality Bureau|first1=Cabinet Office|title=Education and Research Fields|url=http://www.gender.go.jp/english_contents/pr_act/pub/pamphlet/women-and-men15/pdf/1-8.pdf|website=gender.go.jp|publisher=Japan Gender Equality Bureau Cabinet Office|accessdate=17 December 2015}}</ref>
Modern education of women began in earnest during the Meiji era's modernization campaign. The first schools for women began during this time, though education topics were highly gendered, with women learning arts of the [[samurai]] class, such as [[Tea ceremony|tea ceremonies]] and [[Ikebana|flower arrangement]]. The 1871 education code established that students should be educated "without any distinction of class or sex".<ref name=Burton>{{cite book|last1=Burton|first1=Margaret Emerstine|title=The Education of Women in Japan|date=1914|publisher=Fleming H. Revell (Harvard University Preservation Program)|location=Cambridge, MA}}</ref> Nonetheless, after 1891 students were typically segregated after third grade, and many girls did not extend their educations past middle school.<ref name=Koyama />
By the end of the Meiji period, there was a women's school in every prefecture in Japan, operated by a mix of government, missionary, and private interests.<ref name=Patessio>{{cite journal|last1=Patessio|first1=Mara|title=Women getting a ‘university’ education in Meiji Japan: discourses, realities, and individual lives.|journal=Japan Forum|date=Dec 2013|volume=25|issue=4|pages=556–581|doi=10.1080/09555803.2013.788053|url=http://search.ebscohost.com/login.aspx?direct=true&db=a9h&AN=92664352&site=ehost-live|accessdate=23 December 2015|issn=0955-5803|postscript={{subscription needed|via=[https://www.ebsco.com EBSCO]'s Academic Search Complete}}}}</ref> By 1910, very few universities accepted women.<ref name=Koyama>{{cite book|last1=Koyama|first1=Takashi|title=The changing social position of women in Japan|date=1961|publisher=UNESCO|location=Paris|url=http://unesdoc.unesco.org/images/0000/000028/002807eo.pdf|accessdate=17 December 2015}}</ref> Graduation was not assured, as often women were pulled out of school to marry or to study "practical matters".<ref name=Patessio />
[[File:Toyama municipal Toyama girls' higher school(2).jpg|thumb|Girls' high school in early period, c. 1939.]]
Notably, [[Tsuruko Haraguchi]], the first woman in Japan to earn a PhD, did so in the US, as no Meiji-era institution would allow her to receive her doctorate.<ref name=Patessio /> She and other women who studied abroad and returned to Japan, such as [[Yoshioka Yayoi]] and [[Tsuda Umeko]], were among the first wave of women's educators who lead the way to the incorporation of women in Japanese academia.<ref name=Patessio />
After 1945, the [[Occupation of Japan|Allied occupation]] aimed to enforce equal education between sexes; this included a recommendation in 1946 to provide compulsory co-education until the age of 16.<ref name=Koyama /> By the end of 1947, nearly all middle schools and more than half of high schools were co-educational.<ref name=Koyama />
In 2012, 98.1% of female students and 97.8% of male students were able to reach senior high school.<ref name="MEXT 2012">{{cite web|last1=(MEXT)|first1=Ministry of Education, Culture, Sports and Technology|title=Gakko kihon chosa - Heisei 24 nendo (sokuho) kekka no gaiyo|url=http://www.mext.go.jp/component/b_menu/houdou/__icsFiles/afieldfile/2012/08/30/1324976_02.pdf|website=MEXT|publisher=Japanese Ministry of Education, Culture, Sports and Technology|accessdate=18 December 2015}}</ref> Of those, 55.6% of men and 45.8% of women continued with undergraduate studies, although 10% of these female graduates attended [[junior college]].<ref name="White Paper 2014">{{cite journal|last1=Cabinet Office|first1=Gender Equality Bureau|title=White Paper on Gender Equality 2013|journal=Statistical Topics (Japanese)|date=April 2014|volume=80|url=http://www.stat.go.jp/data/kagaku/kekka/topics/topics80.htm|accessdate=19 December 2015}}</ref>
==Health== At 87 years, the [[life expectancy]] of Japanese women is [[List of countries by life expectancy|the longest]] of any gender in the world.<ref name=Chanlett />
[[Abortion in Japan]] is legal under some restrictions. The number per year has declined by 500,000 since 1975. Of the 200,000 abortions performed per year, however, 10% are teenage women, a number which has risen since 1975.<ref name="Cabinet Office 1-7">{{cite web|last1=Cabinet Office|first1=Gender Equality Bureau|title=Women and Men in Japan|url=http://www.gender.go.jp/english_contents/pr_act/pub/pamphlet/women-and-men15/|website=Gender.go.jp|publisher=Japanese Gender Equality Bureau Cabinet Office|accessdate=16 December 2015}}</ref>
==Laws against crime==
===Domestic violence=== In 2002, the government of Japan passed a law against [[domestic violence]].<ref name=Borovoy /> In 2013, 100,000 women reported domestic violence to shelters.<ref name="Cabinet Office 1-6">{{cite web|last1=Cabinet Office|first1=Gender Equality Bureau|title=Violence against Women|url=http://www.gender.go.jp/english_contents/pr_act/pub/pamphlet/women-and-men15/pdf/1-6.pdf|website=gender.go.jp|publisher=Japanese Gender Equality Bureau Cabinet Office|accessdate=16 December 2015}}</ref> Of the 10,000 entering protective custody at the shelter, nearly half arrived with children or other family members.<ref name="Cabinet Office 1-6" />
In Japan, domestic disputes have traditionally been seen as a result of negligence or poor support from the female partner.<ref name=Borovoy>{{cite book|last1=Borovoy|first1=Amy|title=The too-good wife: alcohol, codependency, and the politics of nurturance in postwar Japan|date=2005|publisher=University of California Press|location=Berkeley, CA|isbn=0520244524}}</ref> A partner's outburst can therefore be a source of [[shame]] to the wife or mother of the man they are supposed to care for.<ref name=Lebra>{{cite book|last1=Lebra|first1=Takie|title=Japanese Women: Constraint and Fulfillment|date=1984|publisher=University of Hawaii Press|location=Honolulu}}</ref> Because women's abuse would be detrimental to the family of the abused, legal, medical and social intervention in domestic disputes was rare.<ref name=Nemoto2>{{cite journal|last1=Nemoto|first1=Keiko|last2=Rodriguez|first2=Rachel|last3=Valhmu|first3=Lucy|title=Exploring the Health Care Needs of Women in Abusive Relationships in Japan|journal=Health Care for Women International|date=April 2006|volume=27|issue=4|pages=290–306|doi=10.1080/07399330500511774|url=http://search.ebscohost.com/login.aspx?direct=true&db=a9h&AN=20379936&site=ehost-live|accessdate=26 December 2015|publisher=Taylor and Francis|issn=0739-9332|postscript={{subscription needed|via=[https://www.ebsco.com EBSCO]'s Academic Search Complete}}}}</ref>
After a spate of research during the 1990s, Japan passed the Prevention of Spousal Violence and the Protection of Victims act in 2001.<ref name=Nemoto2 /><ref>{{cite book|last1=The Gender Equality Bureau of the Cabinet Office|title=Heisei 14 nenban danjo kyodo sankaku hakusho [FY 2001, Annual report on the state of formation of a gender equal society]|date=2002|publisher=Zaimusyou insatsu Kyoku.|location=Tokyo}}</ref> The law referred to domestic violence as "a violation of the constitutional principle of equal rights between sexes". This law established protection orders from abusive spouses and created support centers in every prefecture, but women are still reluctant to report abuse to doctors out of shame or fear that the report would be shared with the abuser.<ref name=Nemoto2 /> A 2001 survey showed that many health professionals were not trained to handle domestic abuse and blamed women who sought treatment.<ref name=Nemoto2 /><ref name=Tokyoto>{{cite journal|last1=Tokyoto Iryo Syakai Jigyo Kyokai Iryo Fukushi Mondai Kenkyu Kai|title=Iryokikan ni okeru domesutikku baiorensu ni tsuite no chosa hokokusho [A report regarding domestic violence in health care settings]|journal= Josei no anzen to kenko no tameno shien kyoiku senta tushin|date=2001|volume=3|pages=23–38}}</ref>
===Stalking=== [[Stalking|Stalking laws]] were passed in 2000 after the media attention given to the murder of a [[Murder of Shiori Ino|university student]] who had been a stalking victim.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://search.japantimes.co.jp/cgi-bin/nn20051221a4.html|title=Stalker-killer's life term upheld|work=[[The Japan Times]]|date=December 21, 2005|accessdate=September 16, 2010}}</ref> With nearly 21,000 reports of stalking in 2013, 90.3% of the victims were women and 86.9% of the perpetrators were men.<ref name="Cabinet Office 1-6" /> Anti-stalking laws in Japan were expanded in 2013 to include [[Cyberstalking|e-mail harassment]], after the widely publicized 2012 murder of a young woman who had reported such harassment to police.<ref name=Aquino>{{cite news|last1=Aquino|first1=Faith|title=Japan toughens anti-stalking laws, includes repeated emailing as harassment|url=http://japandailypress.com/japan-toughens-anti-stalking-laws-includes-repeated-emailing-as-harassment-2731299/|accessdate=20 December 2015|agency=Japan Daily Press|date=2013-06-27|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150928181217/http://japandailypress.com/japan-toughens-anti-stalking-laws-includes-repeated-emailing-as-harassment-2731299/|archivedate=2015-09-28|location=https://web.archive.org}}</ref> Stalking reports are growing at a faster rate in Japan than any other country.<ref name="Al-jazeera stalk">{{cite web|title = Japan's stalking crisis|url = http://www.aljazeera.com/programmes/101east/2014/12/japan-stalking-crisis-2014128103943425348.html|website = Al-jazeera|publisher = Al-jazeera|accessdate = 20 December 2015|archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20150905141833/http://www.aljazeera.com/programmes/101east/2014/12/japan-stalking-crisis-2014128103943425348.html|archivedate = 5 September 2015|location = https://web.archive.org/web/}}</ref>
===Sexual assault=== Surveys show that between 28% and 70% of women have been groped on train cars.<ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/8254389.stm "Tokyo police act on train gropers"]</ref><ref name=Mitsutoshii /> Some railway companies designate [[women-only passenger car]]s<ref>{{Cite web|title=Untitled Document |url=http://www.belsona-strategic.com/hisandhers_subway.htm |date=2007-12-26 |accessdate=2015-12-20 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071226060039/http://www.belsona-strategic.com/hisandhers_subway.htm |archivedate=December 26, 2007 }}</ref><ref name=ABC>[http://abcnews.go.com/GMA/International/story?id=803965&CMP=OTC-RSSFeeds0312 "Japan Tries Women Only Train Cars to Stop Groping: Tokyo Subway Experiment Attempts to Slow Epidemic of Subway Fondling"] An ABC News article.</ref><ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20071218143817/http://www.truthout.org/cgi-bin/artman/exec/view.cgi/35/11500 "Women Only Cars on Commuter Trains Cause Controversy in Japan"]</ref> though there are no penalties for men to ride in a women-only car.<ref name=Mitsutoshii>{{cite journal|last1=Mitsutoshii|first1=Horii|last2=Burgess|first2=Adam|title=Constructing sexual risk: 'Chikan', collapsing male authority and the emergence of women-only train carriages in Japan.|journal=Health, Risk & Society|date=2012|volume=14|issue=1|pages=41–55|doi=10.1080/13698575.2011.641523|issn=1369-8575|postscript={{subscription needed|via=[https://www.ebsco.com EBSCO]'s Academic Search Complete}}}}</ref> Gropers can be punished with seven years or less of jail time and/or face fines of just under $500.<ref name=ABC />
The use of women-only cars in Japan has been critiqued from various perspectives.<ref name=Mitsutoshii /> Some suggest that the presence of the cars makes women who choose not to use them more vulnerable. Public comment sometimes include the argument that women-only cars are a step too far in protecting women.<ref name=Mitsutoshii /> Some academics have argued that the cars impose the burden of social segregation to women, rather than seeking the punishment of criminals.<ref name=Freedman>{{cite journal|last1=Freedman |first1=Alisa |title=Commuting Gazes: Schoolgirls, Salarymen, and Electric Trains in Tokyo |journal=The Journal of Transport History |date=1 March 2002 |volume=23 |issue=1 |url=https://www.questia.com/library/journal/1P3-115159347/commuting-gazes-schoolgirls-salarymen-and-electric |accessdate=27 December 2015 |issn=0022-5266 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151227000859/https://www.questia.com/library/journal/1P3-115159347/commuting-gazes-schoolgirls-salarymen-and-electric |archivedate=December 27, 2015 }}</ref> Another critique suggests the cars send the signal that men create a dangerous environment for women, who cannot protect themselves.<ref name=Mitsutoshii />
==Beauty==
The Japanese cosmetics industry is the second largest in the world, earning over $15 billion per year.<ref name=Miller>{{cite book|last1=Miller|first1=Laura|title=Beauty up : exploring contemporary Japanese body aesthetics|date=2006|publisher=University of California Press|location=Berkeley, Calif.|isbn=9780520245082|edition=2. [printing]}}</ref> The strong market for beauty products has been connected to the value placed on self-discipline and self-improvement in Japan, where the body is mastered through ''[[kata]]'', repeated actions aspiring toward perfection, such as bowing.<ref name=Miller />
In the [[Heian period]], feminine beauty standards favored darkened teeth, some body fat, and eyebrows painted above the original (which were shaved).<ref name=Morris>{{cite book|last1=Morris|first1=Ivan|title=The world of the shining prince : court life in ancient Japan|date=1995|publisher=Kodansha International|location=New York [u.a.]|isbn=978-1568360294|edition=[3. Dr.]}}</ref>
Beauty corporations have had a role in creating contemporary standards of beauty in Japan since the Meiji era. For example, the Japanese cosmetics firm, [[Shiseido]] published a magazine, ''Hannatsubaki'', with beauty advice for women emphasizing hair styles and contemporary fashion.<ref name=Miller /> The pre-war "[[modern girl]]" of Japan followed Western fashions as filtered through this kind of Japanese media.<ref name=Miller />
Products reflect several common anxieties among Japanese women. Multiple polls suggest that women worry about "fatness, breast size, hairiness and bust size".<ref name=Miller /> The idealized figure of a Japanese woman is generally fragile and petite.<ref name="Keene, Donald 1989"/> Japanese beauty ideals favor small features and narrow faces.<ref name=Miller /> Big eyes are admired, especially when they have "double eyelids".<ref name="Keene, Donald 1989">[Keene, Donald. "The Japanese Idea of Beauty". The Wilson Quarterly 13.1 (1989): 128–135. Print.]</ref>
Another ideal is pale skin. Tanned skin was historically associated with the working-class, and pale skin associated with the nobility.<ref name=Miller /> Many women in Japan will take precaution to avoid the sun, and some lotions are sold to make the skin whiter.<ref name=Kyo />
By the 1970s, "[[cuteness]]" had emerged as a desirable aesthetic, which some scholars linked to a boom in [[Manga|comic books]] that emphasized young-looking girls, or Lolitas.<ref name=Miller /> While these characters typically included larger eyes, research suggests that it was not a traditional standard of beauty in Japan, preferred in medical research and described as "unsightly" by cosmetic researchers of the Edo era.<ref name=Kyo>{{cite book|last1=Selden|first1=Cho Kyo; translated by Kyoko|title=The search for the beautiful woman a cultural history of Japanese and Chinese beauty|date=2012|publisher=Rowman & Littlefield Publishers, Inc.|location=Lanham|isbn=9781442218956}}</ref>
[[Japanese clothing|Clothing]] is another element in beauty standards for women in Japan. Again, femininity is a large factor; therefore, [[pink]]s, reds, bows, and frills are all found in their apparel. [[Kimonos]], full-length silk robes, are worn by women on special occasions.<ref name="Keene, Donald 1989"/>
==Geisha== {{Main article|Geisha}}
[[File:Geiko Kimiha.jpg|thumb|left|Geisha in Miyagawa-chō, Kyoto]]
A {{nihongo|[[geisha]]|芸者}} is a traditional Japanese female entertainer who acts as a hostess and whose skills include performing various Japanese arts such as classical music, dance, games, serving tea and conversation, mainly to entertain male customers.<ref name="Dalby, Liza 1992">[Dalby, Liza. "Kimona and Geisha". ''The Threepenny Review 51'' (1992): 30–31. Print.]</ref> Geisha are trained very seriously as skilled entertainers and are not to be confused with [[prostitutes]]. The training program starts from a young age, typically 15 years old, and can take anywhere from six months to three years.<ref name="Dalby, Liza 1992"/>
A young geisha in training, under the age of 20, is called a [[maiko]]. Maiko (literally "dance girl") are apprentice geisha, and this stage can last for years. Maiko learn from their senior geisha mentor and follow them to all their engagements. Then at around the age of 20–22, the maiko is promoted to a full-fledged geisha<ref name="ReferenceA">[Warta, T. (n.d.). Geisha Makeup Designs and Origin.]</ref> in a ceremony called [[erikae]] (turning of the collar).
==Contraception and sexuality== [[File:Non marital by countries.gif|thumb|400px|The percentage of births to unmarried women in selected countries, 1980 and 2007.<ref name="non_mar1">{{cite web|url=https://www.cdc.gov/nchs/data/databriefs/db18.htm|title=Changing Patterns of Nonmarital Childbearing in the United States |work=CDC/National Center for Health Statistics|date=May 13, 2009|accessdate=September 24, 2011}}</ref> As can be seen in the figure, Japan has not followed the trend of other Western countries of children born outside of marriage to the same degree.]] {{Further|Sexuality in Japan}} In Japan, the [[contraceptive pill]] was legalized in 1999, much later than in most Western countries.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Cosgrove-Mather |first1=Bootie |title=Japanese Women Shun The Pill |url=https://www.cbsnews.com/news/japanese-women-shun-the-pill/ |accessdate=2018-10-14 |work=CBS News |date=20 August 2004 }}</ref> Its use is still low, with many couples preferring [[condom]]s. Sexuality in Japan has developed separately from mainland [[Asia]], and Japan did not adopt the [[Confucian view of marriage]] in which [[chastity]] is highly valued. However, births outside marriage remain rare in Japan.

A '''young adult''' is generally a person ranging in age from their late teens or early twenties to their thirties, although definitions and opinions, such as [[Erik Erikson]]'s [[Erikson's stages of psychosocial development|stages of human development]], vary. The young [[adult]] stage in human development precedes [[middle age|middle adulthood]]. A person in the middle adulthood stage ages from 40 or 41 to 64. In [[old age]], a person is 65 years old or older.<ref name="Martin Briner">Martin Briner, [http://www.dean.usma.edu/math/activities/cape/Constructivism/501erik.htm Erik Erikson page] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060821183134/http://www.dean.usma.edu/math/activities/cape/Constructivism/501erik.htm |date=2006-08-21 }}, 1999, on Briner's [http://www.dean.usma.edu/math/activities/cape/Constructivism/501learn.htm site about learning theories] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20061007042838/http://www.dean.usma.edu/math/activities/cape/Constructivism/501learn.htm |date=2006-10-07 }}, USMA Department of Mathematical Sciences, Center for Assessment and Program Evaluation (CAPE), United States Military Academy at West Point. Accessed 24 November 2006.</ref>
==Time co-ordinates== For a variety of reasons, timeliness on young adulthood cannot be exactly defined—producing different results according to the different mix of overlapping indices (legal, maturational, occupational, sexual, emotional and the like) employed, or on whether 'a ''developmental perspective''... [or] the ''socialization perspective''<ref name=Levinson1986>{{cite journal |last1=Levinson |first1=Daniel J. |title=A conception of adult development |journal=American Psychologist |volume=41 |issue=1 |year=1986 |pages=3–13 |doi=10.1037/0003-066X.41.1.3 }}</ref> is taken. 'Sub-phases in this timetable of psychosocial growth patterns... are not rigid, and both social change and individual variations must be taken into account'{{sfn|Rapoport|Rapoport|1980|p=46}}—not to mention regional and cultural differences. Arguably indeed, with people living longer, and also reaching puberty earlier, 'age norms for major life events have become highly elastic'{{sfn|Sheehy|1996|p=15}} by the twenty-first century.
Some have suggested that, after {{'}}''Pre-adulthood''... in the first 20 years or so... the second era, ''Early Adulthood'', lasts from about age 17 to 45... the adult era of greatest energy and abundance and of greatest contradiction and stress.'<ref name=Levinson1986/> Within that framework, 'the ''Early Adult Transition'' (17–22) is a developmental bridge between pre-adulthood and early adulthood',<ref name=Levinson1986/> recognizing that 'the transition into adulthood is not a clear-cut dividing line'.{{sfn|Zastrow|Kirst-Ashman|2009|p=411}} One might alternatively speak of 'a ''Provisional Adulthood (18–30)''... [&] the initiation to First Adulthood'{{sfn|Sheehy|1996|p=10}}{{sfn|Sheehy|1996|p=59}} as following that.
Despite all such fluidity, there is broad agreement that it is essentially the twenties and thirties which constitute {{'}}''Early adulthood''... the basis for what [[Daniel Levinson|Levinson]] calls ''the Dream''—a vision of his [or her] goal's in life which provide motivation and enthusiasm for the future'.{{sfn|Birch|1997|p=220}}
==Health== Young/prime adulthood can be considered the healthiest time of life{{sfn|Zastrow|Kirst-Ashman|2009|p=411}} and young adults are generally in good health, subject neither to [[disease]] nor the problems of [[senescence]]. Strength and [[Physical fitness|physical performance]] reach their peak from 18–39 years of age.<ref name="auto">{{cite journal |vauthors=Tarpenning KM, Hamilton-Wessler M, Wiswell RA, Hawkins SA |title=Endurance training delays age of decline in leg strength and muscle morphology |journal=Medicine and Science in Sports and Exercise |volume=36 |issue=1 |pages=74–8 |year=2004 |pmid=14707771 |doi=10.1249/01.MSS.0000106179.73735.A6 }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Knechtle B, Rüst CA, Rosemann T, Lepers R |title=Age-related changes in 100-km ultra-marathon running performance |journal=Age |volume=34 |issue=4 |pages=1033–45 |year=2012 |pmid=21796378 |pmc=3682063 |doi=10.1007/s11357-011-9290-9 }}</ref> [[Flexibility (anatomy)|Flexibility]] may decrease with age throughout adulthood.<ref name="auto"/><ref>{{cite journal|title=The Association of Flexibility, Balance, and Lumbar Strength with Balance Ability: Risk of Falls in Older Adults|first1=Emilio J. Martínez-López|last1=Emilio|first2=Fidel|last2=Hita-Contreras|first3=Pilar M.|last3=Jiménez-Lara|first4=Pedro|last4=Latorre-Román|first5=Antonio|last5=Martínez-Amat|date=1 May 2014|publisher=|journal=J Sports Sci Med|volume=13|issue=2|pages=349–357|pmid=24790489|pmc=3990889}}</ref><ref name="auto"/>
Women reach their peak [[fertility]] in their early 20s.<ref>{{MedlinePlusEncyclopedia|001191|Infertility}}</ref> *At age 30 **75% will have a conception ending in a live birth within one year *At age 35 ** 66% will have a conception ending in a live birth within one year *At age 40 **44% will have a conception ending in a live birth within one year<ref>{{cite journal|url=https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmedhealth/PMH0076677/|title=Infertility: Overview|first=|last=pmhdev|date=25 March 2015|publisher=|via=www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov}}</ref><ref name=Leridon2004>{{cite journal |last1=Leridon |first1=H. |title=Can assisted reproduction technology compensate for the natural decline in fertility with age? A model assessment |journal=Human Reproduction |volume=19 |issue=7 |pages=1548–53 |year=2004 |pmid=15205397 |doi=10.1093/humrep/deh304 }}</ref>
In [[developed countries]], [[mortality rate]]s for the 18–40 age group are typically very low. Men are more likely to die at this age than women, particularly in the 18–25 group: reasons include [[car accidents]] and [[suicide]]. Mortality statistics among men and women level off during the late twenties and thirties, due in part to good health and less [[recklessness (psychology)|risk-taking behavior]].<ref>{{cite web | title = Life Expectancy Profiles | work = | publisher = BBC | date= 6 June 2005 | url = http://www.bbc.co.uk/dna/h2g2/A3784854 | accessdate = 2007-06-26 }}</ref>
Regarding disease, [[cancer]] is much less common in young than in older adults.<ref>{{cite web | title = UK cancer mortality statistics by age| publisher = Cancer Research UK |date=May 2007| url = http://info.cancerresearchuk.org/cancerstats/mortality/age/ | accessdate = 2007-06-26 }}</ref> Exceptions are [[testicular cancer]], [[cervical cancer]], and [[Hodgkin's lymphoma]].<ref>{{cite web | title = Cancers at a glance | publisher = Cancer Research UK |date=May 2007| url = http://info.cancerresearchuk.org/cancerandresearch/cancers/ | accessdate = 2007-06-26 }}</ref> In [[sub-Saharan Africa]], [[HIV]]/[[AIDS]] has hit the early adult population particularly hard. According to a [[United Nations]] report, AIDS has significantly increased mortality of between ages 20 to 55 for African males and 20 to 45 for African females, reducing the [[life expectancy]] in South Africa by 18 years and in Botswana by 34 years.<ref>{{Cite journal |author1=Ngom, Pierre |author2=Clark, Samuel |lastauthoramp=yes | title = Adult Mortality In The Era Of HIV/AIDS: Sub-Saharan Africa | publisher = Population Division, Department of Economic and Social Affairs, United Nations Secretariat | date= 18 August 2003 | url = https://www.un.org/esa/population/publications/adultmort/CLARK_Paper3.pdf | format = pdf | accessdate = 2007-06-26}}</ref>
==Early adulthood== According to Erikson, in the wake of the adolescent emphasis upon [[identity formation]], 'the young adult, emerging from the search for and insistence on identity, is eager and willing to fuse their identity with that of others. He [or she] is ready for [[intimacy]], that is, the capacity to commit... to concrete affiliations and partnerships.'{{sfn|Erikson|1975|p=255}} To do so means the ability 'to face the fear of ego loss in situations which call for self-abandon: in the solidarity of close affiliations, in orgasms and [[sex|sexual unions]], in close friendships and in physical combat'.{{sfn|Erikson|1975|p=155}} Avoidance of such experiences 'because of a fear of ego-loss may lead to a deep sense of [[solitude|isolation]] and consequent self-absorption'.{{sfn|Erikson|1975|p=155}}
Where isolation is avoided, the young adult may find instead that 'satisfactory sex relations... in some way take the edge off the hostilities and potential rages caused by the oppositeness of male and female, of fact and fancy, of [[love]] and hate';{{sfn|Erikson|1975|p=257}} and may grow into the ability to exchange intimacy, love and [[compassion]].
In modern societies, young adults in their late teens and early 20s encounter a number of issues as they finish school and begin to hold full-time jobs and take on other responsibilities of adulthood; and 'the young adult is usually preoccupied with self-growth in the context of society and relationships with others.'{{sfn|Birch|1997|p=227}} The danger is that in 'the second era, ''Early Adulthood''... we must make crucially important choices regarding marriage, family, work, and lifestyle before we have the maturity or life experience to choose wisely.'<ref name=Levinson1986/>
While 'young adulthood is filled with avid quests for intimate relationships and other major commitments involving career and life goals', there is also "a parallel pursuit for the formulation of a set of moral values".{{sfn|Zastrow|Kirst-Ashman|2009|p=298}} Erikson has argued that it is only now that what he calls the 'ideological mind' of adolescence gives way to 'that ''[[Ethics|ethical]] sense'' which is the mark of the adult.'{{sfn|Erikson|1975|pp=254–6}}
Reaching adulthood in modern society is not always a linear or clean transition. As generations continue to adapt, new markers of adulthood are created that add different social expectations of what it means to be an adult.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Vandegrift |first1=Darcie |title='We don't have any limits': Russian young adult life narratives through a social generations lens |journal=Journal of Youth Studies |volume=19 |issue=2 |year=2015 |pages=221–36 |doi=10.1080/13676261.2015.1059930 }}</ref>
==Age 30 transition==
Daniel Levinson suggested that the first phase of early adulthood comes to a close around twenty-eight to thirty, when 'at about 28 the provisional character of the twenties is ending and life is becoming more serious... the ''age-thirty crisis''.'<ref name=Levinson1986/> between age 28 and 32', stressing that 'it is not uncommon, at the approach to the thirties, to tear up the life structure one put together to support the original dream of the twenties,'{{sfn|Sheehy|1996|p=47}} and to start anew—'to create the basis for the next life structure.<ref name=Levinson1986/> When 'the Age Thirty Transition' is a difficult one, 'in a severe crisis [s/]he experiences a threat to life itself, the danger of chaos and dissolution, the loss of hope for the future.<ref name=Levinson1986/>
==Settling down== After the relative upheaval of the early 30s, the middle to late 30s are often characterized by '''settling down''': 'the establishment phase', involving 'what we would call ''major life investments''—work, family, friends, community activities, and values.'{{sfn|Rapoport|Rapoport|1980|p=46}}{{sfn|Rapoport|Rapoport|1980|p=72}} What has been termed 'the ''Culminating Life Structure for Early Adulthood'' (33–40) is the vehicle for completing this era and realizing our youthful aspirations.'<ref name=Levinson1986/> People in their thirties may increase the financial and emotional investments they make in their lives, and may have been employed long enough to gain promotions and raises. They often become more focused on advancing their careers and gaining stability in their personal lives—'with marriage and child-rearing,'{{sfn|Rapoport|Rapoport|1980|p=46}} starting a [[family]], coming to the fore as priorities.
[[Gail Sheehy]], however, signposts the same twenties/thirties division rather differently, arguing that nowadays 'the twenties have stretched out into a long Provisional Adulthood', and that in fact 'the transition to the Turbulent Thirties marks the initiation to First Adulthood.'{{sfn|Sheehy|1996|p=55}}{{sfn|Sheehy|1996|p=59}}
==Midlife transition==
Young Adulthood then draws to its close with 'the ''Midlife Transition'', from roughly age 40 to 45'<ref name=Levinson1986/>—producing 'a brand-new passage in the forties, when First Adulthood ends and Second Adulthood begins.'{{sfn|Sheehy|1996|p=14}}
